name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut is a state in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of New England.

name: connecticut
sentence: In the 2010 census, it has the highest per capita income, the Human Development Index (0.962) and the median household income in the United States.

name: connecticut
sentence: It is bordered by Rhode Island to the east, Massachusetts to the north, New York to the west, and Long Island Sound to the south.

name: connecticut
sentence: Its capital is Hartford and its most populated city is Bridgeport.

name: connecticut
sentence: Geographically, the state is part of New England, and although its cultural history comes from the region in the modern era, large sections of it are increasingly linked to the three-state region with New York and New Jersey.

name: connecticut
sentence: The state is named for the Connecticut River which approximately bisects the state.

name: connecticut
sentence: The word "Connecticut" is derived from various anglicized spellings of "Quononoquett (Conanicut)," a Mohegan-Pequot word for "long tidal raz".

name: connecticut
sentence: The first European settlers in Connecticut were Dutch, who established a small, short-lived settlement called Fort Hoop in Hartford, at the confluence of the park and Connecticut Rivers.

name: connecticut
sentence: Half of Connecticut was originally part of the Dutch colony New Netherlands, which included much of the land between Connecticut and Delaware, although the first large colonies were established in the 1630s by the English.

name: connecticut
sentence: Thomas Hooker led a band of supporters of the Massachusetts Bay colony and founded the Connecticut colony

name: connecticut
sentence: The colonies of Connecticut and New Haven have prepared documents of the Fundamental Orders, considered the first constitutions in America.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1662, the three colonies merged under a royal charter, making Connecticut a colony of the Crown.

name: connecticut
sentence: It was one of the Thirteen Colonies that rejected British domination in the American Revolution.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut is the third smallest state per zone, the 29th most populated, and the fourth most densely populated of the 50 states.

name: connecticut
sentence: It is known as the "Constitutional State", the "Nutmeg State", the "Provisions State" and the "Country of Holy Habitudes".

name: connecticut
sentence: It influenced the development of the U.S. federal government (see Connecticut Compromise).

name: connecticut
sentence: The Connecticut River, the Thames River and ports along the Long Island Strait have given Connecticut a strong maritime tradition that continues today.

name: connecticut
sentence: The state also has a long history of hosting the financial services industry, including insurance companies in Hartford and hedge funds in Fairfield County.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut is bordered south by Long Island Sound, west by New York, north by Massachusetts, and east by Rhode Island.

name: connecticut
sentence: The state capital and the fourth largest city is Hartford, and other major cities (by population) are Bridgeport, New Haven, Stamford, Waterbury, Norwalk, Danbury, New Britain, Greenwich and Bristol.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut is a little bigger than the country of Montenegro.

name: connecticut
sentence: There are 169 incorporated cities in Connecticut.

name: connecticut
sentence: The highest peak in Connecticut is Mount Bear at Salisbury in the northwest corner of the state.

name: connecticut
sentence: The highest point is just east of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York (42°3′ N, 73°29′ W), on the southern slope of Mount Frissell, which peaks near Massachusetts.

name: connecticut
sentence: In contrast, many coastal cities have areas less than 20 feet (6 m) above sea level.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut has a long maritime history and a reputation based on this history – but the state does not have a direct (technically speaking) seafront.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Connecticut coast is located on Long Island Strait, an estuary.

name: connecticut
sentence: State access to the open Atlantic Ocean is to both the west (to the city of New York) and the east (to the "race" near Rhode Island).

name: connecticut
sentence: This situation provides many safe harbours from ocean storms, and many transatlantic ships seek anchor within Long Island Sound when tropical cyclones pass off the upper east coast.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Connecticut River crosses the centre of the state and flows into Long Island Strait.

name: connecticut
sentence: The most populated metropolitan area in the state is located in the Connecticut River Valley.

name: connecticut
sentence: Despite the relatively small size of Connecticut, it has wide regional variations in its landscape; for example, in the northwest Litchfield Hills, it includes mountains and horse farms, while in areas east of New Haven along the coast, the landscape includes coastal marshes, beaches and large-scale marine activities.

name: connecticut
sentence: The rural areas and small towns of Connecticut in the northeast and northwest corners of the state contrast strongly with its industrial cities such as Stamford, Bridgeport and New Haven, located along the coastal highways from the New York border to New London, then north to the Connecticut River to Hartford.

name: connecticut
sentence: Many cities in the northeast and northwest of Connecticut centre around a green.

name: connecticut
sentence: Near the green are usually historical visual symbols of New England's cities, such as a white church, colonial meeting house, colonial tavern or inn, several colonial houses, etc., establishing a picturesque historical appearance maintained for historical preservation and tourism.

name: connecticut
sentence: Many of the southern and coastal regions of Connecticut have been built and rebuilt over the years, and are less like traditional New England.

name: connecticut
sentence: The northern border of the state with Massachusetts is marked by the Southwick Jog or Granby Notch, a square detour of about 4.0 km to Connecticut.

name: connecticut
sentence: The origin of this anomaly is clearly established in a long series of disputes and temporary agreements that were finally concluded in 1804, when the inhabitants of southern Southwick sought to leave Massachusetts, and the city was divided into two.

name: connecticut
sentence: The southwestern border of Connecticut, an exception to the state of New York, is marked by a panhandle in Fairfield County, which contains the cities of Greenwich, Stamford, New Canaan, Darien and parts of Norwalk and Wilton.

name: connecticut
sentence: This irregularity in the border is the result of territorial disputes at the end of the 17th century, culminating with New York abandoning its claim to the region, whose inhabitants considered themselves to be part of Connecticut, in exchange for an equivalent area extending north of Ridgefield on the Massachusetts border, as well as the undisputed claim in Rye, New York.

name: connecticut
sentence: Areas maintained by the National Parks Service include the Appalachian National Scenic Trail, the Quinebaug and Shetucket River Valley National Heritage Corridor, and Weir Farm National Historic Site.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut is located in the difficult transition zone between the southern end of the humid continental climate and the northern part of the humid subtropical climate.

name: connecticut
sentence: Northern Connecticut generally has a climate characterized by cold winters with moderate snowfall and warm and humid summers.

name: connecticut
sentence: The extreme south and the coast of Connecticut have a climate with cool winters with a mixture of rain and rare snow, and the long warm and humid summers typical of the middle and low East coast.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut sees a fairly uniform precipitation pattern, with precipitation and snowfall spread throughout the 12-month period.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut accounts for an average of 56% of the possible sunshine (higher than the U.S. national average), an annual average of 2400 hours of sunshine.

name: connecticut
sentence: Early spring (April) may vary slightly cool (40 to 50s F) warm (65 to 70 F), while mid and late spring (late April/May) are warm.

name: connecticut
sentence: At the end of May, the Bermuda High Building created a southern flow of warm, humid tropical air, bringing warm weather conditions throughout the state, with high means in New London of 81°F (27°C) and 85°F (29°C) in Windsor Locks at the top of the summer in late July.

name: connecticut
sentence: Sometimes heat waves of 90 to 100°F (38°C) occur across Connecticut.

name: connecticut
sentence: Although summers are sunny in Connecticut, fast-moving summer thunderstorms can cause short showers with thunder and lightning.

name: connecticut
sentence: Sometimes these thunderstorms can be severe, and the condition on average one tornado per year.

name: connecticut
sentence: During the hurricane season, the remnants of tropical cyclones sometimes affect the region, although a direct impact is rare.

name: connecticut
sentence: The time usually associated with the fall season usually begins in October and lasts until the first days of December.

name: connecticut
sentence: The daily temperatures in October and November range from the 50's to the 60's (Fahrenheit) with nights in the 40's and 30's.

name: connecticut
sentence: In early October, coloured foliage began in the northern parts of the state and moved south and east to the southeast of Connecticut in early November.

name: connecticut
sentence: However, the southern and coastal regions have more oaks and hickory trees (and fewer maples) and are often less colourful than the northern regions.

name: connecticut
sentence: In December, the diurnal peaks are in 40°F for much of the state, and the mean hollows of the night are below freezing.

name: connecticut
sentence: Winters (December to mid-March) are generally cold from south to north in Connecticut.

name: connecticut
sentence: The coldest month (January) has high mean temperatures ranging from 38°F (3°C) in coastal lowlands to 33°F (1°C) in the interior and northern portions of the state.

name: connecticut
sentence: Average annual snowfall varies from about 60 inches (1,500 mm) at higher elevations in the northern part of the state to only 20-25 inches (510-640 mm) along the southeast coast of Connecticut (Branford to Groton).

name: connecticut
sentence: In general, any locality north or west of Interstate 84 receives the most snow during a storm and throughout the season.

name: connecticut
sentence: Most of Connecticut has less than 60 days of snow cover.

name: connecticut
sentence: Snow usually falls from late November to late March in the northern part of the state, and from early December to mid-March in the southern and coastal parts of the state.

name: connecticut
sentence: The record temperature of Connecticut is 106°F (41°C) which occurred in Danbury on 15 July 1995; the low record is -32°F (−36°C) which occurred in the Northwest Hills Falls Village on 16 February 1943 and Coventry on 22 January 1961.

name: connecticut
sentence: The forests consist of a mixture of coastal forests in the north-east of Oak in the southern regions of the state, in the high forests of New England and Acadia in the north-western part of the state.

name: connecticut
sentence: The mountain laurel (Kalmia latifolia) is the flower of the state and originates from low ridges in several parts of Connecticut.

name: connecticut
sentence: Rosebay Rhododendron (maximum Rhododendron) is also native to the eastern highlands of Connecticut and the Pachaug State Forest houses the Rhododendron Sanctuary Trail.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Atlantic white cedar (Chamaecyparis thyoides) is present in wetlands in the southern part of the state.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut has an indigenous cactus (Opuntia humifusa), found in sandy coastal areas and low hills.

name: connecticut
sentence: Several types of beach grasses and wildflowers are also native to Connecticut.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut extends over the hardiness zones of USDA plants 5b to 7a.

name: connecticut
sentence: Coastal Connecticut is the vast transition zone where more southern and subtropical plants are grown.

name: connecticut
sentence: In some coastal communities, Magnolia grandiflora (southern magnolia), Crape Myrtle, palm scrub (Sabal minor), Needle Palms (Rhapidophyllum hystrix) and other sempervirent leaves are cultivated in small numbers.

name: connecticut
sentence: The name Connecticut is derived from the word Mohegan-Pequot which was translated as "long tidal river" and "long river", referring to the Connecticut River.

name: connecticut
sentence: Evidence of human presence in Connecticut dates back 10,000 years.

name: connecticut
sentence: Stone tools were used for hunting, fishing and woodworking.

name: connecticut
sentence: Semi-nomads in the way of life, these peoples move seasonally to take advantage of various resources in the region.

name: connecticut
sentence: They share languages based on Algonquian.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Connecticut region was inhabited by many Amerindian tribes that can be grouped into the Nipmuc, the Sequins or the "River Indians" (which included the Tunxis, Schaghticoke, Podunk, Wangunk, Hammonasset and Quinnipiac), the Mattabesec or the "Wolf Confederation" and the Pequot-Mohegan.

name: connecticut
sentence: Some of these groups continue to live in Connecticut, including Mohegans, Pequots and Paugusetts.

name: connecticut
sentence: The first European explorer in Connecticut was Dutchman Adriaen Block, who explored the region in 1614.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Dutch fur traders then sailed on the Connecticut River, which they called Versche Rivier ("Fresh River"), and built a fort at Dutch Point in Hartford which they called "House of Hope" (Dutch: Huis van Hoop).

name: connecticut
sentence: The Connecticut colony was originally a number of separate, smaller settlements in Windsor, Wethersfield, Saybrook, Hartford and New Haven.

name: connecticut
sentence: The first English settlers came in 1633 and settled in Windsor and Wethersfield the following year.

name: connecticut
sentence: John Winthrop the youth of Massachusetts received a commission to establish the Saybrook settlement at the mouth of the Connecticut River in 1635.

name: connecticut
sentence: The main body of the settlers came into a large group in 1636.

name: connecticut
sentence: They were Puritans of the Massachusetts Bay colony led by Thomas Hooker, who founded the Connecticut colony in Hartford.

name: connecticut
sentence: The colony of Quinnipiack was founded by John Davenport, Theophilus Eaton and others in New Haven in March 1638.

name: connecticut
sentence: The colony of New Haven had its own constitution called "The Basic Agreement of the New Haven Colony", signed on June 4, 1639.

name: connecticut
sentence: The regulations were made without the official sanction of the English Crown, and each of them was an independent political entity.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1662 Winthrop went to England and obtained a charter from Charles II, which united the colonies of Connecticut.

name: connecticut
sentence: The colonial colonies of historical significance are Windsor (1633), Wethersfield (1634), Saybrook (1635), Hartford (1636), New Haven (1638), Fairfield (1639), Guilford (1639), Milford (1639), Stratford (1639), Farmington (1640), Stamford (1641) and New London (1646).

name: connecticut
sentence: The Pequot War marked the first great conflict between settlers and Amerindians in New England.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Pequots reacted with increasing aggression against colonial settlements on their territory, while simultaneously taking land from the Narragansett and Mohegan tribes.

name: connecticut
sentence: The settlers responded to a murder in 1636 by raiding a village of Pequot on Block Island; the Pequots besieged the Saybrook Colony garrison that fall, and then attacked Wethersfield in the spring of 1637.

name: connecticut
sentence: The settlers declared war on the Pequots, organized a band of militias and allies of the Mohegan and Narragansett tribes, and attacked a Pequot village on the Mystic River, with estimates of deaths ranging from 300 to 700 Pequots.

name: connecticut
sentence: After suffering another major loss in a battle at Fairfield, the Pequots demanded a truce and conditions of peace.

name: connecticut
sentence: The western boundaries of Connecticut have changed over time.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Hartford Treaty with the Dutch was signed on 19 September 1650, but it was never ratified by the British.

name: connecticut
sentence: According to her, the western boundary of Connecticut extended north of Greenwich Bay for a distance of 32 km, provided that the line was not less than 10 miles from the Hudson River.

name: connecticut
sentence: This agreement was observed by both sides until the outbreak of the war between England and the Netherlands in 1652.

name: connecticut
sentence: The conflict continued over colonial boundaries until the Duke of York seized New Netherlands in 1664.

name: connecticut
sentence: On the other hand, the original Charter of Connecticut, in 1662, granted him all the land to the "South Sea", that is to say the Pacific Ocean.

name: connecticut
sentence: Most of the royal colonial concessions were for long east-west bands.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut took its concession seriously and established a ninth county between the Susquehanna River and the Delaware River, Westmoreland County.

name: connecticut
sentence: The result was brief Pennamite wars with Pennsylvania.

name: connecticut
sentence: Yale College was established in 1701, providing Connecticut with an important institution to educate clergy and civilian leaders.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Congregational Church dominated religious life in the colony and, by extension, municipal affairs in many parts.

name: connecticut
sentence: With more than 600 miles of coastline including along its navigable rivers, during the colonial years, Connecticut developed a history of a maritime tradition that would later produce booms in shipbuilding, shipping, naval support, seafood production and recreational boating.

name: connecticut
sentence: Historical records indicate that the Tryall was the first ship built in the Connecticut settlement in 1649 on a site on the Connecticut River in the present Wethersfield.

name: connecticut
sentence: In the two decades preceding 1776 and the American Revolution, the shipyards of Connecticut launched about 100 sloops, schooners and brigs according to a US customs database maintained online by the Mystic Seaport Museum, the largest being the 180-ton Patient Mary launched at New Haven in 1763.

name: connecticut
sentence: The first lighthouse in Connecticut was built in 1760 at the mouth of the Thames with the lighthouse of the port of New London.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut appointed four delegates to the Second Continental Congress who signed the Declaration of Independence: Samuel Huntington, Roger Sherman, William Williams and Oliver Wolcott.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Connecticut legislature authorized the formation of six new regiments in 1775, following clashes between British regulars and Massachusetts militiamen in Lexington and Concord.

name: connecticut
sentence: There were some 1,200 soldiers from Connecticut at the Battle of Bunker Hill in June 1775.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1775, David Bushnell invented the Turtle that the following year launched the first underwater attack in history, without success against a British warship at anchor in the port of New York.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1777, the British received news of supplies from the Continental Army in Danbury, and landed an expeditionary force of about 2,000 soldiers in Westport.

name: connecticut
sentence: This force then marched towards Danbury and destroyed houses and much of the depot.

name: connecticut
sentence: Mainland army troops and militias led by General David Wooster and General Benedict Arnold hired them during their march back to Ridgefield in 1777.

name: connecticut
sentence: During the winter of 1778–79, General George Washington decided to divide the Continental Army into three divisions surrounding New York City, where British General Sir Henry Clinton had taken winter quarters.

name: connecticut
sentence: Major General Israel Putnam chose Redding as a winter camp area for some 3,000 regulars and militia under his command.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Redding camp allowed Putnam soldiers to keep the Danbury reconstituted supply depot and to support any operation along Long Island Strait and the Hudson River Valley.

name: connecticut
sentence: Some of these men were veterans of the winter camp in Valley Forge, Pennsylvania, the previous winter.

name: connecticut
sentence: Soldiers at the Redding camp suffered supply shortages, cold temperatures and heavy snow, with some historians doubling the "Connecticut's Valley Forge" camp.

name: connecticut
sentence: The state was also the site of a number of raids on Long Island orchestrated by Samuel Holden Parsons and Benjamin Tallmadge, and provided men and equipment for the war effort, particularly to the Washington Army outside New York City.

name: connecticut
sentence: General William Tryon raided the coast of Connecticut in July 1779, focusing on New Haven, Norwalk and Fairfield.

name: connecticut
sentence: New London and Groton Heights were searched in September 1781 by Benedict Arnold, who had betrayed the British.

name: connecticut
sentence: At the beginning of the American Revolution, the Continental Congress designated Nathaniel Shaw Jr. of New London as its naval agent in charge of recruiting privateers to seize British ships as opportunities presented, with nearly 50 operations outside the Thames River that eventually fired reprisals from the British force led by Arnold.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut ratified the United States Constitution on 9 January 1788, becoming the fifth state.

name: connecticut
sentence: The state flourished during the period after the American Revolution, as mills and textile factories were built and seaports flourished through trade and fishing.

name: connecticut
sentence: After Congress established in 1790 the predecessor of the US Revenue Cutter Service that would evolve in the U.S. Coast Guard, President Washington assigned Jonathan Maltbie as one of the seven masters to enforce customs regulations, with Maltbie monitoring the south coast of New England with a 48-foot sloop of cut called Argus.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1786 Connecticut transferred the territory to the American government, which became part of the Northwest Territory.

name: connecticut
sentence: The state retained land that extended to the northern part of present-day Ohio, the Western Connecticut Reserve.

name: connecticut
sentence: The Western Reserve section was largely established by people from Connecticut, and they brought the place names from Connecticut to Ohio.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut has entered into agreements with Pennsylvania and New York that have extinguished land claims within the boundaries of these states and created the Connecticut Panhandle.

name: connecticut
sentence: The state then ceded the Western Reserve in 1800 to the federal government, which brought it to its present limits (other than minor adjustments with Massachusetts).

name: connecticut
sentence: For the first time in 1800, shipwrecked people from Connecticut launched more than 100 ships in a single year.

name: connecticut
sentence: In the following decade, at the door of the resumption of hostilities with Britain that triggered the War of 1812, the shipyards in Connecticut built nearly 1,000 ships, the most productive stretch of a decade in the 19th century.

name: connecticut
sentence: During the war, the British raided Stonington and Essex and blocked ships in the Thames River.

name: connecticut
sentence: Isaac Hull, from Derby, became the most famous naval figure in Connecticut to win fame during the conflict, as captain of the USConstitution.

name: connecticut
sentence: The British blockade during the War of 1812 harmed exports and reinforced the influence of federalists who opposed the war.

name: connecticut
sentence: The cessation of imports from Great Britain has stimulated the construction of textile and machine manufacturing plants.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut has become a major manufacturing centre, partly thanks to the inventions of Eli Whitney and other early innovators of the industrial revolution.

name: connecticut
sentence: The war led to the development of rapid clippers that helped extend the reach of New England merchants to the Pacific and Indian oceans.

name: connecticut
sentence: The first half of the 19th century also saw a rapid increase in whaling, with New London being one of the three largest home ports in the New England industry after Nantucket and New Bedford.

name: connecticut
sentence: The state was known for its political conservatism, characterized by its federalist party and the Yale College of Timothy Dwight.

name: connecticut
sentence: The most important intellectuals are Dwight and Noah Webster, who compiled his great dictionary in New Haven.

name: connecticut
sentence: Religious tensions polarize the state, while the Congregational Church struggles to maintain traditional views, in alliance with the federalists.

name: connecticut
sentence: The failure of the Hartford Convention in 1814 adversely affected the federalist cause, as the Democratic Republican Party took control in 1817.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut had been governed by the "Basic Orders" since 1639, but the state adopted a new constitution in 1818.

name: connecticut
sentence: The extensive Connecticut industry, its dense population, flat terrain and wealth encouraged the construction of railways from 1839.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1840, 102 miles (164 km) of line were in operation, reaching 402 miles (647 km) in 1850 and 601 miles (967 km) in 1860.

name: connecticut
sentence: New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, known as the New Haven or The Consolidated, became the dominant Connecticut railway company after 1872.

name: connecticut
sentence: J.P. Morgan began financing New England's major railways in the 1890s, dividing the territory so that they would not compete.

name: connecticut
sentence: The New Haven purchased 50 small businesses, including steamship lines, and built a network of light rails (electric trolleys) that provided long distance transportation for all of southern New England.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1912, the New Haven operated more than 2,000 miles (3,200 km) of track with 120,000 employees.

name: connecticut
sentence: As the steam ships proliferated after the Civil War, Noank produced the two largest ships built in Connecticut during the 19th century, with the 332-foot wooden steam wheel Rhode Island launched in 1882 and the 345-foot pallet wheel Connecticut seven years later.

name: connecticut

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1875, the first telephone exchange in the world was established in New Haven.

name: connecticut
sentence: When World War I broke out in 1914, Connecticut became one of the major suppliers of weapons to the American army; in 1918, 80% of the state's industries produced goods for the war effort.

name: connecticut
sentence: Remington Arms of Bridgeport produced half of the small arms cartridges used by the U.S. Army, along with other major suppliers, including Winchester in New Haven and Colt in Hartford.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut was also a major supplier of the U.S. Navy, with electrical boat orders for 85 submarines, Torpedo Lake boat construction over 20 submarines and Groton Iron Works cargo ships.

name: connecticut
sentence: On 21 June 1916, the Navy made Groton the site of its base and submarine school on the East Coast.

name: connecticut
sentence: The state enthusiastically supported the American war effort in 1917 and 1918 with major purchases of war bonds, a new boom in industry and an emphasis on increasing food production on farms.

name: connecticut
sentence: Thousands of state, local and voluntary groups mobilized for the war effort and were coordinated by the State Defence Council of Connecticut.

sentence: Manufacturers were struggling with labour shortages; Waterbury's American Brass and Manufacturing Company operated at half its capacity, so the federal government agreed to force soldiers to work there.

sentence: Connecticut manufactured 4.1% of the total U.S. military weapons produced during the war, ranking ninth among the 48 states, with major factories including Colt for firearms, Pratt & Whitney for aircraft engines, Chance Vought for fighter aircraft, Hamilton Standard for propellers, and Electric Boat for submarines and PT boats.

name: connecticut
sentence: In Bridgeport, General Electric produced an important new weapon to fight tanks: the bazooka.

sentence: On 13 May 1940, Igor Sikorsky made a free flight of the first practical helicopter.

name: connecticut
sentence: The helicopter was little used during the Second World War, but future military production made the Stratford Sikorsky Aircraft plant the largest manufacturing site in Connecticut in the early 21st century.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut lost a few factories in wartime after the end of the hostilities, but the state participated in a general post-war expansion that included the construction of highways and led to middle class growth in the suburbs.

sentence: Bush and his grandson George W. Bush both became presidents of the United States.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1965, Connecticut ratified its current constitution, replacing the document that had served since 1818.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1968, commercial operation of the Connecticut Yankee Nuclear Generating Station in East Haddam began; in 1970, the Millstone Nuclear Generating Station began operations in Waterford.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1974, Connecticut elected Democratic Governor Ella T. Grasso, who became the first woman in any state to be elected governor without being the wife or widow of a previous governor.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut's dependence on the defence industry was an economic challenge at the end of the Cold War.

name: connecticut
sentence: The resulting fiscal crisis led to Lowell Weicker's election as governor on a third-party note in 1990.

name: connecticut

name: connecticut
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that Connecticut's population was 3,565,287 on July 1, 2019, a 0.25 per cent decrease since the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 2019, Connecticut's population was estimated at 3,565,287, a decrease of 7,378 (0.25%) from the previous year and 8,810 (0.25%) from 2010.

name: connecticut
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 67,427 (222,222 births minus 154,795 deaths) and an increase due to net migration of 41,718 people to the state.

name: connecticut
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 75,991 people, and internal migration resulted in a net loss of 34,273.

name: connecticut
sentence: According to 2005 estimates, Connecticut has moved from the 29th to the 30th most populated position.

name: connecticut
sentence: According to 2018 estimates, the population of Connecticut is 3,572,665.

name: connecticut
sentence: 6.6 per cent of its population were under the age of 5, 24.7 per cent under the age of 18 and 13.8 per cent over the age of 65.

name: connecticut
sentence: Women account for about 51.6 per cent of the population, with 48.4 per cent of the population being boys.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1790, 97% of the population of Connecticut was classified as "rural".

name: connecticut
sentence: The first census in which less than half of the population was classified as rural dates back to 1890.

name: connecticut
sentence: In the 2000 census, only 12.3% were considered rural areas.

sentence: Most of the west and south of Connecticut (especially the Gold Coast) is strongly associated with New York City

sentence: The population centre of Connecticut is located in the city of Cheshire.

sentence: At the 2010 U.S. Census, the percentages of race and ethnicity in Connecticut were as follows:

sentence: Hispanics and Latinos, regardless of race, accounted for 13.4% of the population at the 2010 census.

sentence: The most populous ethnic group in the state is the non-Hispanic white group, but it rose from 98 per cent in 1940 to 71 per cent in 2010.

sentence: In 2004, 11.4% of the population (400,000) was born abroad.

sentence: In 1870, home Americans accounted for 75 per cent of the state's population, but this proportion had fallen to 35 per cent in 1918.

sentence: In 2000, 81.69 per cent of Connecticut residents aged 5 and over spoke English at home and 8.42 per cent spoke Spanish, followed by Italian (1.59%), French (1.31%) and Polish (1.20%).

sentence: Religious affiliations of the people of Connecticut from 2014:

name: connecticut
sentence: A Pew survey of the religious self-identification of Connecticut residents showed the following distribution of affiliations: Protestants 35%, Mormonism 1%, Jews 3%, Roman Catholics 33%, Orthodox 1%, non-religious 28%, Jehovah's Witness 1%, Hinduism 1%, Buddhism 1% and Islam 1%.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 2000, the Jewish congregations had 108,280 members (3.2%).

name: connecticut
sentence: The Jewish population is concentrated in cities near Long Island Sound, between Greenwich and New Haven, in Grand New Haven and in Grand Hartford, particularly the suburbs of West Hartford.

name: connecticut
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives, the largest Christian denominations, by number of adherents, in 2010 were: the Catholic Church, with 1.252.936; the United Church of Christ, with 96.506; and the non-denominational evangelical Protestants, with 72,863.

name: connecticut
sentence: Recent immigration has brought other non-Christian religions to the State, but the number of adherents of other religions is still low.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut is also home to the largest Protestant church in New England: the first cathedral in Bloomfield, Hartford County.

name: connecticut
sentence: Hartford sits in the Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford, which is sovereign over the Diocese of Bridgeport and the Diocese of Norwich.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut's economic output in 2019, measured by gross domestic product, was $289 billion, up from $277.9 billion in 2018.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut's personal income per capita in 2019 was estimated at $79,087, the highest in all states.

name: connecticut
sentence: However, there is a large disparity in income across the state; after New York, Connecticut had the second largest national gap between average incomes of the highest 1 per cent and average incomes of the lowest 99 per cent.

name: connecticut
sentence: According to a 2018 study by Phoenix Marketing International, Connecticut had the third largest number of millionaires per capita in the United States, with a ratio of 7.75%.

name: connecticut
sentence: New Canaan is the richest city in Connecticut with a per capita income of $85,459.

name: connecticut
sentence: Hartford is the poorest municipality in Connecticut, with a per capita income of $13,428 in 2000.

name: connecticut
sentence: In December 2019, Connecticut's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 3.8%, with an unemployment rate in the United States of America of 3.5% that month.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1982, Connecticut recorded its lowest unemployment rate in 2000 between August and October, at 2.2%.

name: connecticut
sentence: The highest unemployment rate during this period occurred in November and December 2010 at 9.3%, but economists expect new record levels of layoffs to be recorded following the closure of businesses in the spring of 2020 following the coronavirus pandemic.

name: connecticut
sentence: Tax is collected by the Connecticut Revenue Services Department and local municipalities.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 2012, after New York City, Connecticut residents had the second highest state and local government tax rate, or 12.6 per cent of income compared to the national average of 9.9 per cent, as reported by the Fiscal Foundation.

name: connecticut
sentence: Prior to 1991, Connecticut had an exclusive income tax system for investments.

name: connecticut
sentence: Employment income was not taxed, but investment income was taxed at 13%, the highest rate in the United States, without deducting costs related to the production of investment income, such as interest on loans.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 1991, under the authority of Governor Lowell P. Weicker Jr., an independent, the system was changed to a system in which taxes on employment income and investment income were equalled at the maximum rate of 4%.

name: connecticut
sentence: The new tax policy attracted investment firms to Connecticut; from 2019, Fairfield County was home to 16 of the world's 200 largest hedge funds.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 2019, Connecticut's personal income tax rates were divided into seven tax brackets of 3% (on income up to $10,000); 5% ($10,000 to $50,000); 5.5% ($50,000 to $100,000); 6% ($100,000 to $200,000); 6.5% ($200,000 to $250,000); 6.9% ($250,000 to $500,000) and 6.9% above $500,000, with additional amounts due in the instalment.

name: connecticut
sentence: All salaries of Connecticut residents are subject to state tax, even if they are earned outside the state.

name: connecticut
sentence: However, in such cases, Connecticut's income tax should be withheld only to the extent that the Connecticut tax exceeds the amount withheld by the other court.

name: connecticut
sentence: Since New York has higher income tax rates than Connecticut, this means that Connecticut residents working in New York do not have any Connecticut income tax withheld.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut allows a credit for taxes paid to other jurisdictions, but since residents working in other states are still subject to Connecticut's income tax, they may be liable for taxes if the jurisdictional credit does not fully offset Connecticut's tax amount.

name: connecticut
sentence: Connecticut collects a state sales tax of 6.35% on the retail sale, rental or rental of most property.

name: connecticut
sentence: Certain articles and services in general are not subject to sales and use taxes unless specifically listed as taxable by law.

name: connecticut
sentence: A provision excluding clothing of less than $50 from sales tax was repealed on July 1, 2011.

name: connecticut
sentence: No additional sales tax is imposed by local authorities.

name: connecticut
sentence: In 2001, Connecticut introduced what became an annual "day" sales tax in August for one week, when retailers do not have to pay sales tax on certain items and quantities of clothing that have varied from year to year.

name: connecticut
sentence: State law allows municipalities to tax property, including real property, vehicles and other personal property, with State law providing for exemptions, credits and varying reductions.

name: connecticut
sentence: All contributions represent 70% of the fair market value.

name: connecticut
sentence: The maximum property tax credit is $200 per return and any surplus cannot be refunded or carried forward.

name: connecticut
sentence: According to the Tax Foundation, in fiscal year 2017, Connecticut residents paid the nation's 3rd highest average property tax after New Hampshire and New Jersey.

name: connecticut
sentence: As of January 1, 2020, gas taxes and duties in Connecticut were 40.13 cents per gallon, the 11th highest in the United States, with a national average of 36.13 cents per gallon excluding federal taxes.

name: connecticut
sentence: In January 2020, taxes and charges on diesel fuel in Connecticut were 46.50 cents per gallon, the ninth highest in the country, with an American average of 37.91 cents.

name: connecticut

name: illinois

name: illinois
sentence: The Illinois government, under the Illinois Constitution, has three branches of government: executive, legislative and judicial.

sentence: The executive branch consists of six elected members and their bureaux, as well as many other departments.

sentence: Illinois is a democratic bastion.

name: illinois
sentence: Historically, Illinois was a political swing state, with a quasi-parity between the republican and democratic parties.

name: illinois
sentence: However, in recent elections, the Democratic Party has gained ground and Illinois has become a strong "blue" state in presidential campaigns.

name: illinois
sentence: The voices of Chicago and most of Cook's counties have long been highly democratic.

name: illinois
sentence: However, "collar counties" (the suburbs surrounding Cook County, Illinois) can be considered moderate electoral districts.

name: illinois
sentence: College cities like Carbondale, Champaign, and Normal also meagre democratic.

sentence: Republicans continue to prevail in rural areas of northern and central Illinois, as well as in southern Illinois outside eastern St. Louis.

name: illinois
sentence: From 1920 to 1972, Illinois was led by the winner of each of the 14 presidential elections.

name: illinois
sentence: In fact, the state has long been considered a national viewpoint, supporting the winner in every election of the 20th century, with the exception of 1916 and 1976.

name: illinois
sentence: On the other hand, Illinois moved more towards the Democratic Party and voted for their presidential candidates in the last six elections; in 2000, George W. Bush became the first Republican to win the presidency without wearing either Illinois or Vermont.

name: illinois
sentence: A local politician and a Chicago resident, Barack Obama, easily won the state's 21 votes in 2008, with 61.9% of the votes.

sentence: In 2010, current Governor Pat Quinn was re-elected with 47% of the vote, while Republican Mark Kirk was elected to the Senate with 48% of the vote.

name: illinois
sentence: In 2012, President Obama easily brought Illinois back, with 58% to Republican candidate Mitt Romney 41%.

name: illinois
sentence: In 2014, Republican Bruce Rauner defeated Governor Quinn from 50% to 46% to become Illinois's first Republican governor in 12 years after being sworn in on January 12, 2015, while Democratic Senator Dick Durbin was re-elected with 53% of the vote.

sentence: In 2016, Hillary Clinton raised Illinois with 55% of the vote, and Tammy Duckworth beat incumbent Mark Kirk 54% to 40%.

name: illinois
sentence: George W. Bush and Donald Trump are the only Republican candidates to win without wearing Illinois or Vermont.

sentence: In 2018, Democratic JB Pritzker beat Bruce Rauner for governorship with 54% of the vote.

name: illinois
sentence: State politics has been infamous for cases of highly visible corruption, as well as for cross-reformers, such as governors Adlai Stevenson and James R. Thompson.

sentence: In 2006, former Governor George Ryan was convicted of racketeering and corruption, resulting in six and a half years' imprisonment.

name: illinois
sentence: In 2008, Governor Rod Blagojevich received a criminal complaint for corruption, following allegations that he had conspired to sell the seat of Senator left by President Barack Obama to the highest bidder.

name: illinois
sentence: Three presidents claimed Illinois as their political base when they came to the presidency: Abraham Lincoln, Ulysses S. Grant and, more recently, Barack Obama.

name: illinois
sentence: Lincoln was born in Kentucky, but moved to Illinois at the age of 21.

name: illinois
sentence: He sat in the General Assembly and represented the 7th district of Congress in the United States House of Representatives before his election to the presidency in 1860.

name: illinois
sentence: Ulysse S. Grant was born in Ohio and had a military career that prevented him from settling, but on the eve of the civil war and as the Middle Ages approached, he moved to Illinois and thus used the state as his home and political base to run for the presidency.

name: illinois
sentence: Barack Obama was born in Hawaii and made Illinois his home after graduating from law school, and later represented Illinois in the U.S. Senate.

name: illinois
sentence: He then became president in 2008, running as a candidate for his Illinois base.

name: illinois
sentence: Ronald Reagan was born in Illinois, in the town of Tampico, raised in Dixon, Illinois, and studied at Eureka College outside Peoria.

sentence: Reagan later moved to California during his early adulthood.

sentence: District territories often have a complex structure.

name: illinois
sentence: Many regions of the State are in fact located in two school districts, one for secondary school, the other for primary school and secondary school.

name: illinois
sentence: And these districts do not necessarily share boundaries.

name: illinois
sentence: A given secondary school may have several elementary districts that feed on it, but some of these foster districts may themselves feed in several secondary school districts.

name: illinois
sentence: Using the criteria established by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Education, there are eleven "national universities" in the State.

name: illinois
sentence: The University of Chicago is consistently ranked as one of the top ten universities in the world on various independent university rankings, and its Booth School of Business, as well as the Kellogg School of Management in Northwestern, are consistently ranked in the top five business colleges in the country and top ten in the world.

name: illinois
sentence: The University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign is often ranked among the best engineering schools in the world and the United States.

name: illinois
sentence: As of August 19, 2010, six of them rank "first level" among the top 500 national universities in the country, according to the rankings of the US News & World Report: University of Chicago, University of Northwestern, University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign, University of Loyola Chicago, Illinois Institute of Technology, University of DePaul, University of Illinois at Chicago, State University of Illinois, University of Southern Illinois Carbondale and University of Northern Illinois.

name: illinois
sentence: Illinois also has over twenty other four-year public and private accredited universities, as well as dozens of small liberal arts colleges across the state.

name: illinois
sentence: In addition, Illinois supports 49 public community colleges in the Illinois community college system.

name: illinois
sentence: Illinois schools are financed primarily by property tax, based on the assessment of land values by the state, rather than by direct contributions from the state.

name: illinois
sentence: Tracy Steffes described Illinois's public education as historically "inequitable," a system where one of the "richest states" is "the smartest in its support for education."There have been several attempts to reform school funding in Illinois.

name: illinois
sentence: The most notable attempt took place in 1973 with the adoption of Illinois's resource equalization formula, which was hoped that funding could be collected and distributed more equitably to schools in Illinois.

name: illinois
sentence: However, opposition from Illinois's affluent communities to the obligation to pay for the less affluent school districts (including many black-majority communities, produced by redline, white flight and other "soft" segregation methods) led to the abolition of formulae in the late 1980s.

name: illinois
sentence: Due to its central location and proximity to the Rust Belt and Grain Belt, Illinois is a national hub for air, automobile, rail and truck traffic.

name: illinois
sentence: From 1962 to 1998, the O'Hare International Airport in Chicago (ORD) is the busiest airport in the world, measured in both total flight and passenger traffic.

name: illinois
sentence: While it was surpassed by Hartsfield of Atlanta in 1998 (as Chicago divides its air traffic between O'Hare and Midway airports, while Atlanta uses only one airport), with 59.3 million national passengers per year, as well as 11.4 million international passengers in 2008, O'Hare remains one of the two or three busiest airports in the world, and in a few years still ranks first in total flights.

name: illinois
sentence: It is a major hub for United Airlines and American Airlines, and a major airport expansion project is underway.

name: illinois
sentence: Midway Airport (MDW), which had been the busiest airport in the world at some point until it was supplanted by O'Hare as the busiest airport in 1962, is now the secondary airport in the Chicago metropolitan area and still ranks as one of the busiest airports in the country.

name: illinois
sentence: Midway is an important hub for Southwest Airlines and serves many other carriers.

name: illinois
sentence: In 2008, Midway served 17.3 million domestic and international passengers.

name: illinois
sentence: Illinois has an extensive rail passenger and freight transportation system.

name: illinois
sentence: Chicago is a national centre in Amtrak and passengers in the state are served by Amtrak's Illinois Service, with Chicago at Carbondale Illini and Saluki, Chicago at Quincy Carl Sandburg and Illinois Zephyr, and Chicago at St. Louis Lincoln Service.

name: illinois
sentence: Currently, there is follow-up work on the Chicago–St.

name: illinois
sentence: Louis Line to increase the maximum speed to 110 mph (180 km/h), which would reduce travel time by an hour and a half.

name: illinois
sentence: Almost all North American railways meet in Chicago, making it the largest and most active railway centre in the country.

name: illinois
sentence: A large suburban train is provided in the city itself and in some immediate suburbs by the Chicago Transit Authority's 'L' system.

name: illinois
sentence: One of the largest suburban rail networks in the United States, operated by Metra, uses existing rail lines to provide direct access to the city and beyond for hundreds of suburbs.

name: illinois
sentence: In addition to the state rail lines, Mississippi and Illinois provide important transportation routes for the state's agricultural interests.

name: illinois
sentence: Lake Michigan provides access to the Atlantic Ocean via the St. Lawrence Seaway.

name: illinois
sentence: Interstate Highways in Illinois are all segments of the Interstate road network that are owned and maintained by the state.

name: illinois
sentence: Illinois has the distinction of having the most primary (two-digit) interstates go through it among the 50 states with 13.

name: illinois
sentence: Illinois also ranks third in the fifty states with the most interstate mileage, coming after California and Texas, which are much larger states in the region.

name: illinois
sentence: The major interstate highways across the state include Interstate 24 (I-24), I-39, I-41, I-55, I-57, I-64, I-70, I-72, I-74, I-80, I-88, I-90 and I-94.

name: illinois
sentence: The Illinois Department of Transportation (IDOT) is responsible for the maintenance of the USHighways in Illinois.

name: illinois
sentence: The Illinois system consists of 21 primary highways.

name: illinois
sentence: Among the U.S. roads that cross the state are the United States 6, the United States 12, the United States 14, the United States 20, the United States 24, the United States 30, the United States 34, the United States 36, the United States 40, the United States 41, the United States 45, the United States 50, the United States 51, the United States 52, the United States 54, the United States 60, the United States 62 and the United States 67.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana is an American state located in the Midwest and Great Lakes regions of North America.

name: indiana
sentence: It is the 38th largest by region and the 17th most populous of the 50 United States.

name: indiana
sentence: Its capital and largest city is Indianapolis.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana was admitted to the United States as the 19th state on 11 December 1816.

name: indiana
sentence: It borders Lake Michigan to the northwest, Michigan to the north, Ohio to the east, Ohio River and Kentucky to the south and south-east, and Wabash River and Illinois to the west.

name: indiana
sentence: Before becoming a territory, many Aboriginal peoples lived in Indiana for thousands of years.

name: indiana
sentence: Since its creation as a territory, settlement patterns in Indiana have reflected regional cultural segmentation in the eastern United States; the northernmost level of the state has been established primarily by residents of New England and New York, Central Indiana by migrants from the states of Mid-Atlantic and adjacent Ohio, and Southern Indiana by settlers from the southern states, particularly Kentucky and Tennessee.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana has a diversified economy with a gross domestic product of $359.12 billion in 2017.

name: indiana
sentence: It has several metropolitan areas with more than 100,000 inhabitants and a number of small industrial towns.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana hosts professional sports teams, including the NFL Indianapolis Colts and the NBA Indiana Pacers.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana's name means "Indian Land," or simply "Indian Land."

name: indiana
sentence: It also comes from Indiana's territorial history.

name: indiana
sentence: On May 7, 1800, the United States Congress passed a law to divide the Northwest Territory into two zones and named the western section of the Indiana Territory.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1816, when Congress passed enabling legislation to begin the process of establishing the state for Indiana, part of that land became the geographical area of the new state.

name: indiana
sentence: A resident of Indiana is officially known as a Hoosier.

name: indiana
sentence: The etymology of this word is contested, but the main theory, put forward by the Indiana Historical Bureau and the Indiana Historical Society, has its origin in Virginia, the Carolinas, and Tennessee (the South of Upland) as a term for a backwoodsman, a rough peasant, or a humpland.

name: indiana
sentence: The first inhabitants of what is now Indiana were the Paleo-Indians, who arrived about 8,000 B.C. after the melting of glaciers at the end of the ice age.

name: indiana
sentence: Divided into small groups, the Paleo-Indians are nomads hunting large game species such as mastodons.

name: indiana
sentence: They have created stone tools made of chert in chips, knapping and flakes.

name: indiana
sentence: The archaic period, which began between 5000 and 4000 BC, covered the next phase of indigenous culture.

name: indiana
sentence: People have developed new tools as well as techniques to cook food, an important step in civilization.

name: indiana
sentence: These new tools included different types of spear points and knives, with different shapes of notches.

name: indiana
sentence: They made stone tools such as stone axes, woodworking tools and grinding stones.

name: indiana
sentence: During the latter part of the period, they built mounds of land and middens, which showed that settlements became more permanent.

name: indiana
sentence: The archaic period ended at about 1500 B.C., although some archaic people lived up to 700 B.C.

name: indiana
sentence: The Woodland period began around 1500 B.C., when new cultural attributes emerged.

name: indiana
sentence: The people created ceramics and pottery and expanded their plant culture.

name: indiana
sentence: A group from the beginning of the wood era called the Adena people had elegant burial rituals, with log tombs under the earth mounds.

name: indiana
sentence: In the middle of the Woodlands, the Hopewells began to develop long-distance merchandise trade.

name: indiana
sentence: Towards the end of the stage, people developed a very productive crop and the adaptation of agriculture, cultivating crops such as corn and squash.

name: indiana
sentence: The wood period ended around 1000 AD.

name: indiana
sentence: The Mississippi culture emerged from 1000 AD until the 15th century, shortly before the arrival of Europeans.

name: indiana
sentence: During this stage, the inhabitants created large urban settlements designed according to their cosmology, with large mounds and squares defining ceremonial and public spaces.

name: indiana
sentence: The concentrated settlements depend on agricultural surpluses.

name: indiana
sentence: One of them was the Angel Mounds.

name: indiana
sentence: They had vast public spaces such as squares and platform mounds, where leaders lived or conducted rituals.

name: indiana
sentence: The Mississippi civilization collapsed in Indiana in the mid-15th century for reasons that remain obscure.

name: indiana
sentence: The historic Amerindian tribes of the region at the time of the European meeting spoke different languages of the Algonquian family.

name: indiana
sentence: They included the Shawnee, Miami and Illini.

name: indiana
sentence: The refugee tribes of the eastern regions, including the Delawares who settled in the White and Whitewater River valleys, later joined them.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1679, French explorer René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle, was the first European to cross Indiana after reaching the present South Bend at the Saint Joseph River.

name: indiana
sentence: He returned the following year to learn more about the region.

name: indiana
sentence: French Canadian fur traders soon arrived, bringing blankets, jewellery, tools, whiskey and weapons to trade hides with the Amerindians.

name: indiana
sentence: As early as 1702, Sieur Juchereau established the first trading post near Vincennes.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1715, Sieur de Vincennes built Fort Miami in Kekionga, now Fort Wayne.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1717, another Canadian, Picote de Beletre, built Fort Ouiaton on the Wabash River, attempting to control the Amerindian trade routes from Lake Erie to the Mississippi River.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1732, Sieur de Vincennes built a second fur trading post in Vincennes.

name: indiana
sentence: The French-Canadian settlers, who had left the previous post because of the hostilities, returned in more numbers.

name: indiana
sentence: In a few years, British settlers arrived from the East and fought against Canadians for control of the lucrative fur trade.

name: indiana
sentence: The fighting between French and British settlers took place throughout the 1750s.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana's Amerindian tribes allied themselves with French Canadians during the French and Indian War (also known as the Seven Years War).

name: indiana
sentence: With the British victory in 1763, the French were forced to surrender to the British crown all their lands in North America east of the Mississippi River and north and west of the colonies.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana tribes did not give up: they captured Fort Ouiatinon and Fort Miami during the Pontiac rebellion.

name: indiana
sentence: The British Royal Proclamation of 1763 designated the land west of the Appalachians for Amerindian purposes and excluded the British settlers of the area, whom the Crown called "Indian territory."

name: indiana
sentence: In 1775, the American Revolutionary War began as the settlers sought British autonomy and independence.

name: indiana
sentence: The majority of the fighting took place near the east coast, but patriotic military officer George Rogers Clark called an army to help fight the British in the west.

name: indiana
sentence: Clark's army won major battles and took Vincennes and Fort Sackville back on 25 Feb. 1779.

name: indiana
sentence: During the war Clark managed to cut off British troops, who attacked the settlers in the east of the west.

name: indiana
sentence: His success is often credited for changing the course of the American Revolution War.

name: indiana
sentence: At the end of the war, through the Treaty of Paris, the British Crown transferred its rights to the lands south of the Great Lakes to the new United States, including Native American lands.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1787, the United States defined the Northwest Territory, which included the current Indiana region.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1800 Congress separated Ohio from the Northwest Territory, designating the rest of the lands as Indiana Territory.

name: indiana
sentence: President Thomas Jefferson chose William Henry Harrison as Governor of the Territory, and Vincennes was established as the capital.

name: indiana
sentence: After the separation of Michigan territory and the formation of Illinois territory, Indiana was reduced to its present size and geography.

name: indiana
sentence: Beginning with the battle of the woods fallen in 1794 and the Treaty of Greenville in 1795, Native American titles on Indiana lands were extinguished by usurpation, purchase, or war and treaty.

name: indiana
sentence: About half the state was acquired in the Treaty of St. Mary's of Miami in 1818.

name: indiana
sentence: The purchases were only completed when the Treaty of Mississippiwas in 1826 acquired the last of the American Aboriginal lands reserved in the northeast.

name: indiana
sentence: Portrait of the Indiana Border Around 1810: The boundary was defined by the Treaty of Fort Wayne in 1809, adding much of the southwestern lands around Vincennes and the southeastern lands adjacent to Cincinnati, areas along the Ohio River as part of American territory.

name: indiana
sentence: The colonies were military outposts such as Fort Ouiatnon in the northwest and Fort Miami (later Fort Wayne) in the northeast, Fort Knox and the Vincennes settlement in the lower Wabash.

name: indiana
sentence: Other facilities include Clarksville (passing through Louisville), Vevay and Corydon along the Ohio River, Quaker Colony in Richmond, on the eastern border, and Conner's Post (later Connersville), on the eastern central border.

name: indiana
sentence: Indianapolis would not be populated for another 15 years, and Indiana's central and northern territory remained a wilderness inhabited primarily by Aboriginal communities.

name: indiana
sentence: Only two counties in the extreme southeast, Clark and Dearborn, were organized by European settlers.

name: indiana
sentence: There were few land titles issued from Cincinnati.

name: indiana
sentence: Settler migration occurs mainly by flat boat on the Ohio River to the west, and by car paths on the Wabash/White River valleys (west) and Whitewater River (east).

name: indiana
sentence: In 1810, Shawnee Tecumseh's tribal leader and his brother Tenskwatawa encouraged other Aboriginal tribes in the Territory to resist European colonization.

name: indiana
sentence: Tensions rose and the United States allowed Harrison to launch a preventive expedition against the Tecumseh Confederation; the United States won at the Battle of Tippecanoe on November 7, 1811.

name: indiana
sentence: Tecumseh was killed in 1813 during the Battle of Thames.

name: indiana
sentence: After his death, armed resistance against United States control ended in the region.

name: indiana
sentence: Most of the Amerindian tribes of the state were later abducted west of the Mississippi River in the 1820s and 1830s after the American negotiations and the purchase of their land.

name: indiana
sentence: Corydon, a city in the extreme south of Indiana, was named the second capital of Indiana territory in May 1813 to reduce the threat of Indian raids after the Battle of Tippecanoe.

name: indiana
sentence: Two years later, a petition for the establishment of a State was approved by the general assembly of the Territory and sent to Congress.

name: indiana
sentence: Enabling legislation was passed to allow delegates to write a constitution for Indiana.

name: indiana
sentence: On 10 June 1816 delegates gathered in Corydon to draft the constitution, which was completed in 19 days.

name: indiana
sentence: Jonathan Jennings was elected first governor of the nascent state in August 1816.

name: indiana
sentence: On December 11, 1816, President James Madison approved Indiana's admission to the union as the nineteenth state.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1825 the state capital was moved from Corydon to Indianapolis.

name: indiana
sentence: Many European immigrants went west to settle in Indiana in the early 19th century.

name: indiana
sentence: The largest group of immigrants to settle in Indiana was the Germans, as well as many immigrants from Ireland and England.

name: indiana
sentence: Americans who were mainly of English origin migrated from northern New York and New England, as well as from the mid-Atlantic state of Pennsylvania.

name: indiana
sentence: The arrival of steamboats on the Ohio River in 1811 and the national road at Richmond in 1829 greatly facilitated the colonization of northern and western Indiana.

name: indiana
sentence: After the creation of a state, the new government worked to transform Indiana from a border into a developed, well-populated and prosperous state, with significant demographic and economic changes.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1836, the founders of the state launched a program, the Indiana Mammouth Internal Improvement Act, which led to the construction of publicly funded roads, canals, railways and public schools.

name: indiana
sentence: The plans went bankrupt and were a financial disaster, but increased the land and produced more than four times the value.

name: indiana
sentence: In response to the crisis and in order to avoid another, in 1851, a second constitution was adopted.

name: indiana
sentence: Its provisions include the prohibition of public debt, as well as the extension of the vote to African-Americans.

name: indiana
sentence: During the American Civil War, Indiana gained political influence and played an important role in the affairs of the nation.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana was the first Western state to mobilize for the United States in the war, and Indiana soldiers participated in all the major commitments of the war.

name: indiana
sentence: The state provided 126 infantry regiments, 26 artillery batteries and 13 cavalry regiments to the Union.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1861, Indiana received a quota of 7,500 men to join the Union Army.

name: indiana
sentence: So many volunteers in the first call that thousands of people had to be hijacked.

name: indiana
sentence: Before the end of the war, Indiana had paid 208,367 men.

name: indiana
sentence: The victims were more than 35 per cent of these men: 24,416 lost their lives and more than 50,000 were injured.

name: indiana
sentence: The only civil war conflicts in Indiana were the Newburgh Raid, a bloodless capture of the city; and the Battle of Corydon, which took place during Morgan's Raid, leaving 15 dead, 40 wounded, and 355 captured.

name: indiana
sentence: After the war, Indiana remained a largely agricultural state.

name: indiana
sentence: Post-war industries included mining, including limestone extraction, meat packaging, food processing, such as grain grinding, alcohol distillation, and the construction of cars, bugs, agricultural machinery and equipment.

name: indiana
sentence: However, the discovery of natural gas in the 1880s in northern Indiana led to an economic boom: the abundant and cheap fuel attracted heavy industry; the availability of jobs in turn attracted new settlers from other parts of the country as well as from Europe.

name: indiana
sentence: This led to the rapid expansion of cities such as South Bend, Gary, Indianapolis and Fort Wayne.

name: indiana
sentence: With the beginning of the industrial revolution, Indian industry began to develop at an accelerated pace in the northern part of the state.

name: indiana
sentence: With industrialization, workers have developed trade unions and suffrage movements related to women's progress.

name: indiana
sentence: In the early 20th century, Indiana became a strong manufacturing state linked to the new automotive industry.

name: indiana
sentence: Haynes-Apperson, the country's first commercially successful automobile company, operated in Kokomo until 1925.

name: indiana
sentence: The construction of the Indianapolis Highway and the beginning of auto-related industries were also linked to the automotive boom.

name: indiana
sentence: In the 1930s, Indiana, like the rest of the nation, was affected by the Great Depression.

name: indiana
sentence: The economic slowdown has had a major negative impact on Indiana, such as the decline in urbanization.

name: indiana
sentence: The Dust Bowl further west has led many migrants to flee to the more industrialized Midwest.

name: indiana
sentence: Governor Paul V. McNutt's administration found it difficult to establish a state-funded social assistance system to help overcrowded private charities.

name: indiana
sentence: During its administration, spending and taxes were drastically reduced in response to the depression, and the state government was completely reorganized.

name: indiana
sentence: McNutt ended the state ban and passed the first state income tax.

name: indiana
sentence: On several occasions, he declared martial law to put an end to workers' strikes.

name: indiana
sentence: The Second World War helped revive the Indiana economy, as the war required steel, food and other goods that were produced in the state.

name: indiana
sentence: About ten per cent of Indiana's population joined the armed forces, while hundreds of industries won war production contracts and began to make war equipment.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana manufactured 4.5% of all U.S. military weapons produced during the Second World War, ranking eighth among the 48 states.

name: indiana
sentence: The expansion of the industry to meet the demands of war has helped to put an end to the Great Depression.

name: indiana
sentence: With the end of World War II, Indiana returned to pre-Depression production levels.

name: indiana
sentence: Industry became the main employer, a trend that continued in the 1960s.

name: indiana
sentence: Urbanisation in the 1950s and 1960s led to strong growth in the cities of the state.

name: indiana
sentence: The automotive, steel and pharmaceutical industries dominated large Indiana companies.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana's population continued to grow after the war, exceeding five million by the 1970 census.

name: indiana
sentence: In the 1960s, Matthew E. Welsh's administration adopted its first 2% sales tax.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana schools were disaggregated in 1949.

name: indiana
sentence: In 1950, the Census Bureau reported that the Indiana population was 95.5% white and 4.4% black.

name: indiana
sentence: The Welsh Governor also worked with the General Assembly to pass the Indiana Civil Rights Bill, which provides equal protection for minorities seeking employment.

name: indiana
sentence: On December 8, 1964, a Convair B-58 carrying nuclear weapons slipped onto an ice runway on the basis of the Bunker Hill Air Force in Bunker Hill, Indiana, and caught fire during a training exercise.

name: indiana
sentence: The five nuclear weapons on board were set on fire, including a thermonuclear weapon of 9 megatonnes, causing radioactive contamination of the crash area.

name: indiana
sentence: From 1970 onwards, a series of amendments to the Constitution of the State were proposed.

name: indiana
sentence: With the adoption, the Indiana Court of Appeal was established and the procedure for appointing judges was adapted.

name: indiana
sentence: The 1973 oil crisis created a recession that hurt the automotive industry in Indiana.

name: indiana
sentence: Companies such as Delco Electronics and Delphi have begun a long series of reductions that have contributed to high unemployment rates in manufacturing in Anderson, Muncie and Kokomo.

name: indiana
sentence: The trend towards restructuring and deindustrialization continued until the 1980s, when the national and State economies began to diversify and recover.

name: indiana
sentence: With a total area (land and water) of 36,418 square miles (94,320 km2), Indiana ranks 38th among the largest states.

name: indiana
sentence: The State has a maximum north-south dimension of 250 miles (400 kilometres) and a maximum east-east dimension of 145 miles (233 kilometres).

name: indiana
sentence: The geographic centre of the state (39° 53.7'N, 86° 16.0W) is located in Marion County.

name: indiana
sentence: Located in the Midwest of the United States, Indiana is one of eight states in the Great Lakes region.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana is bordered north by Michigan, east by Ohio, and west by Illinois, partially separated by the Wabash River.

name: indiana
sentence: Lake Michigan borders Indiana in the northwest, and the Ohio River separates Indiana from Kentucky in the south.

name: indiana
sentence: The average altitude of Indiana is approximately 760 feet (230 m) above sea level.

name: indiana
sentence: The highest point in the state is Hoosier Hill in Wayne County at 1,257 feet (383 m) above sea level.

name: indiana
sentence: The lowest point at 320 feet (98 m) above sea level is in Posey County, where the Wabash River meets the Ohio River.

name: indiana
sentence: The resulting elevation range of 937 feet (286 m) is the narrowest of any U.S. non-coastal state.

name: indiana
sentence: Only 2850 square miles (7,400 km2) are above 1,000 feet (300 m) and this area is closed in 14 counties.

name: indiana
sentence: Approximately 4,700 square miles (12,000 km2) have an altitude of less than 500 feet (150 m), mainly concentrated along Ohio and the lower Wabash, Tell City and Upper Earth valleys at Evansville and Mount Vernon.

name: indiana
sentence: The state consists of two natural regions of the United States: the central lowlands and the inner lower plateaus.

name: indiana
sentence: The till plains form the northern and central regions of Indiana.

name: indiana
sentence: Much of its appearance is the result of elements left behind by glaciers.

name: indiana
sentence: The centre of Indiana is mostly flat with a few low hilly hills (except when rivers cut deep valleys across the plain, such as the Wabash River and Sugar Creek) and soil composed of glacial sands, gravel and clay, giving rise to exceptional agricultural land.

name: indiana
sentence: Northern Indiana is similar, with the exception of higher and more hilly terminal moraines and hundreds of kettle lakes.

name: indiana
sentence: In northwestern Indiana, there are several ridges of sand and dunes, some reaching nearly 200 feet in height.

name: indiana
sentence: It runs along the shore of Lake Michigan and from the interior to the Kankakee Outwash Plain.

name: indiana
sentence: Southern Indiana is characterized by rugged and hilly valleys and terrain, contrasting with much of the state.

name: indiana
sentence: Here, the substrate is exposed to the surface and is not buried in the glacier to the north.

name: indiana
sentence: Because of Indiana's dominant limestone, the area has many caves, caves and quarries.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana's main river systems include the Whitewater, White, Blue, Wabash, St. Joseph and Maumee rivers.

name: indiana
sentence: According to the Indiana Ministry of Natural Resources, there were 65 rivers, streams and streams of environmental interest or picturesque beauty, which included only a portion of approximately 24,000 hydrographic miles in the state.

name: indiana
sentence: The Wabash River, the longest open river east of Mississippi, is the official Indiana River.

name: indiana
sentence: At 475 miles (764 kilometres) in length, the river bisects the state from northeast to southwest, forming part of the state border with Illinois, before converging with the Ohio River.

name: indiana
sentence: The river has been the subject of several songs, such as On the Banks of the Wabash, The Wabash Cannonball and Back Home Again, In Indiana.

name: indiana
sentence: There are about 900 lakes listed by the Indiana Department of Natural Resources.

name: indiana
sentence: In the northwest, Indiana borders Lake Michigan, one of the five lakes that make up the Great Lakes, the largest group of freshwater lakes in the world.

name: indiana
sentence: Tippecanoe Lake, the deepest of the state, reaches depths of nearly 37 metres, while Wawassee Lake is the largest natural lake in Indiana.

name: indiana
sentence: At 10,750 acres (at the summer pool level), Lake Monroe is the largest lake in Indiana.

name: indiana
sentence: In the past, almost all Indiana had a damp continental climate, with cold winters and warm and humid summers; only the extreme south of the state was in the humid subtropical climate, which receives more precipitation than other parts of Indiana.

name: indiana
sentence: But from the 2016 update, about half of the state is now classified as subtropical wet.

name: indiana
sentence: Temperatures generally vary from the north and south sections of the state.

name: indiana
sentence: In mid-winter, mean high/low temperatures range from about 30°F/15°F (−1°C/−10°C) to the extreme north at 41°F/24°F (5°C/−4°C) in the extreme south.

name: indiana
sentence: In mid-summer, there is generally slightly less variation across the state, as average high/low temperatures vary from 84°F/64°F (29°C/18°C) to the extreme north at 90°F/69°F (32°C/21°C) to the extreme south.

name: indiana
sentence: Indiana's record temperature was 116°F (47°C) on July 14, 1936, at Collegeville.

name: indiana
sentence: The record level was −36°F (−38°C) on 19 January 1994 in New Whiteland.

name: indiana
sentence: The growing season generally ranges from 155 days in the north to 185 days in the south.

name: indiana
sentence: While occasional droughts occur in the state, total precipitation is distributed relatively equally throughout the year.

name: indiana
sentence: Total precipitation ranges from 35 inches (89 cm) near Lake Michigan in northwest Indiana to 45 inches (110 cm) along the Ohio River in the south, while the state average is 40 inches (100 cm).

name: indiana
sentence: Annual snowfalls in Indiana vary considerably from state to state, ranging from 80 inches (200 cm) in the northwest along Lake Michigan to 14 inches (36 cm) in the extreme south.

name: indiana
sentence: The effect of the lake on snow accounts for about half of the snowfall in northwestern and north central Indiana due to the effects of moisture and relative heat from Lake Michigan to the wind.

name: indiana
