name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire () is a state in the northeastern part of the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bordered by Massachusetts to the south, Vermont to the west, Maine and the Atlantic Ocean to the east, and the Canadian province of Quebec to the north.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the 5th smallest by region and the 10th least populated US state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Concord is the capital of the state, while Manchester is the largest city.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has no general sales tax or income tax other than interest and dividends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire primary is the first primary in the U.S. presidential election cycle.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its license plates bear the motto of the state, "Live Free or Die".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state nickname, "The Granite State", refers to its extensive granite formations and quarries.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In January 1776 it became the first colony in British North America to establish a government independent of the authority of the Kingdom of Great Britain; it was the first to establish its own constitution of state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Six months later, it became one of the first 13 colonies to sign the United States Declaration of Independence and, in June 1788, it was the ninth state to ratify the United States Constitution, which gave effect to that document.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, New Hampshire was an important centre for the manufacture of textiles, footwear and paper, with Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in Manchester at one point given the largest textile cotton factory in the world.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Many mills were located along various rivers in the state, particularly the Merrimack and Connecticut rivers.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Many French Canadians migrated to New Hampshire to work the mills in the late 19th and early 20th centuries; New Hampshire still ranks second among the states by the percentage of people claiming American French ancestry, with 24.5% of the state identifying itself as such.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Manufacturing centres such as Manchester, Nashua and Berlin were hit hard in the 1930s and 1940s while major manufacturing industries left New England and settled in the southern United States or abroad, reflecting national trends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 1950s and 1960s, defence contractors moved into many former mills, such as Sanders Associates in Nashua; the population of southern New Hampshire increased from the 1980s as the major highways connecting the area to Greater Boston and established several community bedrooms in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With some of the highest ski mountains on the East Coast, New Hampshire's main recreational attractions include skiing, snowmobiles and other winter sports, hiking and mountaineering (Monadnock Mountain in the southwest corner of the state is one of the most climbing mountains in the United States), autumn foliage observation, summer cottages along many lakes and the sea coast, motorsports at the New Hampshire Motor Speedway, and Moto Week, a popular motorcycle rally that took place in Weirs Beach in June in Laconia.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountain National Forest connects the Vermont and Maine portions of the Appalachian Trail and has the automatic Mount Washington Road, where visitors can drive to the 1,917-metre peak of Mount Washington.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state was named after the southern English county of Hampshire by Captain John Mason.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is one of the six states of New England.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bounded by Quebec, Canada, north and northwest, Maine and Atlantic to the east, Massachusetts to the south, and Vermont to the west.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The main areas of New Hampshire are the Northern Grand Woods, the White Mountains, the Lakes Region, the French Riviera, the Merrimack Valley, the Monadnock Region and the Dartmouth-Lake Sunapee Region.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the shortest ocean coast in an American coastal state, with a length of 29 km, sometimes measured at only 33 km.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The range of the White Mountains in New Hampshire covers the north-central part of the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The range includes Mount Washington, the highest in the northeastern United States – the site of the second highest wind speed ever recorded – as well as Mount Adams and Mount Jefferson.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With strong winds of hurricanes every three days on average, more than a hundred deaths recorded among visitors, and visible krumholtz (dwarfs, matt trees like a bonsai carpet), the climate on the upper sections of Mount Washington inspired the meteorological observatory on the summit to pretend that the region has the "worst time in the world".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountains house the rock formation called the old mountain man, a profile similar to that of Franconia Notch, until the disintegration of the formation in May 2003.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Even after its loss, the old man remains a lasting symbol for the state, seen on state highway signs, car registration plates, and many government and private entities around New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the southwestern corner of New Hampshire, Mount Monadnock gave its name to a class of earth forms – a monadnock – indicating, in geomorphology, any isolated, resistant peak that rises from a less resistant eroded plain.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The main rivers include the Merrimack River (177 km), which crosses the lower half of the north-south state before passing through Massachusetts and reaching the sea at Newburyport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its tributaries include the Contoocook River, the Pemigewasset River and the Winnipeasukee River.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 660 km Connecticut River, which begins at Connecticut Lakes in New Hampshire and flows south to Connecticut, defines the western boundary with Vermont.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state border is not at the centre of this river, as is usually the case, but at the low line on the Vermont side, that is, the entire river along the Vermont border (reserving areas where water levels have been raised by dams) is located in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A single city — Pittsburg — shares a land border with the state of Vermont.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Connecticut's "northwestern upstream waters" also define the portion of Canada-U.S.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The border.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Piscataqua River and its various tributaries form the only important ocean port in the state where they discharge into the Atlantic at Portsmouth.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Salmon Falls River and Piscataqua define the southern part of the border with Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The border of the Piscataqua River was the subject of a border dispute between New Hampshire and Maine in 2001, and New Hampshire claimed domination over several islands (mainly Seavey Island) including the Portsmouth shipyard.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2002, the United States Supreme Court dismissed the case, leaving ownership of the island in Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, New Hampshire claims the sovereignty of the base.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The largest of the lakes in New Hampshire is Lake Winnipesauke, which covers 71 square miles (184 km2) in the east-central part of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Lake Umbagog along the Maine border, about 12.3 square miles (31.9 km2), is a second far away.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Squam Lake is the second largest lake entirely located in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the shortest ocean coast in any state in the United States, about 46 km long.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Hampton Beach is a popular summer destination.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: About 11 km offshore are the islands of Shoals, nine small islands (including four in New Hampshire) known as the site of a 19th-century art colony founded by poet Celia Thaxter, and the presumed location of one of the buried treasures of the Black Barbe pirate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state has the highest percentage of forested land in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is found in the biome of broad-leaved, mixed-leaved temperate forests.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Much of the state, particularly the White Mountains, is covered by conifers and deciduous forests of northern New England and Acadia.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The southeast corner of the state and parts of the Connecticut River along the Vermont border are covered by mixed oaks from the northeast coastal forests.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The numerous forests of the state are popular among fall leaf drinkers in search of the bright foliage of the many deciduous trees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The northern third of the state is locally referred to as "Northern Country" or "northern Notches", with reference to White Mountain crossings as canal traffic.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It contains less than 5 per cent of the population of the State, suffers from relatively high poverty and regularly loses its population as the logging and paper industries decline.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the tourism industry, particularly visitors to northern New Hampshire for skiing, snowboarding, hiking and mountain biking, has helped offset the economic losses caused by the closure of factories.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The duration of the winter season is expected to decline in the New Hampshire ski resorts due to the effects of global warming, which is expected to continue the historical contraction and consolidation of the ski industry and threaten ski businesses and communities dependent on ski tourism.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a humid continental climate (classification of the climate of Köppen Dfa in certain areas of the south, Dfb in most of the state and subarctic Dfc in some areas of the north of the highlands), with warm and humid summers and long, cold and snowy winters.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Precipitation is distributed fairly uniformly throughout the year.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The climate in the southeast is moderated by the Atlantic Ocean and the average of relatively mild winters (for New Hampshire), while the northern and inner parts have colder temperatures and lower humidity.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Winters are cold and snowy throughout the state, and particularly severe in northern and mountainous regions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average annual snowfall ranges from 60 inches (150 cm) to more than 100 inches (250 cm) throughout the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The average of diurnal peaks between the mid-1970s and the lower 1980s (24–28°C) in the state as a whole in July, with nocturnal troughs in the mid-50s to the lower 1960s (13–15°C).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: January temperatures range from an average height of 34°F (1°C) on the coast to night temperatures below 0°F (−18°C) in the extreme north and at high altitudes.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average annual precipitation at the state level is approximately 40 inches (100 cm) and some variations occur in the White Mountains due to differences in altitude and annual snowfall.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The highest temperature recorded in New Hampshire was 106°F (41°C) at Nashua on 4 July 1911, while the lowest recorded temperature was −47°F (−44°C) at the top of Mount Washington on 29 January 1934.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Mount Washington also saw an unofficial reading of -50°F (−46°C) on January 22, 1885, which, if made official, would bind the historic record of New England (also -50°F (−46°C) to Big Black River, Maine, on January 16, 2009, and Bloomfield, Vermont, on December 30, 1933).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Extreme snow is often associated with a nor'easter, such as the Blizzard of 78 and the Blizzard of 1993, when several feet accumulated through parts of the state over 24 to 48 hours.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Lighter snowfalls of several inches occur frequently throughout the winter, often associated with a clipper from Alberta.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire, on occasion, is affected by hurricanes and tropical storms, although by the time they reach the state, they are often extratropical, most of the storms hitting the southern coast of New England and moving inside or offshore in the Gulf of Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most storms in New Hampshire occur on average less than 20 days a year and two tornadoes occur each year across the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The map of the Hardiness Areas of the National Arbor Day Foundation illustrates areas 3, 4, 5 and 6 throughout the state and indicates the transition from a relatively cooler climate to a warmer climate when moving south across New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The hardiness zones of 1990 USDA plants in New Hampshire range from zone 3b to zone 5b to the south.

sentence: Fortune merchants built important houses, provided them with the best luxuries, and invested their capital in trade and land speculation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: (General Sullivan, head of the attack, described him as "remarking powder, small arms, bayonets and canisters, as well as cannons and ammunition") over the course of two nights.

name: new_hampshire

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to unverified accounts, gunpowder was then used at the Battle of Bunker Hill, carried there by Major Demerit, one of the many patriots in New Hampshire who stored the powder in their homes until it was transported elsewhere for use in revolutionary activities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: During the attack, British soldiers fired at the rebels with guns and muskets.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Although there were apparently no casualties, they were among the first shots of the period of the American Revolution, occurring about five months before the battles of Lexington and Concord.

sentence: Industrialization has taken the form of numerous textile factories, which in turn have attracted significant flows of immigrants from Quebec (the "French Canadians") and Ireland.

sentence: Starting in 1952, New Hampshire received national and international attention for its presidential primaries held at the beginning of each presidential election year.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The media gave New Hampshire and Iowa about half of all the attention given to all states in the primary process, magnifying the decision-making powers of the state and encouraging the repeated efforts of non-state politicians to change the rules.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the population of New Hampshire was 1,359,711 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 3.28% since the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The population centre of New Hampshire is located in Merrimack County, in the town of Pembroke.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The population centre has moved south of 19 km since 1950, reflecting the fact that the fastest growth in the state has been along its southern border, which is within the Boston Communication Area and other cities in Massachusetts.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The most densely populated areas are generally less than 80 km from the Massachusetts border and are concentrated in two areas: along the Merrimack valley from Concord to Nashua, and in the sea area along an axis from Rochester to Portsmouth.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Outside these two regions, only one community, the city of Keene, has a population of more than 20,000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The four counties that cover these two regions represent 72 per cent of the population of the state and one (Hillsborough) represents nearly 30 per cent of the population of the state, as well as the two most populated communities, Manchester and Nashua.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The northern part of the state is very sparsely populated: the largest county per region, Coos, covers the northern quarter of the state and has only about 31,000 inhabitants, about one third of whom live in a single community (Berlin).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Trends over the past few decades have been for the population to move south, as many northern communities do not have the economic base to maintain their population, while southern communities have been absorbed by Greater Boston.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the 2010 census, the population of New Hampshire was 1,316,470.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The gender composition of the State is 49.3 per cent for men and 50.7 per cent for women.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: 21.8% of the population was under the age of 18.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The racial composition of New Hampshire at the time of the 2010 census was as follows:

sentence: Hispanics or Latinos, regardless of race, accounted for 2.8 per cent of the population in 2010: 0.6 per cent were Mexican, 0.9 per cent Puerto Rican, 0.1 per cent Cuban and 1.2 per cent Hispanic or Latin.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the American Community Survey 2012–2017, the largest groups of ancestry in the state were Irish (20.6%), English (16.5%), French (14.0%), Italian (10.4%), German (9.1%), French Canadians (8.9%) and Americans (4.8%).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the highest percentage (22.9%) of French, French-Canadian and Acadian residents of any state in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to estimates from the American Community Survey of the Census Bureau from 2017, 2.1% of the population aged 5 and over speak Spanish at home, while 1.8% speak French.

sentence: In Coos County, 9.6% of the population speaks French at home, down from 16% in 2000.

sentence: Note: The percentages in the table do not add up to 100, because Hispanics are counted both by ethnicity and race, resulting in a higher overall number.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A Pew survey showed that the religious affiliations of New Hampshire residents were as follows: Protestants 30%, Catholics 26%, LDS (Mormon) 1%, Jews 1%, Jehovah's Witnesses 2% and non-religious 36%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A survey suggests that people in New Hampshire and Vermont are less likely than other Americans to attend weekly service and only 54% say they are "absolutely sure that there is a God" compared to 71% in the rest of the nation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire and Vermont are also at the lowest levels among states engaged in religion.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, 23% of New Hampshire residents in a Gallup poll considered themselves "very religious", while 52% considered themselves "non-religious".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), the largest denominations are the Catholic Church with 311.028 members, the United Church of Christ with 26,321 members and the United Methodist Church with 18,029 members.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016, a Gallup Poll found that New Hampshire was the least religious in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Only 20% of New Hampshire respondents considered themselves to be "very religious," while the national average was 40%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that New Hampshire's total revenue was $86 billion in 2018, ranking 40th in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The median household income in 2017 was 74,801, the fourth highest in the country (including Washington, DC).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its agricultural products are dairy products, nurseries, cattle, apples and eggs.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its industrial outputs are machinery, electrical equipment, rubber and plastic products, and tourism is a major component of the economy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire experienced a significant change in its economic base in the 20th century.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, the base was made up of traditional New England textiles, footwear manufacturing and small machine shops, taking advantage of low-wage labour from nearby small farms and parts of Quebec.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Today, out of the total value of the state's manufacturing dollar, these sectors contribute only 2% for textiles, 2% for leather goods and 9% for machining.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: They have experienced a sharp decline due to obsolete factories and the attractiveness of cheaper wages in the southern United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire now has a broad-based and growing economy, with a state GDP growth rate of 2.2% in 2018.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The government's main economic sectors in 2018, based on its contribution to GDP, are: 15% of real estate and leasing and leasing; 13% of professional business services; 12% of manufacturing industry; 10% of government and government services; and 9% of health and social services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state budget for 2018 was $5.97 billion, including $1.79 billion in federal funds.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The issue of tax is controversial in New Hampshire, which has a property tax (under municipal control) but no sales tax or income tax.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State has tighter taxes on meals, housing, vehicles, business and investment income, and tolls on State roads.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Energy Information Administration, energy consumption and per capita energy consumption in New Hampshire are among the lowest in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Seabrook Nuclear Generating Station, near Portsmouth, is the largest nuclear reactor in New England and supplied 57% of New Hampshire's electricity generation and 27% of its electricity consumption in 2017.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016 and 2017, New Hampshire obtained more wind energy than coal-fired power plants.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: About 32% of New Hampshire's electricity consumption came from renewable resources (including nuclear, hydro, wind and other renewable resources).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a net exporter of electricity, exporting 63 trillion British thermal units (18 TWh).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's residential electricity consumption is low compared to the national average, partly because the demand for air conditioning is low during the generally mild summer months and because few households use electricity as a primary source of energy for domestic heating.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Nearly half of New Hampshire households use fuel oil for winter heating, which is one of the largest shares in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a potential for renewable energy such as wind, hydro and wood fuel.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State does not have a general sales tax or personal income tax (the State taxes, at a rate of 5%, income from dividends and interest), and the legislator has exercised tax withholding.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Efforts to diversify the general economy of the State continue.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The lack of a general tax system in New Hampshire has led local communities in the state to have some of the highest property taxes in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the overall tax burden of the state is relatively low; in 2010, New Hampshire ranked 44th among the states in terms of the combined average tax burden of states and local authorities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In February 2010, the state unemployment rate was 7.1 per cent.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: By October 2010, the unemployment rate had fallen to 5.4%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The seasonal (preliminary) unemployment rate in April 2019 was 2.4% based on a civilian workforce of 767,500, with 749,000 active people.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's workforce is 90 per cent in non-agricultural employment, 18 per cent in trade, transport and public services, 17 per cent in education and health care, 12 per cent in government, 11 per cent in professional and business services, and 10 per cent in leisure and hospitality.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to a 2013 study by Phoenix Marketing International, New Hampshire had the eighth highest percentage of millionaire households in the United States, or 6.48% of all households.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2013, New Hampshire also had the lowest poverty rate in the country, at only 8.7 per cent of all residents, according to the Census Bureau.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In March 2018, 86% of New Hampshire's workforce was employed by the private sector, with 53% of these workers employed by companies with less than 100 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: About 14 per cent of private sector employees are employed by companies with more than 1,000 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to Community surveys conducted by the NH Labour Market and Employment Security Information Bureau, the most important private employers in the State are:

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State Government of New Hampshire employs approximately 6,100 people.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In addition, the U.S. Department of State employs approximately 1,600 people at the Portsmouth National Visa Centre, which processes visa applications for U.S. immigrants.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Governor of New Hampshire, since January 5, 2017, is Chris Sununu (Republican).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The two American senators in New Hampshire are Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan (the two Democrats), both of whom are former governors.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The two American representatives of New Hampshire from January 2019 onwards are Chris Pappas and Ann McLane Kuster (the two Democrats).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a state of control over alcoholic beverages, and through the State Alcohol Commission, it takes $100 million from the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the only state in the United States that does not require adults to wear seat belts on their vehicles.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is one of the three states that do not have a mandatory helmet law.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New Hampshire of 1783 is the supreme law of the State, followed by the revised annotated New Hampshire Statutes and the New Hampshire Code of Administrative Rules.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: These provisions are roughly similar to those of the U.S. Federal Constitution, the U.S. Code and the Code of Federal Regulations, respectively.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a bifurcated executive power, consisting of the governor and a five-member executive council that votes on government contracts worth more than $5,000 and "advises and consents" to the governor's appointments to important state positions such as department heads, all judge functions and all pardon applications.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire does not have a Lieutenant Governor; the Speaker acts as "interim Governor" whenever the Governor is unable to perform his or her duties.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The legislative power is referred to as the Tribunal.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It consists of the House of Representatives and the Senator.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are 400 representatives, making it one of the most important elected bodies in the English-speaking world, and 24 senators.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Legislators receive a nominal salary of $200 per year, the lowest in the United States by far, so most are indeed volunteers, nearly half of whom are retirees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: (For more details, see the New Hampshire Government article.)

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The only State Court of Appeal is the Supreme Court of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Superior Court is the court of general jurisdiction and the only court that provides for jury trials in civil or criminal cases.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The other State courts are the Probation Court, the District Court and the Family Division.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has 10 counties and 234 cities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a "Dillon Rule" state, i.e. the state retains all powers that are not expressly granted to municipalities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Despite this, the legislature is strongly in favour of local control, particularly with regard to land-use regulations.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The municipalities of New Hampshire are classified as cities or cities, which differ mainly in the form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most cities generally operate according to the form of government of municipal assemblies, where registered voters in the city act as municipal legislatures, and a selection board acts as the city's executive.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The major cities and the thirteen cities of the state operate either in the form of a council (manager or council) or in the form of a mayor.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is no difference, from the point of view of the state government, between cities and cities outside the form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All state laws treat all municipalities equally.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a small number of unincorporated areas called grants, locations, purchases or cantons.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: These locations are limited to the absence of self-government, and services are generally provided by neighbouring cities or the county or state if necessary.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2000 census, there were 25 people left in New Hampshire, with a total population of 173 (in 2000); several were completely depopulated.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All but two of these areas are in Coos County.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democratic Party and the Republican Party are the two largest parties in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A plurality of electors are registered as undeclared, and can choose one or the other vote in primary school, and then regain their undeclared status after voting.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Libertarian Party had the status of an official party between 1990 and 1996.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is also a program known as the Free State Project to transform New Hampshire into a libertarian fortress by suggesting that libertarians move there to concentrate their power.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The libertarian party regained access to the ballot papers after the 2016 election because the candidate for the position of governor obtained more than 4% of the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of February 5, 2016, there were 88,2959 registered voters, of whom 389,472 (44.1%) had not declared affiliation to a political party, 262,111 (29.7%) were Republicans and 231,376 (26.2%) were Democrats.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is internationally recognized for the primary school of New Hampshire, the first primary in the quadrennial cycle of the US presidential elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The law of the State requires that the Secretary of State organize this election at least one week before any "similar event".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the Iowa Caucus preceded the New Hampshire primary.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This first competition, which uses the same procedure as the general election, attracts more attention than in other States, and it has been decisive in the preparation of the national competition.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State law allows a city with fewer than 100 residents to open its polling stations at midnight and close its offices when all registered citizens have voted.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: For example, the communities of Dixville Notch, Coos County, and Hart's, Carroll County, among others, chose to implement these provisions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Dixville Notch and Hart's Location are traditionally the first places in New Hampshire and the United States to vote in primary and presidential elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Appointments for all other partisan offices are decided in separate primary elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the presidential election cycles, this is the second primary election held in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Saint Anselm College in Goffstown has become a popular campaign venue for politicians as well as several national presidential debates due to its proximity to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the past, New Hampshire had often voted Republican.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Between 1856 and 1988, New Hampshire voted six times for the Democratic presidential ticket: Woodrow Wilson (twice), Franklin D. Roosevelt (three times) and Lyndon B. Johnson (one time).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: From 1992 onwards, New Hampshire became a state rotating in national and local elections and, at that time, supported the Democrats in all presidential elections, with the exception of 2000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It was the only state in the country to move from the support of Republican George W. Bush in the 2000 elections to that of his democratic challenger in the 2004 elections, when John Kerry, a senator from nearby Massachusetts, won the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats dominated the New Hampshire elections in 2006 and 2008.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2006, the Democrats won both seats in Congress (elected Carol Shea-Porter in the first district and Paul Hodes in the second), re-elected Governor John Lynch and won a majority on the Executive Council and in both chambers for the first time since 1911.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats had not held both the legislature and the office of governor since 1874.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Neither of the U.S. senators was a candidate for a vote in 2006.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2008, the Democrats retained their majorities, their government and their seats in Congress; and former Governor Jeanne Shaheen defeated outgoing Republican John E. Sununu for the U.S. Senator in a retake of the 2002 competition.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 2008 elections allowed women to hold a majority of 13 of the 24 seats in New Hampshire Senatte, the first for any legislative body in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the mid-term elections of 2010, the Republicans made historic gains in New Hampshire, capturing veto-proof majorities in the state's legislature, taking the five seats on the Executive Council, electing a new American senator, Kelly Ayotte, winning both seats in the US Chamber of Deputies, and reducing the margin of victory of outgoing Governor John Lynch over his 2006 and 2008 victories.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2012 parliamentary elections, the Democrats took over the House of Representatives of New Hampshire and reduced the Republican majority in the New Hampshire Senate to 13-11.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, New Hampshire became the first state in the history of the United States to elect an entirely female federal delegation: Carol Shea-Porter, Congressional District 1 Democratic Member of Parliament, and Ann McLane Kuster, Congressional District 2 Member of Parliament, accompanied the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Senators Jeanne Shaheen and Kelly Ayotte in 2013.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In addition, the state elected its second female governor: the Democrat Maggie Hassan.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2014 elections, the Republicans took over the House of Representatives of New Hampshire with a majority of 239 to 160 votes and increased their majority in the New Hampshire Senate to 14 of the 24 seats in the Senate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the national level, outgoing Senator Jeanne Shaheen beat her Republican challenger, former Massachusetts Senator Scott Brown.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire also elected Frank Guinta (R) for its first Congressional District Representative and Ann Kuster (D) for its second Congressional District Representative.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2016 elections, the Republicans held the House of Representatives of New Hampshire with a majority of 220 to 175, and held their 14 seats in New Hampshire Senator.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the gibernatory race, outgoing Governor Maggie Hassan was replaced by Republican Chris Sununu, who defeated democratic candidate Colin Van Ostern.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Sununu became the first Republican governor of the state since Craig Benson, who left his post in 2005 after John Lynch's defeat.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Republicans control the governor's office and the two chambers of the state legislature, a trifecta of government in which the Republicans have the full power of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the presidential race, the state voted for the Democratic candidate, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on the Republican candidate, Donald Trump, by a margin of 2,736 votes, or 0.3%, one of the closest results the state has ever seen in a presidential race, while libertarian candidate Gary Johnson won 4.12% of the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats also won a competitive race in the second district of Congress, as well as a race in the Senate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire delegation currently consists exclusively of democrats.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the 116th Congress of the United States, it is one of the only eight states with an entirely democratic delegation, five of which are in New England (the others are Delaware, Hawaii and New Mexico).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a well-maintained and well-signed network of interstate highways, U.S. highways and state highways.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State highway markers still represent the Old Man of the Mountain despite the disappearance of rock formation in 2003.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Several road numbers align with the same road numbers in neighbouring states.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The numbering of the state highway is arbitrary, without a global system as for American and interstate systems.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has 25 public airports, three of which are served by regular commercial passenger services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The busiest airport is Manchester-Boston in Manchester and Londonderry, which serves the Greater Boston metropolitan area.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Amtrak's Vermonter and Downeester lines provide long distance rail passenger service.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Greyhound, Concord Coach, Vermont Translines and Dartmouth Coach all provide long distance connections to and from points in New Hampshire and beyond and between them.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2013, the Boston-based MBTA Commuter Rail services reached only northern Massachusetts.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority is working to expand the Lowell Capital Corridor (Massachusetts) service to Nashua, Concord and Manchester, including Manchester-Boston Regional Airport; and the Haverhill Coastal Corridor (Massachusetts) service to Plaistow, New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 2007 legislation created the New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority (NHRTA) to oversee the development of suburban trains in the State of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2011, Governor John Lynch vetoed HB 218, a bill passed by Republican legislators, which would have significantly reduced the powers and responsibilities of NHRTA.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The I-93 corridor study suggested a rail alternative along the Manchester and Lawrence branch line, which could provide freight and passenger services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This rail corridor would also have access to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Eleven public transit authorities operate local and regional bus services throughout the State, and eight private carriers operate express bus services that connect the national long distance bus network.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Department of Transportation operates a state-wide match-sharing service, in addition to an independent route matching program and a guaranteed return program.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Tourist railways include Conway Scenic Railroad, Hobo-Winnipesaukee Railroad and Mount Washington Cog Railway.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's freight railways include Claremont & Concord Railroad (CCRR), Pan Am Railways via Springfield Terminal Railway (ST), New England Central Railroad (NHR, St. Lawrence and Atlantic Railroad (SLR) and New Hampshire Northcoast Corporation (NHN).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The first public secondary schools in the state were the secondary school for boys and the secondary school for girls in Portsmouth, founded in 1827 or 1830 according to the source.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has over 80 public high schools, many of which serve more than one city.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The largest is Pinkerton Academy in Derry, which is owned by a private non-profit organization and serves as a public high school in a number of nearby cities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are at least 30 private high schools in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire also houses prestigious university-preparatory schools such as Phillips Exeter Academy, St. Paul's School, Proctor Academy, Brewster Academy and Kimball Union Academy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2008, the state tied up with Massachusetts as having the highest scores on the standardized SAT and ACT tests given to high school students.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The following sports teams are based in New Hampshire:

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Loudon's New Hampshire Motor Speedway is an oval circuit that has been visited by series of national motorsport championships such as NASCAR Cup Series, NASCAR Xfinity Series, NASCAR Camping World Truck Series, NASCAR Wholen Modified Tour, American Canadian Tour (ACT), Champ Car and IndyCar Series.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Other racing venues include Star Speedway and New England Dragway in Epping, Lee Speedway in Lee, Twin State Speedway in Claremont, Monadnock Speedway in Winchester and Canaan Fair Speedway in Canaan.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has two universities competing at NCAA Division I in all college sports: the Dartmouth Big Green (Ivy League) and the New Hampshire Wildcats (America East Conference), as well as three NCAA Division II teams: Franklin Pierce Ravens, Saint Anselm Hawks and Southern New Hampshire Penmen (Northeast-10 Conference).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most other schools participate in NCAA Division III or NAIA.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Every year since 2002, all the high school stars fight Vermont in ten sports in the playoffs "Twin State".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the spring, the many sap houses in New Hampshire house open sugar houses.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In summer and early fall, New Hampshire is home to many county fairs, the largest being Contoocook's Hopkinton State Fair.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Lakes area is home to many summer camps, including around Lake Winnipesaukee, and is a popular tourist destination.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Peterborough Players have been performing every summer in Peterborough since 1933.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Barnstormers Theatre in Tamworth, founded in 1931, is one of the oldest professional summer theatres in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In September, New Hampshire hosted the New Hampshire Highland Games.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire also registered an official tartan with the competent authorities in Scotland, used to make kilts carried by Lincoln police while its officers served during the games.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Autumn foliage peaks in mid-October.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In winter, the ski resorts and snowmobile trails in New Hampshire attract visitors to a large area.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Once the lakes freeze, they become dotted with ice-fishing ice houses, known locally as the bobhouses.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Funspot, the world's largest video arcade (now called a museum), is located in Laconia.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Leading figures in New Hampshire include founding father Nicholas Gilman, Senator Daniel Webster, revolutionary war hero John Stark, publisher Horace Greeley, founder of Christian science religion Mary Baker Eddy, poet Robert Frost, astronaut Alan Shepard, rock musician Ronnie James Dio, author Dan Brown, actor Adam Sandler, inventor Dean Kamen, actors Sarah Silverman and Seth Meyers, restorers Richard and Maurice McDonald, and President Franklin Pierce of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is a state in the Mid-Atlantic region of the northeastern United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is bordered to the north and east by New York State, to the east, south-east and south by the Atlantic Ocean, to the west by Delaware River and Pennsylvania, and to the southwest by Delaware Bay and Delaware State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the fourth smallest state by region, but the 11th most populous, with 8,882,190 residents in 2019 and an area of 8,722.58 square miles, making it the most populous of the 50 American states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The capital is Trenton while the largest city is Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All but one of the counties in New Jersey are in the combined statistical zones of New York City or Philadelphia; therefore, the largest metropolitan area of the state is in Greater New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was inhabited for the first time by Amerindians for at least 2,800 years, the Lenape being the dominant group at the time of the arrival of Europeans in the early 17th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch and Swedish settlers founded the first European settlements in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The English then took control of the area, naming it Province of New Jersey – after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey – and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, 1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was the scene of several major battles during the American Revolutionary War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 19th century, the factories of the "six major" cities of Camden, Paterson, Newark, Trenton, Jersey City and Elizabeth contributed to the country's industrial revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The central location of New Jersey in the northeast megalopolis fuelled its rapid growth and suburbanization in the second half of the 20th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the turn of the twenty-first century, the state's economy became increasingly diverse, while its multicultural population began to return to more urban environments within the state, surpassing the growth of the suburbs since 2008.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2020, New Jersey had the largest number of millionaires per capita in all US states, with 9.76% of households — more than 323,000 out of 3.3 million — meeting the criteria.

name: new_jersey
sentence: According to 2017 data, it was the second poorest U.S. state by median household income.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's public school system is consistently ranked among the fifty states of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 180 million years ago, during the Jurassic period, New Jersey bordered North Africa.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The pressure of the collision between North America and Africa caused the Appalachians.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 18,000 years ago, the ice age gave rise to glaciers that reached New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As the glaciers retreated, they left Lake Passaic behind, as well as many rivers, swamps and gorges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Originally, New Jersey was established by Amerindians, with Lenni-Lenape dominant at the time of contact.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Scheyichbi is the name Lenape for the land that is now New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenapes were several self-governing groups engaged in corn farming to complete their hunting and harvesting in the area surrounding the Delaware River, Lower Hudson and western Long Island Strait.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Lenape was divided into matrilineal clans based on common female ancestors.

name: new_jersey
sentence: These clans were organized into three distinct phratries identified by their animal sign: the turtle, Turkey and the wolf.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They first met the Dutch at the beginning of the 17th century, and their main relationship with Europeans was the fur trade.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch became the first Europeans to claim land in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch colony of New Netherlands consisted of parts of modern states of the Middle Atlantic.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although the European principle of land ownership was not recognized by the Lenape, Dutch West India Company policy required its settlers to purchase the land they settled.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The first to do so was Michiel Pauw who established a patroness named Pavonia in 1630 along the northern river which eventually became the Bergen.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Peter Minuit's purchase of land along the Delaware River established the colony of New Sweden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The entire region became a territory of England on 24 June 1664, after an English fleet under Colonel Richard Nicolls sailed in what is now New York Harbor and took control of Fort Amsterdam, annexing the entire province.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the English Civil War, Channel Island of Jersey remained faithful to the British crown and gave refuge to the king.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It was from the royal square of Saint-Hélier that Charles II of England was proclaimed king in 1649, following the execution of his father, Charles I.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The North American lands were divided by Charles II, who gave his brother, the Duke of York (later King James II), the area between New England and Maryland as an exclusive colony (as opposed to a royal colony).

name: new_jersey
sentence: James then granted land between the Hudson River and the Delaware River (the land that would become New Jersey) to two friends who had remained faithful during the English Civil War: Sir George Carteret and Lord Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The area was called the Province of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Since the creation of the state, New Jersey has been characterized by ethnic and religious diversity.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Congregationalists in New England settle alongside Scottish Presbyterians and Dutch Reformed Migrants.

name: new_jersey
sentence: While the majority of residents lived in cities with individual properties of 100 acres (40 ha), some wealthy owners owned large properties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The English Quakers and Anglicans had important land properties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Unlike Plymouth Colony, Jamestown and other colonies, New Jersey was populated by a second wave of immigrants from other colonies instead of those who migrated directly from Europe.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey remained agrarian and rural throughout the colonial era and commercial agriculture grew sporadically.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Some townships, such as Burlington on the Delaware River and Perth Amboy, have emerged as important ports for the expedition to New York and Philadelphia.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The colony's fertile land and tolerant religious policy attracted more settlers, and the population of New Jersey had increased to 120,000 in 1775.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Colonization during the first 10 years of English domination took place along Hackensack River and Arthur Kill-settlers came mainly from New York and New England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On 18 March 1673 Berkeley sold his half of the colony to Quakers, England, which established the Delaware Valley as a Quaker colony.

name: new_jersey
sentence: (William Penn acted for some time as land trustee.)

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was governed very briefly as two distinct provinces, east and west of Jersey, for 28 years between 1674 and 1702, sometimes part of New York or Dominion of New England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1702, the two provinces were brought together under the direction of a royal governor, rather than an exclusive province.

sentence: The position of Governor of New Jersey was considered one of the most powerful in the nation.

sentence: Until 2010, the governor was the only member of the state-wide executive elected and appointed many government officials.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the past, an acting governor was even more powerful as he served simultaneously as President of the State Senator of New Jersey, leading half of the legislative process and the entire executive process.

sentence: In 2002 and 2007, the Speaker of the Senate of State Richard Codey served as Acting Governor for a short period of time, and from 2004 to 2006 Codey became a long-term Acting Governor because of Jim McGreevey's resignation.

sentence: A 2005 amendment to the Constitution of the State prevents the President of the Senate from acting as governor in the event of a permanent vacancy for a Governor without giving up his seat in the State Senate.

sentence: Phil Murphy is the governor.

sentence: The governor's residence is Drumthwacket, located in Princeton.

sentence: She was elected on the Republican ticket with Governor-elect Chris Christie in the November 2009 election to the NJ government.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The post was created as a result of a constitutional amendment to the Constitution of the State of New Jersey adopted by voters on 8 November 2005 and entered into force on 17 January 2006.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The current version of the Constitution of the State of New Jersey was adopted in 1947.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It provides for a bicameral legislature of New Jersey, consisting of a 40-member Senate and an 80-member General Assembly.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Each of the 40 legislative districts elects one State Senator and two members of the Assembly.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The members of the Assembly shall be elected for a term of two years for all odd years; the senators of the States shall be elected for the years ending in 1, 3 and 7 and shall thus be appointed for a term of four or two years.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is one of only five states that elect its officials in odd years.

name: new_jersey
sentence: (The others are Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi and Virginia.)

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey holds elections for these offices every four years, the year following each year of federal presidential elections.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For example, last year, when New Jersey elected a governor was 2017; the next governor election will take place in 2021.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Supreme Court of New Jersey is composed of one Chief Justice and six Associate Judges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All are appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of a majority of the members of the Senate.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Judges are appointed for an initial period of seven years, after which they may be reappointed until the age of 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most of the daily work in the New Jersey courts is done by the municipal court, where simple traffic violations, minor criminal offences and small civil cases are heard.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The most serious criminal and civil cases are dealt with by the Superior Court for each county.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All judges of the Superior Court are appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of a majority of the members of the Senate.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Each judge shall serve an initial term of seven years, after which he or she may be reappointed until the age of 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The New Jersey judiciary is unusual in that it still has separate courts of law and fairness, such as its neighbour Delaware, but unlike most other American states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Superior Court of New Jersey is divided into the Law and Chancery Divisions at trial level; the Law Division hears both criminal and civil cases where the plaintiff's main remedy is damages, while the Chancery Division hears family cases, civil suits where the plaintiff's main remedy is a fair remedy and trials under consideration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Superior Court also has an Appeals Chamber, which functions as the State Intermediate Court of Appeal.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The judges of the Superior Court shall be assigned by the Chief Justice to the Appeals Division.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There is also a tax court, which is a court of limited jurisdiction.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The judges of the Tax Court are seized of appeals from tax decisions rendered by county tax boards.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They also have before them appeals concerning decisions rendered by the Director of the Taxation Division on matters such as State income, sales taxes, business taxes and property refunds.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Appeals from decisions of the Tax Court are heard by the Appeal Division of the Superior Court.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The judges of the Tax Court are appointed by the Governor for an initial term of seven years and are reappointed until they reach the mandatory retirement age of 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There are 12 Tax Courts.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey divides into 21 counties

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was completely divided into counties in 1692.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the only state in the nation where the county's elected representatives are called "Freeholders", which governs each county on its own board of directors.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The number of free owners in each county is determined by referendum and must consist of three, five, seven or nine members.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Depending on the county, executive and legislative functions may be exercised by the board of directors of the free shareholders elected or divided into different branches of the administration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 16 counties, members of the board of directors of the elected Freeholders perform both legislative and executive functions on a commission basis, each freeholder being responsible for a department or a group of departments.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the other five counties (Atlantic, Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Mercer), there is a directly elected county executive who performs executive functions while the board of directors of elected free shareholders retains a legislative and supervisory role.

name: new_jersey

name: new_york
sentence: New York is a state in the northeastern part of the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: It was one of the thirteen colonies of origin, forming the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: With a total area of 54,555 square miles (141,300 km2), New York is the 27th largest state.

name: new_york
sentence: Its population of over 19 million in 2019 makes it the fourth most populous population.

name: new_york
sentence: Sometimes called New York State, it's the home of New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: Two thirds of the state's population live in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: With an estimated population of 8.34 million in 2019, New York City is the most populous city in the United States and the first gateway to immigration to the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: The metropolitan area of New York is one of the most populated in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: As a world city, New York City is home to the United Nations Headquarters and has been described as the world's cultural, financial and media capital, as well as the most economically powerful city in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The state's four most populous cities are Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, while the state's capital is Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has a diverse geography.

name: new_york
sentence: The state is bordered by New Jersey and Pennsylvania to the south and Connecticut, Massachusetts and Vermont to the east.

name: new_york
sentence: The state has a maritime border with Rhode Island, east of Long Island, and an international border with the Canadian provinces of Quebec to the north and Ontario to the northwest.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern portion of the state lies on the Atlantic coastal plain and includes Long Island and several smaller associated islands, as well as the City of New York and the lower Hudson River valley.

name: new_york
sentence: The large Upstate New York area includes several Appalachian mountain ranges and Adirondack Mountains in the northeast lobe of the state.

name: new_york
sentence: The north-south of the Hudson River Valley and the east-west of the Mohawk River Valley made the bisect of these more mountainous areas.

name: new_york
sentence: The western part of New York is considered to be part of the Great Lakes region and its boundaries are Lake Ontario, Lake Erie and Niagara Falls.

name: new_york
sentence: The central part of the state is dominated by Finger Lakes, a popular holiday and tourist destination.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was inhabited by tribes of Algonquian and Iroquoian Indians for several hundred years when the first Europeans arrived in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: French settlers and Jesuit missionaries arrived from southern Montreal to trade and proselytize.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1609 the area was visited by Henry Hudson sailing for the Dutch East India Company.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch built Fort Nassau in 1614 at the confluence of the Hudson and Mohawk rivers, where the present capital of Albany later developed.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch soon established New Amsterdam and parts of the Hudson Valley, establishing the multicultural colony of New Netherlands, a trade and immigration centre.

name: new_york
sentence: England seized the colony of the Dutch in 1664.

name: new_york
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War (1775-1783), a group of settlers from New York Province attempted to take control of the British colony and later succeeded in establishing independence.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, the development of the interior by New York, beginning with the Erie Canal, gave it incomparable advantages over other parts of the east coast and built its political and cultural ascendancy.

name: new_york
sentence: Many landmarks in New York are well known, including four of the ten most visited tourist attractions in the world in 2013: Times Square, Central Park, Niagara Falls and Grand Central Terminal.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the home of the Statue of Liberty.

name: new_york
sentence: In the twenty-first century, New York became a global hub of creativity and entrepreneurship, social tolerance and environmental sustainability.

name: new_york
sentence: There are approximately 200 colleges and universities in New York, including the State University of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Many were ranked among the top 100 in the nation and the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The tribes of what is now New York were mostly Haudenosaunee and Algonquian.

name: new_york
sentence: Long Island was roughly split between Wampanoag and Lenape.

name: new_york
sentence: Lenape also controlled most of the area surrounding New York Harbour.

name: new_york
sentence: To the north of Lenape, it was a third Algonquian nation, the Mohicans.

name: new_york
sentence: To the north of them, from east to west, there were three Iroquoian nations: the Mohawks, the original Iroquois and the Petuns.

name: new_york
sentence: To the south of them, divided about along Appalachia, were the Susquehannock and the Erie.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the Wampanoag and Mohicans were caught in the War of King Philip, a joint effort of many New England tribes to repel Europeans from their lands.

name: new_york
sentence: After the death of their leader, Chief Philip Metacomet, most of these peoples fled inside the country, dividing themselves into Abenaki and Schaghticoke.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the Mohicans remained in the area until the 1800s, however, a small group known as Ouabano migrated southwest to western Virginia at an earlier time.

name: new_york
sentence: Maybe they merged with the Shawnee.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawks and Susquehannocks were the most militaristic.

name: new_york
sentence: By trying to counter trade with Europeans, they targeted other tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawks were also known to refuse white colonization on their land and banish any people who converted to Christianity.

name: new_york
sentence: They represent a major threat to the Abenakis and Mohicans, while the Susquehannock briefly conquered the Lenape in the 1600s.

name: new_york
sentence: The most devastating event of the century, however, was the Beaver Wars.

name: new_york
sentence: From about 1640 to 1680, the Iroquoian peoples conducted campaigns ranging from modern Michigan to Virginia against the Algonquian and Siwan tribes, as well as both.

name: new_york
sentence: The goal was to control more land for the trapping of animals, a career that most natives had turned to in the hope of trading first with whites.

name: new_york
sentence: This completely altered the ethnography of the region, and most of the big game was hunted before the whites fully exploded the land.

name: new_york
sentence: Subsequently, the Iroquoise Confederation provided shelter for refugees from the Muscouten, Erie, Chononton, Tutelo, Saponi and Tuscarora nations.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 1700s, they also merged with the Mohawks during the Franco-Indian war and took the remaining Susquehannock from Pennsylvania after being decimated in the war.

name: new_york
sentence: Most of these other groups were involved until they ceased to exist.

name: new_york
sentence: Then, after the Revolution, a large group of them separated and returned to Ohio, becoming known as Mingo Senatorca.

name: new_york
sentence: The six current tribes of the Iroquoise Confederation are the Senatorca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, Tuscarora and Mohawk.

name: new_york
sentence: The Iroquois fought for both sides during the revolutionary war.

name: new_york
sentence: Today, the Iroquois still live on several reserves in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Meanwhile, the Lenapes formed a close relationship with William Penn.

name: new_york
sentence: However, when Penn died, his sons managed to take up much of their land and banish it in Ohio.

name: new_york
sentence: When the United States drafted the Indian Abduction Act, the Lenapes were moved to Missouri, while their cousins, the Mohicans, were sent to Wisconsin.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition, in 1778, the United States moved the Nanticoke from the Delmarva Peninsula to the former Iroquois lands south of Lake Ontario, although they did not stay long.

name: new_york
sentence: They mainly chose to migrate to Canada and merge with the Iroquois, although some moved westward and merged with the Lenape.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1524 Giovanni da Verrazzano, an Italian explorer serving the French crown, explored the Atlantic coast of North America between the Carolinas and Newfoundland, including New York Harbor and Narragansett Bay.

name: new_york
sentence: On 17 April 1524 Verrazzano entered New York Bay, passing through the strait now called the Narrows in the northern bay which he named Santa Margherita, in honour of the sister of the king of France.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano described it as "a vast coastline with a deep delta in which any type of ship could pass" and added: "that it extends inside for a league and opens to form a beautiful lake.

name: new_york
sentence: This vast water table warmed up with native boats."

name: new_york
sentence: It lands on the tip of Manhattan and perhaps on the furthest tip of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano's stay was interrupted by a storm that pushed him north towards Martha's vineyard.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1540, French traders from New France built a castle on Castle Island in the present Albany; it was abandoned the following year due to flooding.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1614 the Dutch, under Hendrick Corstiaensen's command, rebuilt the French castle, which they called Fort Nassau.

name: new_york
sentence: Fort Nassau is the first Dutch settlement in North America and is located along the Hudson River, also in the present Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: The small fort served as a trading post and warehouse.

name: new_york
sentence: Located on the floodplain of the Hudson River, the rudimentary "strong" was swept away by the floods in 1617, and abandoned for good after the construction of Fort Orange, Newfoundland, nearby in 1623.

name: new_york
sentence: Henry Hudson's voyage in 1609 marked the beginning of European engagement in the region.

name: new_york
sentence: Sailing for the Dutch East India Company and seeking a passage to Asia, he entered Upper New York Bay on September 11 of the same year.

name: new_york
sentence: His findings encouraged Dutch merchants to explore the coast in search of a profitable fur trade with local American Aboriginal tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: During the 17th century, Dutch trading posts were created for the trade of skins from the Lenape, Iroquois and other tribes in the colony of New Netherlands.

name: new_york
sentence: The first of these trading posts was Fort Nassau (1614, near the present Albany); Fort Orange (1624, on the Hudson River, just south of the present city of Albany and created to replace Fort Nassau), developing in the Beverwijck settlement (1647), and in what became Albany; Fort Amsterdam (1625, to develop in the city of New Amsterdam which is now New York City); and Esopus (1653, now Kingston).

name: new_york
sentence: The success of the ironship of Rensselaerswyck (1630), which surrounded Albany and lasted until the mid-19th century, was also a key factor in the colony's initial success.

name: new_york
sentence: The English captured the colony during the Second Anglo-Dutch War and ruled it as the Province of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The city of New York was taken over by the Dutch in 1673 during the Third Anglo-Dutch War (1672-1674) and renamed New Orange.

name: new_york
sentence: It was returned to the English under the Westminster Treaty a year later.

name: new_york
sentence: The Sons of Liberty were organized in New York during the 1760s, largely in response to the oppressive Stamp Act passed by the British Parliament in 1765.

name: new_york
sentence: The Congress of the Stamp met in the city on 19 October of the same year, composed of representatives of all the Thirteen Colonies that paved the way for the Continental Congress.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stamp Act Congress resulted in the Bill of Rights and Grievances, which was the first written expression by American representatives of many of the rights and complaints later expressed in the United States Declaration of Independence.

name: new_york
sentence: This included the right to representative government.

name: new_york
sentence: At the same time, given the strong commercial, personal and sentimental ties with Britain, many New Yorkers were loyalists.

name: new_york
sentence: The capture of Fort Ticonderoga provided the gun and powder needed to force a British withdrawal from the siege of Boston in 1775.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was the only colony not to vote for independence, as delegates were not allowed to do so.

name: new_york
sentence: New York then subscribed to the Declaration of Independence on 9 July 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New York was governed by a convention that met in White Plains on July 10, 1776, and after repeated adjournments and change of location, concluded its work in Kingston on Sunday evening, April 20, 1777, when the new constitution drafted by John Jay was adopted with a single dissenting voice.

name: new_york
sentence: It was not submitted to the people for ratification.

name: new_york
sentence: On 30 July 1777 George Clinton was inaugurated as the first governor of New York City in Kingston.

name: new_york
sentence: About one third of the battles of the American Revolutionary War took place in New York; the first major battle (and most important of the whole war) was the Battle of Long Island, alias.

name: new_york
sentence: Battle of Brooklyn, August 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: After their victory, the British occupied the city of New York, making it their military and political base of operations in North America during the duration of the conflict, and therefore the centre of interest of General George Washington's intelligence network.

name: new_york
sentence: On the famous ships of the British Wallabout Bay prison, more American fighters died of deliberate negligence than were killed in combat in every battle of the combined war.

name: new_york
sentence: Both sides of the fighters lost more soldiers than wounded.

name: new_york
sentence: The first of the two major British armies was captured by the Continental Army at the Battle of Saratoga in 1777, a success that influenced France to join the revolutionaries.The constitution of the state was promulgated in 1777.

name: new_york
sentence: New York became the 11th state to ratify the United States Constitution on 26 July 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: In an attempt to maintain sovereignty and remain an independent nation positioned between the new United States and British North America, four of the Iroquois nations fought on the British side; only the Oneida and their dependents, the Tuscarora, joined the Americans.

name: new_york
sentence: In retaliation for the attacks on the border by the Mohawk forces of Joseph Brant and Loyalist, the Sullivan expedition in 1779 destroyed nearly 50 Iroquois villages, adjacent agricultural lands and winter shops, forcing many refugees to travel to Niagara under British control.

name: new_york
sentence: As British allies, the Iroquois were expelled from New York, even though they had not participated in treaty negotiations.

name: new_york
sentence: They moved to Canada after the war and obtained Crown land concessions.

name: new_york
sentence: In the treaty, the British ceded most Indian lands to the new United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Because New York entered into a treaty with the Iroquois without Congress' approval, some of the land purchases have been the subject of land claims by the federal government's recognized tribes since the end of the 20th century.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has sold more than 5 million acres (20,000 km2) of former Iroquois territory in the years following the revolutionary war, leading to rapid development in northern New York.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the Treaty of Paris, the last vestige of British authority in the Thirteen former colonies – their troops in New York – left in 1783, which was long celebrated as a day of evacuation.

name: new_york
sentence: The City of New York is the national capital under the statutes of Confederation and the perpetual Union, the first national government.

name: new_york
sentence: This organization was found to be inadequate, and prominent New Yorker Alexander Hamilton advocated a new government that would include executive power, national courts and the power to impose.

name: new_york
sentence: Hamilton led the Annapolis Convention (1786), which called for the Philadelphia Convention, which drafted the United States Constitution, in which he also participated.

name: new_york
sentence: The new government had to be a strong federal national government to replace the relatively weaker confederation of each state.

name: new_york
sentence: Following a lively debate, which included the publication of the now quintessential constitutional interpretation — The Federalist Papers — as a series of articles in New York's newspapers, New York was the 11th state to ratify the United States Constitution on July 26, 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: New York remained the national capital under the new constitution until 1790, and was the site of the inauguration of President George Washington, the drafting of the U.S. Bill of Rights and the first session of the U.S. Supreme Court.

name: new_york
sentence: Hamilton's recovery of the heavily indebted U.S. economy after the war and the establishment of a national bank have greatly contributed to making New York the financial centre of the new nation.

name: new_york
sentence: Both Dutch and British imported African slaves as workers into the city and colony; New York had the second largest slave population after Charleston, South Carolina.

name: new_york
sentence: Slavery was widespread in New York City and in some agricultural areas.

name: new_york
sentence: The state passed a law for the progressive abolition of slavery shortly after the revolutionary war, but the last slave in New York was not released until 1827.

name: new_york
sentence: Transportation in western New York was done by expensive cars on muddy roads before the canals opened up rich agricultural land for long distances.

name: new_york
sentence: Governor DeWitt Clinton promoted the Erie Canal, which connects New York City with the Great Lakes through the Hudson River, the new canal, and rivers and lakes.

name: new_york
sentence: Work began in 1817 and the Erie Canal opened in 1825.

name: new_york
sentence: The tow-boats pulled by the horses on the tow-paths moved slowly over the canal, carrying passengers and freight.

name: new_york

sentence: On May 4, 1847, the Legislative Assembly of New York State established the Council of Immigration Commissioners to regulate immigration.
