sentence: Dem-NPL's protests were strong in the 2000 governor's race and in the 2006 general elections, but the League has not seen a major breakthrough since the administration of former state governor George Sinner.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The candidate for president of the Republican Party generally carries the state; in 2004, George W. Bush won with 62.9% of the vote.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of all the candidates for the democratic presidency since 1892, only Grover Cleveland (1892, one of three votes), Woodrow Wilson (1912 and 1916), Franklin D. Roosevelt (1932 and 1936) and Lyndon B. Johnson (1964) received votes from the North Dakota Electoral College.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On the other hand, Dem-NPL's candidates for the seats of Senator and Member of Parliament for North Dakota won all elections between 1982 and 2008, and the federal government delegation was fully democratic from 1987 to 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, the current two United States of America

name: north_dakota
sentence: Senators John Hoeven and Kevin Cramer are Republicans, as is the only Member of Parliament, Kelly Armstrong.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The income tax structure of North Dakota is slightly progressive; the five tranches of government income tax rates are 1.1%, 2.04%, 2.27%, 2.64% and 2.90% in 2017.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2005, North Dakota ranked 22nd in per capita taxes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The sales tax in North Dakota is 5% for most items.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The State authorizes municipalities to introduce local sales taxes and special local taxes, such as the additional sales tax of 1.75% in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Excise taxes are levied on the purchase price or market value of aircraft registered in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crown imposes a user tax on items purchased elsewhere but used in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Property owners in North Dakota pay property tax to their county, municipality, school district and special tax districts.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Tax Foundation classifies North Dakota as the state with the 20th most favourable tax climate for business in the nation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The day of tax freedom arrives on 1 April, 10 days earlier than the national day of tax freedom.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2006, North Dakota was the lowest number of returns filed by taxpayers with adjusted gross income of more than $1 million, or only 333.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of the 762,062 inhabitants of North Dakota, 56.54 per cent live in one of the 15 most populated cities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo is the largest city in North Dakota and is the region's economic hub.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck, in south-central North Dakota, along the banks of Missouri, has been the capital of North Dakota since 1883, first as the capital of Dakota territory, then as the capital of the state since 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Minot is a town in northern North Dakota and is home to North Dakota State Fair and Norsk Høstfest.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A few miles west of Bismarck, on the west side of the Missouri River, Mandan was named in honour of the Mandan Indians who lived in the area at the time of the Lewis and Clark expedition.

name: north_dakota
sentence: New Salem is the site of the largest statue of a holstein cow in the world.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Lake Grand Forks and Lake Devils are located in picturesque areas of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: West Fargo, the fifth largest city in North Dakota, is one of the fastest growing cities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: and has been recognized as a fun city USA by KaBOOM!

name: north_dakota
sentence: Williston is located near the confluence of the Missouri River and the Yellowstone River near Montana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Medora in the North Dakota Badlands hosts the Medora Musical every summer and is the gateway to Theodore Roosevelt National Park.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fort Yates, along the Missouri River on the Rock Indian Permanent Reserve, claims to host the last resting place of Hunkpa Lakota Sitting Bull chief (Mobridge, South Dakota also claims his grave).

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are 11 public colleges and universities, five tribal community colleges and four private schools.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The most important institutions are the State University of North Dakota and the University of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The higher education system consists of the following institutions:

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota University System (Public Institutions):

name: north_dakota
sentence: Tribal institutions:

name: north_dakota
sentence: Private institutions

name: north_dakota
sentence: "The Flickr State" is one of the nicknames of North Dakota and is derived from Richardson's land squirrel (Spermophilus richardson ii), a very common animal in the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The ground squirrel constantly wilts its tail in a distinctive way.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1953, legislation to make land squirrel the emblem of the state was passed by the state parliament.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has 10 daily newspapers, the most important being the Fargo-Moorhead Forum.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other weekly and monthly publications (most of which are fully supported by advertising) are also available.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The most important of them is the other weekly High Plains Reader.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state's oldest radio station, WDAY-AM, was launched on 23 May 1922.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The three major radio markets in North Dakota are concentrated around Fargo, Bismarck and Grand Forks, although stations broadcast in all regions of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Several new stations were built in Williston in the early 2010s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has 34 AM radio stations and 88 FM radio stations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: KFGO in Fargo has the widest audience.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Television broadcasting in North Dakota began on April 3, 1953, when KCJB-TV (now KXMC-TV) began operations in Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's television media markets are Fargo-Grand Forks (117th largest in the country), including half of the eastern state, and Minot-Bismarck (152nd), which make up the western half of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are currently 31 full-power television stations, divided into 10 networks, with 17 digital sub-channels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public broadcasting in North Dakota is provided by Prairie Public, with national television and radio networks affiliated with PBS and NPR.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public television stations open to community programming are available on the cable networks of Bismarck, Dickinson, Fargo and Jamestown.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is a state located in the eastern Midwest region of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Of the fifty states, it is the 34th largest per zone, and with a population of nearly 11.7 million, is the seventh most populated and the tenth most densely populated.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital of the state and the largest city is Columbus, with the Columbus metro area, the Grand Cincinnati and the Grand Cleveland being the largest metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bordered by Lake Erie to the north, Pennsylvania to the east, Virginia west to the southeast, Kentucky to the southwest, Indiana to the west, and Michigan to the northwest.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is historically known as the "Buckeye State" after its Ohio buckeyes, and Ohions are also known as the "Buckeyes".

name: ohio
sentence: The state derives its name from the Ohio River, whose name comes in turn from the word Senatorca ohi=yo', which means "good river," "great river," or "great river."

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was born from the lands west of Appalachia that were disputed from colonial times to the Indian wars of the late 18th century.

name: ohio
sentence: It was separated from the Northwest Territory, which was the first border of the new United States, and became the 17th State admitted to the Union on March 1, 1803, and the first under the Northwest Order.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was the first free post-colonial state admitted to union, and became one of the first and most influential industrial power plants in the 20th century; although it evolved into an information- and service-based economy in the 21st century, Ohio remains an industrial state, ranking seventh in GDP in 2019, with the third largest manufacturing sector and second largest automotive production.

name: ohio
sentence: The government of Ohio is composed of the executive, led by the Governor, of the legislature, composed of the Bicameral General Assembly of Ohio and the judiciary, led by the Supreme Court of the State.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has 16 seats in the United States House of Representatives.

name: ohio
sentence: The state is known for its status as both an oscillating state and a gazebo during the national elections.

name: ohio
sentence: Eight presidents of the United States came from Ohio, the most from any state, which led him to receive the moniker "Mother of Presidents".

name: ohio
sentence: The geographic location of Ohio has proven to be an asset for economic growth and expansion.

name: ohio
sentence: Because Ohio connects the northeast to the Midwest, many goods and business traffic cross its borders along its well-developed highways.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the country's 10th largest road network and is less than a day's drive away from 50 per cent of the North American population and 70 per cent of North America's manufacturing capacity.

name: ohio
sentence: To the north, Lake Erie gives Ohio 312 miles (502 km) of coastline, allowing for many cargo ports.

name: ohio
sentence: The southern Ohio boundary is defined by the Ohio River (the boundary being at the lower limit of 1792 on the north side of the river), and much of the northern boundary is defined by Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's neighbours are Pennsylvania to the east, Michigan to the northwest, Lake Erie to the north, Indiana to the west, Kentucky to the south, and West Virginia to the southeast.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's boundaries are defined in the enabling Act of 1802 as follows:

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bounded by the Ohio River, but almost the entire river itself belongs to Kentucky and West Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1980, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that, based on the wording of Virginia's cessation of territory (which at the time included what is now Kentucky and West Virginia), the Ohio-Kentucky border (and consequently West Virginia) is the north low water mark of the river as it existed in 1792.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has only this portion of the river between the 1792 low water mark and the current high water mark.

name: ohio
sentence: The boundary with Michigan also changed, following the Toledo War, to a slightly northeasterly angle to the north shore of the mouth of the Maumee River.

name: ohio
sentence: Much of Ohio has glazed till plains, with an exceptionally flat area in the northwest known as Great Black Swamp.

name: ohio
sentence: This glazed area of the north-west and central state is bordered first to the east and south-east by a belt known as the glazed Allegheny plateau, then another belt known as the unglazed Allegheny plateau.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of Ohio is of low relief, but the unglazed Allegheny Plateau has rugged hills and forests.

name: ohio
sentence: The rugged southeastern quadrant of Ohio, which extends into an arc-shaped arc along the Ohio River, from the Panhandle of West Virginia to the periphery of Cincinnati, forms a distinct socio-economic unit.

name: ohio
sentence: Geologically similar to parts of West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania, coal mining in that area, dependence on small pockets of former manufacturing facilities, and the distinctive regional dialect establish this section of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1965, the United States Congress passed the Appalachian Regional Development Act, which attempts to "respond to the persistent poverty and growing economic despair of the Appalachian region".

name: ohio
sentence: This Act defines 29 Ohio counties as part of Appalachia.

name: ohio
sentence: While one third of Ohio's land mass is in the Appalachian region defined by the federal government, only 12.8% of Ohio's people live there (1.476 million people).

name: ohio
sentence: The major rivers of the state are the Cuyahoga River, the Great Miami River, the Maumee River, the Muskingum River and the Scioto River.

name: ohio
sentence: Rivers in the northern part of the state flow through Lake Erie and the St. Lawrence River into the northern Atlantic Ocean, and rivers in the southern part of the state flow through the Ohio River and the Mississippi River into the Gulf of Mexico.

name: ohio
sentence: The worst weather disaster in Ohio's history took place along the Great Miami River in 1913.

name: ohio
sentence: Known as the Greater Dayton Flood, the entire Miami River watershed has flooded, including the business district of downtown Dayton.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result, the Miami Conservancy District was created as the first major floodplain engineering project in Ohio and the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Grand Lac St. Marys, in the western central part of the state, was built as a water supply for canals at the time of canal construction from 1820 to 1850.

name: ohio
sentence: For many years, this stretch of water, more than 52 km2, was the largest artificial lake in the world.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio canal construction projects were not the economic fiasco that similar efforts were made in other states.

name: ohio
sentence: Some cities, such as Dayton, owe their industrial emergence to their location on the canals, and until 1910, the inland canals carried much of the state's bulk cargo.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio climate is a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa/Dfb climate classification) in most of the state, except in the extreme southern counties of the Ohio Bluegrass region, which are on the northern periphery of the wet subtropical climate (Cfa) and the U.S. Upland South region.

name: ohio
sentence: Summers are generally warm and humid throughout the state, while winters generally vary from cold to cold.

name: ohio
sentence: Precipitation in Ohio is moderate throughout the year.

name: ohio
sentence: Violent weather is not uncommon in the state, although there are generally fewer reports of tornadoes in Ohio than in states in what is known as the Tornado gangway.

name: ohio
sentence: Lake-effect snowstorms are not uncommon on the southeast shore of Lake Erie, which is located in an area known as the snow belt.

name: ohio
sentence: Although mostly not in a subtropical climate, warmer-climate flora and fauna reach Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: For example, some trees with a more southerly range, such as Blackjack Oak, Quercus marilandica, are located northerly of Ohio, just north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: Also referring to this climate transition from subtropical to continental climate, several plants such as southern magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Albizia julibrissin (mimosa), Crape Myrtle and even occasionally Needle Palm are robust landscaping materials regularly used as street, yard and garden plantations in the Ohio Bluegrass area; but these same plants will simply not thrive in many of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: This interesting change can be observed during a trip across Ohio on Interstate 75 from Cincinnati to Toledo; the traveller observing this diverse state can even catch a glimpse of Cincinnati's common lizard, one of the few examples of permanent "subtropical" wildlife in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Due to the floods that caused severe road damage, Governor Mike DeWine declared a state of emergency in 37 counties in Ohio in 2019.

name: ohio
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 113°F (45°C), near Gallipolis on July 21, 1934.

name: ohio
sentence: The lowest recorded temperature was −39°F (−39°C) at Milligan on 10 February 1899 during the Great Blizzard of 1899.

name: ohio
sentence: Although few people have registered as being notable to the average resident, more than 200 earthquakes with a magnitude of 2.0 or more have occurred in Ohio since 1776.

name: ohio
sentence: The seismic zone of western Ohio and part of the seismic zone of the southern Great Lakes are located in the state, and there are numerous faults beneath the surface.

name: ohio
sentence: The largest known earthquake in Ohio's history was the Anna earthquake (Shelby County), which occurred on March 9, 1937.

name: ohio
sentence: It was centered in western Ohio, had a magnitude of 5.4 and was VIII-intensity.

name: ohio
sentence: Other major earthquakes in Ohio include: one of magnitude 4.8 near Lima on September 19, 1884; one of magnitude 4.2 near Portsmouth on May 17, 1901; and one of 5.0 in LeRoy Township, Lake County on January 31, 1986, which continued to trigger 13 replicas of magnitude 0.5 to 2.4 for two months.

name: ohio
sentence: Significant earthquakes in Ohio in the 21st century included an earthquake on December 31, 2011, about 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) northwest of Youngstown, and an earthquake on June 10, 2019, about 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) northwest of Eastlake under Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Columbus is the capital of Ohio, located near the geographic centre of the state and well known for Ohio State University.

name: ohio
sentence: However, other cities in Ohio are economic and cultural centres in metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Akron, Canton, Cleveland, Mansfield and Youngstown are in the northeast, known for the major industrial companies Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Timber, the top-ranked colleges Case Western Reserve University and Kent State University, the Cleveland Clinic, and cultural attractions such as the Cleveland Art Museum, Big Five Group Cleveland Orchestra, Playhouse Square, the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

name: ohio
sentence: Lima and Toledo are the major cities in Northwestern Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Northwest Ohio is known for its glass industry and is home to Owens Corning and Owens-Illinois, two Fortune 500 companies.

name: ohio
sentence: Dayton and Springfield are located in the Miami Valley, where the University of Dayton, Dayton Ballet and the large base of the Wright-Patterson Air Force are located.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati anchors southwestern Ohio and is the largest economy in the state.

name: ohio
sentence: It houses the University of Miami and the University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati Union Terminal, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, and various companies of Fortune 500 including Procter & Gamble, Kroger, Macy's, Inc., and the fifth third bank.

name: ohio
sentence: Steubenville is the only metropolitan city in Appalachian Ohio, home to Hocking Hills State Park.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cincinnati metropolitan area extends as far as Kentucky and Indiana, the Steubenville metropolitan area extends as far as West Virginia, the Toledo metropolitan area extends as far as Michigan, and the Youngstown metropolitan area extends as far as Pennsylvania.

name: ohio
sentence: Other metropolitan areas that house Ohio cities include:

name: ohio
sentence: The cities of Ohio that serve as centres for micropolitan regions in the United States include:

name: ohio
sentence: Archaeological evidence of spear points of the Folsom and Clovis types indicates that the Ohio Valley was inhabited by nomads as early as 13,000 BC.

name: ohio
sentence: These first nomads disappeared from Ohio by 1000 B.C.

name: ohio
sentence: Between 1,000 and 800 B.C., Adena's sedentary culture emerged.

name: ohio
sentence: The Adenas were able to establish "semi-permanent" villages because they domesticated plants, including sunflowers, and "wheat squash and possibly corn." With hunting and gathering, this crop supported more established and complex villages.

name: ohio
sentence: The most notable remaining of the Adena culture is the Grand Snake Mound, located in Adams County, Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Around 100 B.C., Adena evolved to the Hopewells, who were also mound builders.

name: ohio
sentence: Their complex, large and technologically sophisticated works of earth can be found in Marietta, Newark and Circleville today.

name: ohio
sentence: They were also a prolific commercial company, with their commercial network covering a third of the continent.

name: ohio
sentence: Hopewell disappeared from the Ohio Valley about 600 AD.

name: ohio
sentence: Mississippi culture grew as Hopewell culture declined.

name: ohio
sentence: Many people speaking the Siwan of the plains and the east coast claim them as ancestors and say that they lived throughout the Ohio region until about the 13th century.

name: ohio
sentence: There were three other contemporary cultures with the Mississippians: the ancient Fort people, the Whittlesey Focus people and Monongahela culture.

name: ohio
sentence: These three cultures disappeared in the 17th century.

name: ohio
sentence: Their origin is unknown.

name: ohio
sentence: The Shawnes may have absorbed the people of the Old Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also possible that Monongahela did not hold land in Ohio during the colonial era.

name: ohio
sentence: The Mississippi culture was close to the people of Fort-Ancien and exchanged a great deal with them.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio Valley Indians were greatly affected by the aggressive tactics of the Iroquois Confederation, based in central and western New York.

name: ohio
sentence: After the beaver wars of the mid-17th century, the Iroquois claimed much of Ohio as a hunting ground and, more importantly, as a beaver trap.

name: ohio
sentence: After the devastation of epidemics and war in the mid-17th century, which largely emptied the Ohio country of indigenous peoples in the mid-17th century to the end of the 17th century, the land gradually became repopulated by the predominantly Algonquian.

name: ohio
sentence: Many of these Ohio nations were multi-ethnic (sometimes multi-lingual) societies born of the devastation caused by disease, war and subsequent social instability.

name: ohio
sentence: They have survived agriculture (maize, sunflowers, beans, etc.)

name: ohio
sentence: Complemented by seasonal hunting.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, they were part of a larger global economy created by European entry into the fur trade.

name: ohio
sentence: The Aboriginal nations living in Ohio during the historical period included the Iroquoians, the Algonquians and the Siwans.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was also the site of Indian massacres, such as the Yellow Creek massacre, the Gnadenhutten massacre and the Pontiac School of Rebellion massacre.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of the Aboriginal people who remained in Ohio were gradually redeemed and persuaded to leave, or ordered by law, in the early 19th century with the Indian Abduction Act of 1830.

name: ohio
sentence: During the 18th century, the French introduced a trading post system to control the fur trade in the region.

name: ohio
sentence: As early as 1754, France and Great Britain fought the French and Indian wars.

name: ohio
sentence: Thanks to the Treaty of Paris, the French gave control of Ohio and the rest of the Old North West to Britain.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Treaty of Paris in 1783, Britain ceded to the United States all the claims of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: The United States created the Northwest Territory under the Northwest Order of 1787.

name: ohio
sentence: Slavery is not allowed in the new territory.

name: ohio
sentence: The settlement began with the founding of Marietta by the Ohio Company of Associates, which had been formed by a group of veterans of the American Revolutionary War.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the Ohio Company, the Miami Company (also known as the "Symma Purchase") claimed the southwest section, and Connecticut Land Company surveyed and established the Connecticut Western Reserve in present-day northeast Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Territorial surveyors from Fort Steuben began to survey approximately at the same time an area of eastern Ohio called the Seven Ranges.

name: ohio
sentence: The former Northwest Territory originally included areas formerly known as Ohio Country and Illinois Country.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio was preparing to become a state, the Indiana Territory was created, which reduced the Northwest Territory to about the present size of Ohio, plus half of the lower Michigan Peninsula and the eastern tip of the Upper Peninsula, as well as a portion of the southeast Indiana called "The Gore".

name: ohio
sentence: The coalition of Amerindian tribes, known as the Confederation of the West, was forced to cede a vast territory, including much of present-day Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville in 1795.

name: ohio
sentence: Under the North-West Ordinance, areas could be defined and admitted as states when their population reaches 60,000.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the population of Ohio was only 45,000 in December 1801, Congress determined that it was growing rapidly and that it had already taken the lead in the state.

name: ohio
sentence: With regard to the natives of Leni Lenape, Congress decided that 10,000 acres on the Muskingum River in the present state of Ohio would be "separated and their property would be devolved to the Moravian Brothers [...] or to a Society of the said Brothers for civilizing the Indians and encouraging Christianity."

name: ohio
sentence: Rufus Putnam served extensively in the French and Indian War and in the American Revolutionary War.

name: ohio
sentence: He was one of the most respected men in the early years of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1776 Putnam created a method of building portable fortifications that allowed the Continental Army to drive the British out of Boston.

name: ohio
sentence: George Washington was so impressed that he made Putnam his chief engineer.

name: ohio
sentence: After the war, Putnam and Manasseh Cutler contributed to the creation of the Northwest Order, which opened the Northwest Territory for settlement.

name: ohio
sentence: This land was used to compensate for what was due to the veterans of the revolutionary war.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also on Putnam's recommendation that the land be surveyed and arranged in six-square-mile townships.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam organized and led the first group of veterans to the territory.

name: ohio
sentence: They settled in Marietta, Ohio, where they built a great fort called Campus Martius.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam and Cutler insisted that the Northwest Territory be a free territory, not slavery.

name: ohio
sentence: They were both from Puritan New England, and Puritans firmly believed that slavery was morally evil.

name: ohio
sentence: The Northwest Territory doubled the size of the United States, and it was extremely important to consider it slavery-free in the decades that followed.

name: ohio
sentence: It covered what became Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and part of Minnesota.

name: ohio
sentence: Had these States been slave states, and their electoral votes were attributed to Abraham Lincoln's main competitor, Lincoln would not have been elected president.

name: ohio
sentence: The Civil War would not have been fought.

name: ohio
sentence: Even if there had been a civil war, the North would probably have lost.

name: ohio
sentence: In Puritan tradition, Putnam played an important role in the establishment of education in the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: Considerable areas have been reserved for schools.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam had been one of the main benefactors of the founding of the Leicester Academy in Massachusetts, and in 1798 he also created the plan for the construction of the Muskingum Academy (now Marietta College) in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1780, the directors of the Ohio Company appointed him superintendent of all his settlement affairs north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1796 he was commissioned by President George Washington as surveyor general of the United States Lands.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1788 he was a judge at the First Court of the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1802 he served in the convention to form a constitution for the State of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: On February 19, 1803, U.S. President Thomas Jefferson signed a law of Congress that approved the limits and constitution of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: However, Congress had never adopted a resolution formally admitting Ohio as the 17th state.

name: ohio
sentence: The current custom of Congress declaring an official date of the State did not begin until 1812, with the admission of Louisiana as the 18th state.

name: ohio
sentence: Although no formal admission decisions were required, when surveillance was discovered in 1953, while Ohio was preparing to celebrate its sesquicentenary, the Ohio MP, George H. Bender, introduced to Congress a bill to admit Ohio to the Union retroactively to March 1, 1803, when the Ohio General Assembly met for the first time.

name: ohio
sentence: At a special session in the former capital of Chillicothe State, the Ohio State Legislative Assembly approved a new petition for the creation of a state, which was handed over to Washington, D.C., on horseback.

name: ohio
sentence: On August 7, 1953 (the year of Ohio's 150th anniversary), President Eisenhower signed a joint Congress resolution that officially declared March 1, 1803, the date Ohio joined the Union.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has known three capitals: Chillicothe, Zanesville and Columbus.

name: ohio
sentence: Chillicothe was the capital from 1803 to 1810.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital was then transferred to Zanesville for two years, as part of a state legislative compromise to pass a bill.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital was then relocated to Chillicothe, the capital from 1812 to 1816.

name: ohio
sentence: Finally, the capital was moved to Columbus, to have it near the geographical center of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: Although many Amerindians migrated westward to escape American encroachment, others remained in the state, sometimes partially assimilated.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1830, under the leadership of President Andrew Jackson, the U.S. government forced the abduction of most tribes to Indian territory west of Mississippi.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1835 Ohio fought with Michigan during the Toledo War, an essentially bloodless border war over the Toledo Band.

name: ohio
sentence: Only one person was injured during the conflict.

name: ohio
sentence: Congress intervened, making Michigan's admission as a conditional state at the end of the conflict.

name: ohio
sentence: In exchange for abandoning its claim to the Toledo Band, Michigan received two-thirds west of the upper peninsula, in addition to a third east that was already considered part of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: The central position of Ohio and its population gave it an important place during the Civil War.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio River was a vital artery for troop and supply movements, as was the Ohio Railways.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio industry has made the state one of the most important states in the Union during the civil war.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has brought more soldiers per capita than any other state in the Union.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1862, state morale was severely shaken as a result of the battle of Shiloh, a costly victory in which Ohio forces suffered 2,000 casualties.

name: ohio
sentence: Later that year, when the Confederate troops under Stonewall Jackson threatened Washington, D.C., Ohio Governor David Tod could still recruit 5,000 volunteers to provide three months of service.

name: ohio
sentence: From July 12 to 23, 1863, southern Ohio and Indiana were attacked in Morgan's Raid.

name: ohio
sentence: While this raid was insignificant and small, it aroused fear among the people of Ohio and Indiana.

name: ohio

sentence: Oklahoma is a state in the south-central United States, bordered by Texas to the south and west, Kansas to the north, Missouri to the northeast, Arkansas to the east, New Mexico to the west, and Colorado to the northwest.

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma
sentence: On November 11, 1911, the temperature in Oklahoma City reached 83°F (28°C) (the record for that date), then a cold front of unprecedented intensity slammed through the state, causing the temperature to reach 17°F (−8°C) (the record for that date) at midnight.

name: oklahoma
sentence: This type of phenomenon is also responsible for many tornadoes in the region, such as the Oklahoma tornado epidemic in 1912, when a warm front ran through a frozen cold front, resulting in an average of one tornado per hour.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahomans have a high rate of English, Scotch-Irish, German and Amerindian ancestry, with 25 different indigenous languages spoken.

sentence: Because many Native Americans were forced to move to Oklahoma when the colonization of whites in North America increased, Oklahoma has a lot of linguistic diversity.

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma
sentence: Western breeders, Amerindian tribes, southern settlers and eastern oil barons have shaped the state's cultural predisposition, and its largest cities have been named among the most undervalued cultural destinations in the United States.

sentence: However, the term is often used positively by Oklahomans.

sentence: Rodeos are popular throughout the state, and Guymon, in the panhandle of the state, welcomes one of the largest in the nation.

sentence: Oklahoma was the 21st recipient of federal medical funding in 2005, with federal spending on health in the state totalling $75,801,364; immunization, bioterrorism preparedness and health education were the top three most funded medical items.

sentence: Oklahomans are in the top half of Americans in terms of prevalence of obesity, and the state is the fifth most obese of the nation, with 30.3 percent of its population to or near obesity.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The people of Oklahoma have a lower than average life expectancy compared to many other states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2014, men in Oklahoma lived on average 73.7 years compared to a national average of 76.7 years and women 78.5 years compared to a national average of 81.5 years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In addition, increases in life expectancy were below the national average.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Male life expectancy in Oklahoma between 1980 and 2014 increased by an average of 4.0 years, compared to a national average of 6.7 years of increased male life expectancy.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Women's life expectancy in Oklahoma between 1980 and 2014 increased by 1.0 years compared to a national average of 4.0 years in the life expectancy of women.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Using 2016-2018 data, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation calculated that life expectancy in Oklahoma counties ranged from 71.2 years for Okfuskee County to 79.7 years for Cimarron and Logan County.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The life expectancy of the State as a whole was 76.0 years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma City and Tulsa are the 45th and 61st largest media markets in the United States, ranked by Nielsen Media Research.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The third state media market, Lawton-Wichita Falls (Texas), is ranked 149th nationally by the agency.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Television broadcasting in Oklahoma began in 1949 when KFOR-TV (then WKY-TV) in Oklahoma City and KOTV-TV in Tulsa began broadcasting a few months apart.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Currently, all major U.S. broadcasting networks have affiliated television stations in the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has two primary newspapers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoman, based in Oklahoma City, is the largest newspaper in the state and the 54th largest in the nation by broadcasting, with a weekly readership of 138,493 and a Sunday readership of 202,690.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Tulsa World, the second most widely distributed newspaper in Oklahoma and the 79th in the nation, has a Sunday broadcast of 132,969 and a daily readership of 93,558.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's first newspaper was created in 1844, called lawyer Cherokee, and was written in both Cherokee and English.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2006, there were more than 220 newspapers in the State, 177 with weekly publications and 48 with daily publications.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The first state radio station, WKY in Oklahoma City, began broadcasting in 1920.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2006, there were more than 500 radio stations in Oklahoma broadcasting with different local or national networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Five universities in Oklahoma operate non-commercial public radio stations/networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has a few ethnic television channels that broadcast in Spanish and Asian, and there are a few Amerindian programs.

name: oklahoma
sentence: TBN, a Christian religious television network, has a studio in Tulsa, and built its first wholly owned subsidiary of TBN in Oklahoma City in 1980.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Transportation in Oklahoma is generated by an anchoring system of interstate highways, interurban railway lines, airports, inland ports and public transport networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Located along an integral point in the U.S. interstate network, Oklahoma contains three primary highways and four auxiliary highways.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the city of Oklahoma, Interstate 35 interstates with Interstate 44 and Interstate 40, one of the most important intersections along the U.S. road network.

name: oklahoma
sentence: More than 12,000 miles (19 000 km) of roads constitute the largest road skeleton in the state, including government-operated roads, ten tolls or major toll roads, and the longest section of Highway 66 in the country.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2008, the Oklahoma City Interstate 44 was the busiest highway in Oklahoma, with a daily traffic volume of 123,300 cars.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2010, the State had the third largest number of bridges classified as structurally deficient, with nearly 5,212 dilapidated bridges, including 235 bridges in the national road network.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's largest commercial airport is the Will Rogers World Airport in Oklahoma City, with an average annual passenger population of more than 3.5 million (1.7 million boardings) in 2010.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa International Airport, the second largest commercial airport in the state, served more than 1.3 million embarkations in 2010.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Between these two, six airlines operate in Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In terms of traffic, the R.L. Jones Jr. (Riverside) airport in Tulsa is the busiest airport in the state, with 335,826 take-offs and landings in 2008.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has over 150 public airports.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is connected to the national rail network by the Amtrak Heartland Flyer, its only regional passenger transport line.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It currently extends from Oklahoma City to Fort Worth, Texas, although legislators began seeking funding in early 2007 to link the Heartland Flyer to Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two inland ports on the rivers serve Oklahoma: the port of Muskogee and the port of Tulsa de Catoosa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The port of Tulsa de Catoosa is one of the most inland international ports in the United States, leading the navigation of the McClellan–Kerr Arkansas River navigation system, which links the Tulsa and Muskogee barge traffic to the Mississippi River.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The port ships more than two million tonnes of goods per year and is a designated area for foreign trade.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is a constitutional republic with a government inspired by the federal government of the United States, with executive, legislative and judicial powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State has 77 counties with jurisdiction over most of the functions of local government in each area, five districts of Congress, and a voting base with plurality in the Republican Party.

name: oklahoma
sentence: State representatives are elected by pluralist vote in the State of Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has the death penalty as a legal penalty, and the state has had (between 1976 and mid-2011) the highest per capita execution rate in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Legislative Assembly of Oklahoma consists of the Senator and the House of Representatives.

name: oklahoma
sentence: As a legislative branch of the state government, it is responsible for collecting and distributing the funds needed to manage the government.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Senator has 48 members for a four-year term, while the House has 101 members for a two-year term.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State has a statutory term limit which limits any person to twelve cumulative years of service between the two legislative powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judiciary of Oklahoma consists of the Supreme Court of Oklahoma, the Criminal Appeal Court of Oklahoma and 77 district courts, each serving a single county.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judiciary of Oklahoma also includes two independent courts: an indictment court and the Oklahoma court on the judiciary.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has two courts of last resort: the State Supreme Court hears civil cases, and the State Criminal Appeal Court hears criminal cases (this split system exists only in Oklahoma and nearby Texas).

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judges of these two courts, as well as the Court of Civil Appeal, are appointed by the Governor on the recommendation of the State Judicial Nominations Commission and are subject to a non-partisan retention vote according to a rotational schedule of six years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Executive is composed of the Governor, his staff and other elected officials.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The chief head of government, the Governor, is the head of the Oklahoma Executive, who is the commander-in-chief of the Oklahoma National Guard when not called for federal use and who reserves the power of veto to bills passed by the Legislative Assembly.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The executive branch's responsibilities include the submission of the budget, the enforcement of State laws and the maintenance of peace within the State.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state is divided into 77 counties, each governed by a three-member council of elected commissioners, a tax assessor, a clerk, a clerk, a treasurer and a sheriff.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While each municipality operates as a separate and independent local government with executive, legislative and judicial powers, county governments retain jurisdiction over incorporated cities and unincorporated areas within their borders, but have executive but no legislative or judicial powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: County and municipal governments collect taxes, employ a separate police force, organize elections and manage emergency response services within their jurisdiction.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other local government services include school districts, technology centre districts, community college districts, rural fire departments, rural water districts and other special-purpose districts.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Thirty-nine Amerindian tribal governments are based in Oklahoma, each with limited powers in designated areas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While typical Indian reserves in most of the United States are not present in Oklahoma, tribal governments hold land granted during the time of Indian territory, but with limited jurisdiction and no control over government governing bodies such as municipalities and counties.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tribal governments are recognized by the United States as quasi-sovereign entities with executive, judicial and legislative powers over tribal members and functions, but are subject to the power of the United States Congress to revoke or deny certain powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tribal governments are required to submit a constitution and any subsequent amendments to the United States Congress for approval.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has 11 sub-State districts, including the two major Governing Councils, INCOG in Tulsa (Council of Indian Governments) and ACOG (Association of Central Oklahoma Governments).

name: oklahoma
sentence: During the first half-century of the state, Oklahoma was considered a democratic bastion, being carried by the Republican Party in only two presidential elections (1920 and 1928).

name: oklahoma
sentence: After the 1948 elections, the state was firmly republican.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Although the registered Republicans were a minority in the state until 2015, Oklahoma was carried by Republican presidential candidates in all but one election since 1952: the victory of Lyndon B. Johnson 1964 shaken.

name: oklahoma
sentence: All Oklahoma counties have been won by Republican candidates in the presidential elections since 2004.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In general, Republicans are the strongest in the suburbs of Oklahoma City and Tulsa, as well as in the Panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Democrats are the strongest in the eastern part of the state and Little Dixie, as well as in the most African-American and internal parts of Oklahoma City and Tulsa.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania (German: Pennsilfaani), officially the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, is a state located in the Middle Atlantic, Appalachian and Great Lakes regions of the Northeastern United States.

sentence: A Pew survey of religious self-identification of Rhode Island residents showed the following distribution of affiliations: Roman Catholics 42%, Protestants 30%, Jews 1%, Jehovah's Witnesses 2%, Buddhism 1%, Mormonism 1%, Hinduism 1% and non-religious 20%.

sentence: The counties did not have a representative government until the adoption of the internal system in 1975.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Governor Pitchfork Ben Tillman, a populist, led the effort to deny the right to vote to the poor blacks and whites, although he controlled the politics of the democratic state from 1890 to 1910 with a base among the poor white peasants.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During the constitutional assembly of 1895, he supported another man's proposal that the State should adopt a rule of one drop, as well as prohibiting marriage between whites and any person of known African descent.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Some members of the Convention have realized that prominent white families of some African descent may be affected by such legislation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In terms similar to a debate in Virginia in 1853 on a similar proposal (which was abandoned), George Dionysius Tillman said in the opposition:

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state has postponed this law by one drop for years.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Virginian legislators passed a law of one drop in 1924, forgetting that their state had many people of mixed ancestry among those who identified themselves as white.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the early 20th century, South Carolina developed a prosperous textile industry.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state has also converted its cotton agricultural base into more profitable crops; attracted large military bases through its powerful delegation to the Democratic Congress, a part of the South following the abandonment of the right to vote of blacks at the turn of the century; and created tourism industries.

name: south_carolina
sentence: At the beginning of the 20th century, millions of African Americans left South Carolina and other southern states for jobs, opportunities and relative freedom in American cities outside the former Confederate states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In total, from 1910 to 1970, 6.5 million blacks left the South in the Great Migration.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1930, South Carolina had a white majority population for the first time since 1708.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of many states that initially rejected the nineteenth amendment (1920) giving women the right to vote.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The South Carolina Legislative Assembly then ratified the amendment on July 1, 1969.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The struggle of the civil rights movement took place in South Carolina as in other states of the South.

name: south_carolina
sentence: However, South Carolina has experienced a much less violent movement than other southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This quiet transition of a Jim Crow company occurred because the white and black leaders of the state were willing to accept the slow change rather than being totally reluctant to accept the change at all.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Other Southern Carolinians, like Senator Strom Thurmond, on the other hand, were among the most radical and effective opponents of social equality and integration.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2015, South Carolina had one of the lowest percentages among all women's states in the State Legislative Assembly, at 13.5% (only Louisiana, Oklahoma and Wyoming had a lower percentage; the national average was 24.3%; the highest percentage was in Colorado at 41%).

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2011, South Carolina ranked first in the country in the rate of women killed by men.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As the 21st century progressed, South Carolina attracted new businesses with a 5% corporate income tax rate, no state property tax, no local income tax, no inventory tax, no sales tax on manufacturing equipment, industrial energy or materials for finished products, no wholesale tax and no unit global income tax.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of the first states to stop paying for "early" baby deliveries under Medicaid and private insurance.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The term "early elective" is defined as a work induction or a Caesarean section between 37 and 39 weeks that is not medically based.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This change is intended to promote the health of babies and reduce unnecessary costs for South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On November 20, 2014, South Carolina became the 35th state to legalize homosexual marriages, when a federal court ordered the change.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has many sites for visual and performing arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Gibbes Museum of Art in Charleston, the Greenville County Museum of Art, the Columbia Museum of Art, the Spartanburg Art Museum and the South Carolina State Museum in Columbia, among others, provide access to the state's visual arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also many historical sites and museums scattered throughout the state, paying tribute to many events and periods in the history of the state, from Amerindian housing to today.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina also has art halls, including the Peace Center in Greenville, the Koger Center for the Arts in Columbia and the Newberry Opera House, among others, to attract local, national and international talent to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Several major sites can host major events, including Colonial Life Arena in Columbia, Bon Secours Wellness Arena in Greenville and North Charleston Coliseum.

name: south_carolina
sentence: One of the country's main arts festivals, the Spoleto Festival USA, is held annually in Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also countless local festivals across the state highlighting many cultural traditions, historical events and folklore.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the South Carolina Arts Commission, the creative industries generate $9.2 billion a year and support over 78,000 jobs in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A 2009 government-wide survey conducted by the University of South Carolina's Institute for Public Service and Policy Research found that 67% of residents had participated in the arts in some form in the past year and that, on average, citizens had participated in the arts 14 times in the previous year.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), in 2010, the largest religion was Christianity, whose largest denominations were the Southern Baptist Convention with 913,763 adherents, the Methodist Church united with 274,111 adherents and the Roman Catholic Church with 181,743 adherents.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The fourth largest is the African Methodist Episcopal Church with 564 congregations and 121,000 members and the fifth largest is the Presbyterian Church (USA) with 320 congregations and nearly 100,000 members.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was the US state with the highest per capita proportion of citizens following the Bahá'í faith, with 17,559 adherents, making Bahá'í the second religion of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Although no major professional sports team is based in South Carolina, the Caroline Panthers have training facilities in the state and played their first home game season at Clemson Memorial Stadium, but they are now playing at the Bank of America Stadium in North Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Panthers consider themselves "the Carolines team" and refrain from naming themselves after Charlotte or any of the Carolinas.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state also houses many professional teams of minor leagues.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The College's teams represent their particular institutions in South Carolina, and are the main options for football, basketball and baseball in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also a top-of-the-range destination for golf and water sports.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also home to one of NASCAR's first runways and its first paved access road, Darlington Raceway, northwest of Florence.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2019, South Carolina's GDP was $249.9 billion, making the state the 26th largest GDP in the United States.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the United States Bureau of Economic Analysis, South Carolina's gross domestic product (GDP) amounted to $97 billion in 1997 and $153 billion in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Its real per capita gross domestic product (GDP) in 2000 dollars was $26,772 in 1997 and $28,894 in 2007; it represented 85% of per capita real GDP of $31,619 for the United States in 1997 and 76% of $38,020 for the United States in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Government debt in 2012 was calculated by source as $22.9 billion, or $7,800 per taxpayer.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Industrial outputs include textiles, chemicals, paper products, machinery, automobiles, automotive products and tourism.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The government's main agricultural products are tobacco, poultry, cotton, cattle, dairy products, soybeans, hay, rice and pork.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as of March 2012, South Carolina had 1,852,700 non-agricultural jobs, of which 12 per cent were in manufacturing, 11.5 per cent in recreation and hospitality, 19 per cent in trade, transportation and public services, and 11.8 per cent in education and health services.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The service sector accounts for 83.7% of South Carolina's economy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Many large companies have moved their locations to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Boeing opened an aircraft manufacturing plant in Charleston in 2011, which is one of the last two assembly sites of the 787 Dreamliner.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is a state of the right to work and many companies use recruitment agencies to temporarily fill positions.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Domtar, Rock Hill, is the only Fortune 500 company based in South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Fortune 1000 list includes SCANA, Sonoco Products and ScanSource.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina also benefits from foreign investment.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 1,950 foreign companies operating in South Carolina and employing nearly 135,000 people.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Foreign direct investment (FDI) contributed $1.06 billion to the state economy in 2010.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Since 1994, BMW has owned a production plant in Spartanburg County, near Greer, and since 1996, the Zapp Group has operated in Summerville, near Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 36 television stations (including PBS affiliates) serving South Carolina with terrestrial access and some online streaming.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The markets in which the stations are located include Columbia, Florence, Allendale, Myrtle Beach, Greenville, Charleston, Conway, Beaufort, Hardeeville, Spartanburg, Greenwood, Anderson and Sumter.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State has the fourth largest state system in the country, consisting of 11 interstates, numbered motorways, state highways and secondary roads, with a total area of approximately 41,500 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On secondary roads, South Carolina uses a numbering system to follow all non-interstate and primary roads maintained by the Department of Transport of South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Secondary roads are numbered by the number of the county followed by a single number for the particular road.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Amtrak passenger train operates four passenger routes in South Carolina: Crescent, Palmetto, Silver Meteor and Silver Star.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Crescent Road serves the cities of Upstate, the silver star serves the cities of Midlands and the Palmetto and Silver Meteor routes serve the towns of Lower Countries.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Station stops

name: south_carolina
sentence: FreightCSX Transportation and Norfolk Southern are the only Class I railway companies in South Carolina, as other state freight companies are short lines.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are seven major airports in South Carolina, all of which act as regional airport centres.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The busiest passenger volume is Charleston International Airport.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Just across the North Carolina border, Charlotte/Douglas International Airport is the 30th busiest airport in the world, in terms of passengers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was one of three states that did not agree to use competitive international math and language standards.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2014, the South Carolina Supreme Court ruled that the state had failed to provide "minimally adequate" education to children in all parts of the state, as required by the state constitution.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has 1,144 K-12 schools in 85 school districts, with 712,244 registered in the fall of 2009.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During the 2008-2009 school year, South Carolina spent $9,450 per student, placing it 31st in the country for expenditures per student.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2015, the national average TSS was 1490 and South Carolina was 1442, 48 points below the national average.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is the only state that owns and operates a state-wide school bus system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In December 2016, the State had a fleet of 5,582 buses whose average vehicle in service was 15 years old (the national average is six) travelling 236 000 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Half of the state's school buses are over 15 years old and some of them would be up to 30 years old.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2017 in the draft budget, Education Superintendent Molly Spearman asked the state lease to buy 1,000 buses to replace the most decrepit vehicles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: An additional 175 buses could be purchased immediately under the Crown Treasurer's Master Lease Program.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On January 5, 2017, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency granted South Carolina more than $1.1 million to replace 57 school buses with new cleaner models under its Diesel Emissions Reduction Act.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has a variety of institutions, ranging from large state-funded research universities to small colleges that cultivate liberal arts, religious or military traditions.

name: south_carolina
sentence: For all health care, South Carolina is ranked 33rd out of 50 states, according to the Commonwealth Fund, a private health foundation that works to improve the health care system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Kaiser Family Foundation, the birth rate among State adolescent girls was 53 births per 1,000 adolescents, compared with the national average of 41.9 births.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State infant mortality rate was 9.4 deaths per 1,000 births, compared with a national average of 6.9 deaths.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 2.6 physicians per 1,000 people compared to the national average of 3.2 physicians.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Per capita health expenditure was $5,114 in the State, compared with a national average of $5,283.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 26 per cent of children and 13 per cent of older people living in poverty in the state, compared to 23 per cent and 13 per cent, respectively, in the United States, and 34 per cent of children were overweight or obese, compared to the national average of 32 per cent.
