name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is an American state located in the Midwestern region of the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It bears the names of the indigenous tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which make up a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the seventeenth largest by region, but the fifth least populated, and the fifth least densely populated of the 50 United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As a southern part of the former Dakota territory, South Dakota became a state on 2 November 1889, simultaneously with North Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is either the 39th or the 40th State admitted to the Union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison modified the state documents before signing them so that no one would know who became a state first.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Pierre is the capital of the state and Sioux Falls, with a population of about 187,200 inhabitants, is the largest city in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is bounded by the states of North Dakota (north), Minnesota (east), Iowa (southeast), Nebraska (south), Wyoming (west) and Montana (northwest).

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state is divided by the Missouri River, which divides South Dakota into two geographically and socially distinct halves, known to residents as the "East River" and the "West River".

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern South Dakota is home to most of the state's population, and the fertile soil of the region is used to cultivate various crops.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the west of Missouri, livestock is the main agricultural activity, and the economy is more dependent on tourism and defence spending.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Most of the Amerindian reserves are located at West River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills, a group of low mountains covered with sacred pines in the Sioux, are located in the southwest part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mount Rushmore, an important tourist destination, is there.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a temperate continental climate, four distinct seasons and moderate precipitation in the east to semi-arids in the west.

name: south_dakota
sentence: State ecology presents species typical of a North American prairie biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Human beings lived in the region for several millennia, with the Sioux becoming dominant in the early 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At the end of the 19th century, Euro-American colonization intensified after a gold rush in the black hills and the construction of eastern railways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of Indian wars were unleashed by miners and crowded settlers, culminating in the wounding of the knee in 1890.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Key events of the 20th century included the Dust Bowl and the Great Depression, the increase in federal spending in the 1940s and 1950s on agriculture and defence, and the industrialization of agriculture that reduced family farming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While several Democrats have represented South Dakota for multiple terms in both chambers of Congress, the state government is largely controlled by the Republican Party, whose candidates have carried South Dakota to each of the last 13 presidential elections.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Historically dominated by an agricultural economy and a rural lifestyle, South Dakota has recently sought to diversify its economy into regions to attract and retain residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The history and rural character of South Dakota continues to have a strong influence on the culture of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota, located in the north central United States, is considered part of the Midwest by the United States Census Bureau and is also part of the Great Plains region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Western South Dakota's culture, economy and geography have more in common with the West than the Midwest.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a total area of 77,116 square miles (199730 km2), making the State the 17th largest in the Union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk Peak, formerly called Harney Peak, with an altitude of 7,242 feet (2,207 m), is the highest point in the state, while the shore of Big Stone Lake is the lowest, with an altitude of 966 feet (294 m).

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is bordered to the north by North Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geographic centre of the United States is 27 km west of Castle Rock in Butte County.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The North American continental pole of inaccessibility is located between Allen and Kyle, 1,024 mi (1,648 km) from the nearest coast.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River is the largest and longest river in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Cheyenne, James, Big Sioux and White rivers are also the main rivers in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern South Dakota has many natural lakes, mainly created by periods of glaciation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In addition, the Missouri River dams create four large reservoirs: Oahe Lake, Sharpe Lake, Francis Case Lake, Lewis Lake and Clark Lake.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota can generally be divided into three regions: Eastern South Dakota, Western South Dakota and Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Missouri serves as a limit to the geographic, social and political differences between eastern and western South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geography of the Black Hills, long considered sacred by the Amerindians, differs from its environment to such an extent that it can be considered distinct from the rest of Southwestern Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sometimes the black hills are combined with the rest of western South Dakota, and people often refer to the two resulting regions, divided by the Missouri River, such as the West River and the East River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In eastern South Dakota, precipitation and topography are generally higher than in the western state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The smaller geographic areas of this region include the Prairie Coteau, the Dissolved Till Plains and the James River Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Prairie Coteau is a plateau located east of the Minnesota River Valley and west of the James River Basin.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Further to the west, the James River basin is primarily low, flat and heavily eroded land, following the flow of the James River by South Dakota from north to south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Till Plains Dissected, an area of hilly hills and fertile soils that covers much of Iowa and Nebraska, extends into the southeast corner of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The layers deposited during the Pleistocene era, about two million years ago, cover most of eastern South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It was the youngest layers of rock and sediment in the state, the product of successive periods of glaciation that deposited a large amount of rock and soil, known as till, on the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Great Plains cover most of the two-thirds of western South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the west of Missouri, the landscape becomes more arid and rugged, composed of hilly hills, plains, ravines and flat, steep hills called mounds.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the south, east of the Black Hills, are the Badlands of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The erosion of the Black Hills, marine skeletons that fell to the bottom of a large shallow sea that once covered the area, and volcanic material all contribute to the geology of this region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills are located in southwestern South Dakota and extend to Wyoming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This range of low mountains covers 6,000 m2 (16 000 km2), with peaks rising from 2,000 to 4,000 feet (600 to 1,200 m) above their bases.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills are the location of Black Elk Peak (7,242 ft or 2,207 m above sea level), the highest point in South Dakota and also the highest point in the United States east of the Rocky Mountains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The two-billion-year-old Precambrian formations, the oldest rocks in the state, form the central nucleus of the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The formations of the Paleozoic era form the outer ring of the Black Hills

name: south_dakota
sentence: This area features rocks such as limestone, which were deposited here when the area formed the shoreline of an ancient inland sea.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Much of South Dakota (with the exception of the Black Hills region) is dominated by a temperate prairie biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although grasses and crops cover most of this region, deciduous trees such as cottonwood, elms and willows are common near rivers and in shelter belts.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state bird, the round-neck pheasant, adapted well to the region after being introduced from China.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Growing populations of bald eagles spread throughout the state, especially near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Prairie rivers and lakes are home to populations of gilt, carp, pike, bass and other species.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River also contains the prehistoric spatular.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Due to higher elevations and precipitation levels, the ecology of Black Hills differs significantly from that of the plains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The mountains are thickly covered with different types of pine, including ponderosa and lodgepole pines, as well as spruce.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Hills mammals include deer, elk (wapiti), sheep, mountain goats, pine martens and mountain lions, while streams and lakes contain several species of trout.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a continental climate with four distinct seasons, ranging from cold and dry winter to warm and semi-wet summers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During summers, the average high state temperature is often close to 90°F (32°C), although it cools to nearly 60°F (16°C) at night.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is not uncommon for South Dakota to have severe hot and dry periods in summer with temperatures rising above 100°F (38°C) several times a year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Winters are cold, with high January temperatures on average below freezing and low temperatures on average below 10°F (−12°C) in most states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 120 °F (49 °C) at Usta on 15 July 2006, and the lowest recorded temperature was −58 °F (−50 °C) at McIntosh on 17 February 1936.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Average annual precipitation in South Dakota ranges from semi-arid conditions in the northwestern part of the state (approximately 15 inches or 380 mm) to semi-humid conditions around the southeastern part of the state (approximately 25 inches or 640 mm), although a small lead-centered area in the black hills has the highest precipitation at nearly 30 inches (760 mm) per year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The summers of South Dakota cause frequent, sometimes severe, thunderstorms with violent winds, thunders and hail.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the State is often considered to be part of the Tornado gangway, and South Dakota suffers an average of 30 tornadoes per year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Severe blizzards and ice storms often occur in winter.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has several sites administered by the National Parks Service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two national parks were established in the state, both in its southwestern region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Wind Cave National Park, founded in 1903 in the Black Hills, has a vast network of caves and is home to a large herd of bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Badlands National Park was established in 1978 and is home to a brightly coloured, eroded landscape surrounded by semi-arid meadows.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Mont-Rushmore National Memorial in the Black Hills was created in 1925.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The sculpture of four American presidents was carved on the mountain by sculptor Gutzon Borglum.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other areas managed by the National Parks Service include the Jewel Cave National Monument near Custer, the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, Minuteman Missile National Historic Site, which includes a decommissioned nuclear missile silo and a separate missile control area several kilometres away, and the Missouri National Recreational River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crazy Horse Memorial is a large mountainside sculpture near Mount Rushmore under construction with private funds.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Mammouth site near Hot Springs is another private attraction in the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This is a paleontological excavation that works and has one of the world's largest concentrations of mammoth remains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Humans have been living in what South Dakota is today for thousands of years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first inhabitants were Paleoindian hunter-gatherers, and disappeared from the area around 5000 B.C.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Between 500 and 800 AD, a semi-nomadic people known as Mound Builders lived in central and eastern South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 14th century, the Crow Creek massacre took place, in which several hundred men, women and children were killed near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: By 1500, the Arikara (or Ree) had settled in much of the Missouri Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: European contact with the region began in 1743, when the LaVérendrye brothers explored the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The LaVérendrye group buried a plaque near the site of modern Pierre, claiming the region for France as part of the great Louisiana.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1762, the whole region was part of the Spanish Louisiana until 1802.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At the beginning of the 19th century, the Sioux had largely replaced the Arikara as a dominant group in the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1803 the United States purchased the territory of Louisiana, a region that included most of Napoleon Bonaparte's South Dakota, and President Thomas Jefferson organized a group commonly known as the "Lewis and Clark Expedition" to explore the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1817, an American fur trade post was established at the present Fort Pierre, which began to settle continuously in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1855, the American army bought Fort Pierre but abandoned it in 1857 in favour of Fort Randall in the south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At that time, American and European settlement grew rapidly, and in 1858 the Yankton Sioux signed the Treaty of 1858, giving the United States most of the present South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Speculators founded two of the largest cities in South Dakota today: Sioux Falls in 1856 and Yankton in 1859.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1861 the territory of Dakota was established by the Government of the United States (originally North Dakota, South Dakota and parts of Montana and Wyoming).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Colonization of the region, mainly by residents of the eastern United States and western and northern Europe, increased rapidly, especially after the completion of an eastern railway link to Yankton in 1873.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1874, gold was discovered in the Black Hills during a military expedition led by George A. Custer and miners and explorers began illegally entering the land promised to the Lakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Custer expedition took place despite the fact that the Sioux had received the entire western half of the present South Dakota (West River) in 1868 by the Treaty of Laramie under the Great Sioux Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Sioux refused to grant mining rights or land in the Black Hills, and the war broke out after the United States did not prevent white miners and settlers from entering the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Finally, the United States won and broke the Sioux Great Reserve into five reserves, settling the Lakota there.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1980, the Supreme Court and Congress ordered compensation, but the Lakota still refused to accept it, insisting on the restitution of their lands.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A growing population and political concerns (the accession of two states meant the arrival of four new senators for the Republican Party) caused the division of Dakota territory into two and President Benjamin Harrison signed proclamations that officially admitted South Dakota and North Dakota to union on November 2, 1889.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harrison had the papers tight to obscure which was signed first and the order was not recorded.

name: south_dakota
sentence: On 29 December 1890, the massacre of the injured knee took place on the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Considered the last major armed conflict between the United States and the Lakota Sioux nation, the massacre resulted in the death of at least 146 Sioux, many of whom were women and children.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 31 U.S. soldiers were also killed during the conflict.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 1930s, several economic and climatic conditions combined with disastrous results for South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A lack of precipitation, extremely high temperatures and inappropriate cultivation techniques produced what was known as the Dust Bowl in South Dakota and several other plains states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The fertile soil was blown into massive dust storms, and several crops were completely ruined.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The experiences of the Dust Bowl, coupled with the seizure of local banks and the general economic effects of the Great Depression, led to the departure of many Dakotas from the south of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The population of South Dakota declined by more than 7% between 1930 and 1940.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Economic stability returned with the entry of the United States into the Second World War in 1941, when demand for the state's agricultural and industrial products increased as the nation mobilized for the war.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1944, the Pick–Sloan Plan was passed by the U.S. Congress as part of the 1944 Flood Control Act, resulting in the construction of six major dams on the Missouri River, four of which are at least partially located in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The fight against floods, hydropower and recreational activities such as boating and fishing are offered by dams and their reservoirs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In recent decades, South Dakota has moved from an agricultural-dominated state to a more diversified state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The tourism industry has grown considerably since the completion of the interstate system in the 1960s, with Black Hills becoming an increasingly important destination.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The financial services industry also began to grow in the state, with the transfer of Citibank's credit card transactions from New York to Sioux Falls in 1981, a move that was followed by several other financial companies.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota was the first state to eliminate interest ceilings.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007, the recently closed Homestake gold mine near Lead was selected as the site for a new underground research facility, the Deep Underground Science and Engineering Laboratory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite the increase in the population of the State and recent economic development, many rural areas have struggled over the past 50 years with the decline of the local population and the emigration of educated young adults to major cities in South Dakota, such as Rapid City or Sioux Falls, or to other states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mechanization and consolidation of agriculture have contributed significantly to the reduction in the number of small family farms and the resulting economic and demographic difficulties for rural cities.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, the state often ranks first for its way of life, and Gallup's 2018 Well-Being Index named South Dakota the happiest and healthier state in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the South Dakota population was 884,659 as of July 1, 2019, an 8.66 per cent increase over the 2010 U.S. census, while only North Dakota, Alaska, Vermont and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2019, South Dakota had an estimated population of 884,659, an increase of 70,479, or 8.66%, since 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 7.3% of the South Dakota population was under 5 years of age, 24% under 18 years of age and 14.3% at least 65 years of age.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Women accounted for about 50.2 per cent of the population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: According to the 2000 census, South Dakota was the fifth lowest of the nation in terms of population and population density.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Of South Dakota's inhabitants, 65.7 per cent were born in South Dakota, 31.4 per cent were born in another U.S. state, 0.6 per cent were born in Puerto Rico, the U.S. islands or abroad, and 2.3 per cent were born in another country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The population centre of South Dakota is located in Buffalo County, in the unincorporated county seat of Gann Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: According to the 2010 census, the racial composition of the population was as follows:

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ethnically, 2.7% of the population of South Dakota was of Hispanic, Latin or Spanish origin (they may be of any race).

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2011, 25.4% of the population of South Dakota were minorities, which means that they had at least one non-Hispanic white parent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2000, the five largest ancestry groups in South Dakota were German (40.7%), Norwegian (15.3%), Irish (10.4%), Native Americans (8.3%), and English (7.1%).

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Germans are the largest ancestry group in most parts of the state, particularly in the East River (east of Missouri), although there are also large Scandinavian populations in some counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has the largest population of Hutterites, a community group of Anabaptists who emigrated in 1874 from Europe, mainly from German-speaking regions.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians, largely Lakota, Dakota and Nakota (Sioux), predominate in several counties and account for 20% of the West River population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The seven major Indian reserves of the state occupy a very small area compared to the former Sioux Great Reserve of West River, which the federal government had previously allocated to the Sioux tribes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has the third largest proportion of Amerindians in any state, behind Alaska and New Mexico.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Five of the state's counties are within the boundaries of sovereign Indian reserves.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Because of the limitations of climate and land and the isolation of urban areas with higher employment opportunities, the standard of living on many South Dakota reserves is often well below the national average; Ziebach County ranked as the poorest of the nation in 2009.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The unemployment rate in Fort Thompson, Crow Creek Reserve, is 70 per cent, and 21 per cent of households do not have basic plumbing or cooking equipment.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A 1995 study by the U.S. Census Bureau found that 58% of households on the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve did not have a telephone.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The isolation of reserves also prevents their ability to generate income from gambling casinos, an avenue that has proved profitable for many tribes closer to urban centres.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1995, the legislator passed a law to make English the "common language" of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since 2019, "the language of the Great Sioux Nation, consisting of three dialects, Dakota, Lakota and Nakota" is an official language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2000 census, 1.90 per cent of the population aged 5 or older speak German at home, 1.51 per cent speak Lakota or Dakota and 1.43 per cent speak Spanish.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2010, 93.46 per cent (692,504) of South Dakota residents aged 5 years and older spoke English as their primary language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 6.54% of the population speak a language other than English.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 2.06 % (15,292) of the population speak Spanish, 1.39 % (10,282) speak Dakota and 1.37% (10,140) speak German.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other spoken languages include Vietnamese (0.16 per cent), Chinese (0.12 per cent) and Russian (0.10 per cent).

name: south_dakota
sentence: In recent decades, the population of many rural areas has declined in South Dakota, as in other states of the Great Plains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The change was described as "rural leakage" as family farming declined.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Young people moved to cities to find another job.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This trend has continued in recent years, with 30 counties in South Dakota losing their population between the 1990 and 2000 censuses.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During this period, nine counties experienced a population loss of more than 10 per cent, with Harding County in the northwest corner of the state losing nearly 19 per cent of its population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The low birth rate and lack of young immigrants have led to an increase in the median age of many of these counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 24 counties, at least 20% of the population is over the age of 65, compared to a national rate of 12.8%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, the effect of rural leakage has not been equally widespread in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although most rural counties and small towns have lost their population, the Sioux Falls area, the largest counties along Interstate 29, the Black Hills and many Indian reserves have all increased in population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As the reserves exercised more sovereignty, some Sioux returned from urban areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Lincoln County near Sioux Falls was the fastest growing seventh (percentage) county in the United States in 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Growth in these areas offset losses in the rest of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The total population of South Dakota continues to grow steadily, although at a slower rate than the national average.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The largest denominations by number of adherents in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 148,883 members, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA) with 112,649 members, and the United Methodist Church (UMC) with 36,020 members.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (ELCA and UMC are specific names in the broader terms "Lutheran" and "methodist", respectively.

name: south_dakota
sentence: )The results of a 2001 survey in which South Dakotas were invited to identify their religion include:

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota's current gross national product in 2010 was $39.8 billion, the fifth lowest state output in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Per capita personal income was $38,865 in 2010, ranked 25th in the United States, and 12.5 per cent of the population was below the poverty line in 2008.The list of the CNBC's Top States for Business for 2010 recognized South Dakota as the seventh best state of the nation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In July 2011, the state unemployment rate was 4.7%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The services sector is the largest economic contributor to South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This sector includes the retail, finance and health care sectors.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Citibank, which was the largest bank holding company in the United States at one time, established domestic banking operations in South Dakota in 1981 in order to take advantage of favourable banking rules.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Public spending is another important segment of the government economy, accounting for more than 10 per cent of gross national product.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ellsworth Air Force Base, near Rapid City, is the second-largest employer in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Agriculture has always been an essential component of the South Dakota economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although other industries have experienced rapid growth in recent decades, agricultural production remains very important for the state economy, particularly in rural areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five most valuable agricultural products in South Dakota are cattle, maize, soybeans, wheat and pigs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Agriculture-related industries such as meat packaging and ethanol production also have a significant economic impact on the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the sixth-largest ethanol producer in the nation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Tourism is another important sector of the South Dakota economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many travel to see the attractions of the state, especially those of the Black Hills area, such as the historic Deadwood, Rushmore Mount, and neighbouring national and state parks.

name: south_dakota
sentence: One of the most important tourist events in the state is the annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five-day event attracted more than 739,000 participants in 2015; considering the state has a total population of 850,000.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2006, tourism provided some 33,000 jobs in the state and contributed more than $2 billion to the South Dakota economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has 83,609 miles (134,556 km) of highways, roads and streets, as well as 679 miles (1,093 km) of interstate highways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two major interstates cross South Dakota: Interstate 90, which crosses the southern half of the state to the east and west, and Interstate 29, which extends north and south in the eastern part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Corridor I-29 has generally higher population and economic growth rates than eastern South Dakota regions farther from the interstate.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Also in the state are the shorter Interstate 190, a spur in the center of Rapid City, and 229, a loop around the south and east of Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several major American roads cross the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: U.S. roads 12, 14, 16, 18 and 212 travel east and west, while U.S. roads 81, 83, 85 and 281 travel north and south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota and Montana are the only states that share a land border that is not crossed by an asphalt road.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota contains two national routes of passage.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Peter Norbeck National Scenic Byway is located in the Black Hills, while the Native American Scenic Byway runs along the Missouri River in the north central part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other scenic passages include Badlands Loop Scenic Byway, the Spearfish Canyon Scenic Byway, and the Wildlife Loop Road Scenic Byway.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since the mid-19th century, railways have played an important role in transportation in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Some 7,110 kilometres of railway were built in South Dakota in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, but only 2,960 kilometres are active.

name: south_dakota
sentence: BNSF Railway is the largest railway in South Dakota; Rapid City, Pierre and Eastern Railroad (formerly Dakota, Minnesota and East) is the other major carrier in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other government carriers include Dakota Southern Railway, Dakota and Iowa Railroad, Ellis and Eastern Railroad, Sunfloor Railroad, Canadian Pacific Railway and Sisseton Milbank Railroad.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rail transportation in the state is mainly freight, but there are two historic railways for passengers: Black Hills Central and Prairie Village, Herman and Milwaukee.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, South Dakota is one of two contiguous states that lack Amtrak service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (South Dakota is the only contiguous state that has ever had Amtrak—Wyoming was served by the San Francisco Zephyr and Pioneer.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: The main commercial airports in South Dakota in terms of passenger traffic are Sioux Falls Regional Airport and Rapid City Regional Airport.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Delta Air Lines, Frontier Airlines and Allegiant Airlines, as well as the suburban airlines that use the affiliate brand with the major airlines, serve the two largest airports.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several other government cities also have commercial air services: Aberdeen Regional Airport, Pierre Regional Airport and Watertown Regional Airport, some of which are funded by the Essential Air Service program.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Like other U.S. states, the structure of the South Dakota government follows the same separation of powers as the federal government, with executive, legislative and judicial powers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The structure of state government is defined in the Constitution of South Dakota, the highest law of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Constitution may be amended by a majority vote of both Houses of Parliament or by the initiative of the voters.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Governor of South Dakota occupies the executive of the state government.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The current governor is Kristi Noem, a Republican.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Constitution of the State gives the Governor the power to sign laws or bills on the veto adopted by the legislature of the State, to exercise the functions of Commander-in-Chief of the National Guard of South Dakota, to appoint a cabinet and to commute criminal penalties or to pardon persons convicted of crimes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Governor shall be appointed for a term of four years and shall not serve more than two consecutive terms.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The legislative power of the State consists of two bodies, the 35-member Senate and the 70-member House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is divided into 35 legislative districts, voters elect two representatives and one senator per district.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The legislature meets for an annual session that begins on the second Tuesday in January and lasts 30 days.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The judicial branch is composed of several levels.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The State Supreme Court, consisting of four judges and one chief justice, is the highest court in the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the Supreme Court are circuit courts.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the circuit courts are the courts of first instance, which deal with criminal and civil cases of lesser importance.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2005, South Dakota had the lowest domestic tax rate in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crown does not collect personal or corporate income tax, estate tax or taxes on intangible personal property.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The State's sales tax rate is 4.5%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Various localities have local levies, so in some regions the rate is 6%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state sales tax does not apply to Indian sales on Indian reserves, but many reserves have a pact with the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: On-reserve businesses collect the tax and government refunds from Indian tribes the percentage of sales tax collected in relation to the ratio of the Indian population to the total population in the affected county or region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ad valorem property taxes are local taxes and are an important source of funding for school systems, counties, municipalities and other local governments.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota Special Tax Division regulates certain taxes, including cigarette and alcohol taxes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is represented at the federal level by Senator John Thune, Senator Mike Rounds and representative Dusty Johnson.

name: south_dakota
sentence: All three are Republicans.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is one of seven states with only one seat in the United States House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the United States presidential elections, South Dakota was given three out of 538 votes in the Electoral College.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As in all other states with the exception of the neighbouring Maine and Nebraska, South Dakota electoral votes are granted in a win-win-all system.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota policy is generally dominated by the Republican Party.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since the creation of the state, the Republicans have won state elections in all but five presidential elections: 1896, 1912 (by the Progressive Party of Theodore Roosevelt), 1932, 1936 and 1964.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (Democrat George McGovern, from South Dakota, did not bear his original status in 1972.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Only Alaska was transported fewer times by a democrat.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In addition, a democrat has not won the post of governor since 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2016, the Republicans hold a 15% registration advantage over the Democrats and hold large majorities in the House of State and the Senator of State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite the general republican and conservative tendencies of the state, Democrats have been successful in various state-wide elections, including those attended by representatives of the South Dakota Congress in Washington.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians have become more active in state and county electoral policy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2002 election, the American Indian vote held Tim Johnson as a democratic candidate with a margin of 532 votes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Until his election defeat in 2004, Senator Tom Daschle was the Senators' minority leader (and briefly his majority leader during the democratic control of the Senators in 2001–2002).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other prominent South Dakota Democrats include former presidential candidates George McGovern and Hubert Humphrey.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2016, South Dakota voted for Republican candidate Donald Trump compared to democratic candidate Hillary Clinton with a 30% margin.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2018, Republican MP Kristi Noem defeated Democrat Billie Sutton in the Liberal election by a small margin, and Republican Dusty Johnson defeated Democrat Tim Bjorkman for sitting in the US House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Contemporary political issues in South Dakota include the costs and benefits of the state lottery, the relatively low ranking of South Dakota in education spending (especially teachers' compensation — recently, the state sales tax has been increased from 4% to 4.5% to fund an increase in teachers' remuneration), and recent legislative and electoral attempts to ban abortion in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A bill supported by the Republicans passed in March 2019 requires all public schools to display "In God we trust" in a prominent place.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota culture reflects the American, rural, western and European roots of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of annual events celebrating the state's ethnic and historical heritage take place around the state, such as Days of '76 in Deadwood, Czech Days in Tabor, and the annual festivities of St. Patrick and Cinco de Mayo in Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The various tribes hold many annual pow wows on their reserves throughout the state, to which non-indigenous Americans are sometimes invited.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Custer State Park holds an annual Buffalo Roundup, where horse volunteers gather the park's herd of about 1,500 bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk (Lakota) was a medical and heyokha man whose life extended to the transition to reservations.

name: south_dakota
sentence: His stories of the Indian War movement and 19th-century phantom dance, as well as his deep thoughts on personal visions and Amerindian religion, formed the basis of the book Black Elk Speaks, first published in 1932.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (In several editions, a first annotated edition was published in 2008.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Paul Goble, author and illustrator of award-winning children's books, was based in the Black Hills in 1977.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Laura Ingalls Wilder, whose semi-autobiographical books are based on her experiences as a child and young adult at the border, is one of the most well-known writers in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: She drew from her life from a house near De Smet to found five of her novels: By the Shores of Silver Lake, The Long Winter, Little Town on the Prairie, This Happy Golden Years and The First Four Years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: They gained renewed popularity in the United States when Little House on the Prairie was adapted and produced as a television series in 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Wilder's daughter, Rose Wilder Lane, who became a well-known writer in his own right, was born near De Smet in 1886.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has also produced several notable artists.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harvey Dunn grew up on a house near Manchester in the late 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While Dunn worked most of his career as a commercial illustrator, his most famous works showed various scenes of border life; he finished those near the end of his career.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Oscar Howe (Crow) was born on Crow Creek Indian Reserve and won fame for his watercolour paintings.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Howe was one of the first Amerindian painters to adopt techniques and styles strongly influenced by the abstraction movement of the mid-20th century, rather than relying on traditional Amerindian styles.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Terry Redlin, originally from Watertown, is an accomplished painter of rural scenes and wildlife.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many of his works are exhibited at the Redlin Art Center in Watertown.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sioux Falls is the largest city in South Dakota, with a population of 153,888 in 2010, and a metropolitan area of 238,122 inhabitants.The city, founded in 1856, is located in the southeast corner of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Retail, finance and health care became more important in Sioux Falls, where the economy was originally focused on agro-industry and careers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City, with a population of 67,956 and a metropolitan area of 124,766, is the second largest city in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is located at the eastern end of the Black Hills and was founded in 1876.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City's economy is largely based on tourism and defence spending, due to the proximity of many tourist attractions in the Black Hills and Ellsworth Air Force Base.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Aberdeen (26,091), Brookings (22,056), Watertown (21,482), Mitchell (15,254), Yankton (14,454), Pierre (13,646), Huron (12,592) and Vermillion (10,571).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Pierre is the capital of the state and Brookings and Vermillion are the sites of the two largest universities in the state (South Dakota State University and South Dakota University, respectively).

name: south_dakota
sentence: With a population of about 14,000, Pierre is the second smallest state capital in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Of the ten largest cities in the state, only the fast city is west of Missouri.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first South Dakota newspaper, the Democratic Dakota, began publishing in Yankton in 1858.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Today, the largest newspaper in the state is the Sioux Falls Argus Leader, with a Sunday draw of 63,701 and a weekday draw of 44,334.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Rapid City Journal, with a Sunday draw of 32,638 and a weekday draw of 27,827, is the second largest newspaper in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The other four state newspapers are Aberdeen American News, Watertown Public Opinion, Huron Plainsman and Brookings Register.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1981, Tim Giago founded the Lakota Times as a newspaper for the local American Indian community on the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This newspaper, now published in New York and known as Indian Country Today, is available in all states of the country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Sioux City Journal also covers parts of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Nine television stations are broadcast in South Dakota; South Dakota public television is broadcast in several parts of the State, while the other stations are broadcast by Sioux Falls or Rapid City.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The two largest television markets in South Dakota are Sioux Falls-Mitchell, with an audience of 246,020 people, and Rapid City, with an audience of 91,070 people.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Both markets rank 114th and 177th respectively in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first state television station, KELO-TV, began broadcasting in Sioux Falls in 1953.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Among the first programs of KELO, Captain 11, an afternoon children's program.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Captain 11 ran from 1955 to 1996, making it the longest children's television program in the country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of South Dakotas are famous for their work on television and publishing.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The former anchor and author of NBC Nightly News Tom Brokaw is from Webster and Yankton, USA Today the founder Al Neuharth was from Eureka and Alpena, the game host Bob Barker spent much of his childhood in Mission, and entertainment animators Pat O'Brien and Mary Hart are from Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2006, there were 136,872 students enrolled in primary and secondary schools in South Dakota, of whom 120,278 were enrolled in the public school system.

name: south_dakota
sentence: There are 703 public schools in 168 school districts, giving South Dakota the largest number of schools per capita in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The current high school graduation rate is 89.9%, and the average TCA score is 21.8%, slightly higher than the national average of 21.1.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 89.8% of the adult population had at least one high school diploma and 25.8% had a bachelor's degree or more.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The average salary of teachers in South Dakota public schools of $36,674 in 2008 was the lowest in the nation (the national average was $52,308).

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007, South Dakota passed a law inspired by the Indian Education for All Act (1999) of Montana, which requires education on Amerindian tribal history, culture and heritage in all schools, from kindergarten to college, in order to increase the knowledge and appreciation of Indian culture among all residents of the state, and to enhance understanding of Indian students' contributions to their own cultures.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Council of Regents of South Dakota, whose members are appointed by the Governor, controls the six public universities in the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota State University (SDSU) in Brookings is the largest university in the state with a enrolment rate of 12,831.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The University of South Dakota (USD), located in Vermillion, is the oldest university in the state and has the only faculty of law and medicine in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota also has several private universities, the most important of which is the Augustana University in Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Due to its small population, South Dakota does not host large professional league sports franchises.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state has minor leagues and independent leagues that all play in Sioux Falls or Rapid City.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sioux Falls has four teams: the Sioux Falls Canaris (baseball), the Sioux Falls Skyforce (basketball), the Sioux Falls Stampede (hockey) and the Sioux Falls Storm (inside American football).

sentence: The area now known as Tennessee was first inhabited by the Paleo-Indians almost 12,000 years ago.

name: tennessee

name: tennessee
sentence: The first British colony in today's Tennessee was built in 1756 by settlers from the colony of South Carolina at Fort Loudoun, near the present Vonore.

sentence: On that date Fort Loudoun became the westmost British outpost.

sentence: The fort was designed by John William Gerard of Brahm and built by forces under the command of British captain Raymond Demeré.

sentence: Hostilities broke out between the British and the neighbour Overhill Cherokees, and a siege of Fort Loudoun ended with his surrender on 7 Aug. 1760.

name: tennessee
sentence: The next morning Captain Paul Demeré and a number of his men were killed in an ambush nearby, and most of the rest of the garrison was taken prisoner.

sentence: In the 1760s, long hunters from Virginia explored much of Eastern and Middle Tennessee, and the first permanent European settlers began to arrive at the end of the decade.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Constitution of the State of Tennessee, article I, section 31, stipulates that the starting point for the identification of the boundary is the extreme height of the stone mountain, at the point where the Virginia line intersects it, and leads essentially the extreme heights of the mountain ranges through the Appalachian Mountains separating North Carolina from Tennessee after the Amerindian cities of Cowee and Old Chota, thence along the main ridge of said mountain (mount Unicoi) to the southern boundary of the State; all the territory, lands and waters to the west of said line are included within the limits and limits of the newly formed state of Tennessee.

sentence: The oldest rocks in Texas date from Mesoproterozoic and are about 1,600 million years old.

sentence: It is the buried ridge of the Appalachian-Ouachita Mountains area of Pennsylvania's continental collision.

name: texas

name: texas
sentence: Generally prohibited in the West in general, corporal punishment in schools is not unusual in more conservative rural areas of the state, with 28,569 public school students paddling at least once, according to government data for the 2011-2012 school year.

name: texas
sentence: In Texas, the rate of corporal punishment in school is exceeded only by Mississippi, Alabama and Arkansas.

name: texas
sentence: The two most recognized leading universities in the state are the University of Texas in Austin and the University of A&M in Texas, ranked 21st and 41st best universities in the country, respectively, according to the latest 2020 report from the Centre for World University Rankings.

name: texas

sentence: The Texas Higher Education Coordination Council ranks state public universities in three distinct levels:

sentence: Texas's Bill 588, a controversial alternative in Texas, guarantees Texas students who have graduated in the 10 per cent of their high school class the automatic admission to state-funded universities.

name: texas
sentence: The bill encourages demographic diversity while trying to avoid problems arising from Hopwood v. Texas (1996).

name: texas
sentence: Thirty-six (36) separate and distinct public universities exist in Texas, 32 of which belong to one of the six state university systems.

name: texas
sentence: The discovery of minerals on the lands of the Permanent University Fund, particularly oil, contributed to the rapid growth of the two largest university systems in the state: the University of Texas system and the Texas A and M system.

name: texas
sentence: The other four academic systems: the University of Houston system, the University of Northern Texas system, the State of Texas system and the Texas technical system are not funded by the Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The Carnegie Foundation ranks four of Texas's universities as Tier 1 research institutions: the University of Texas at Austin, the University of A&M in Texas, the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas at Austin and the University of Texas A&M are the flagship universities of the University of Texas System and Texas A&M University System, respectively.

name: texas
sentence: Both have been established under the Texas Constitution and hold interests in the Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The State has endeavoured to increase the number of flagship universities by raising some of its seven institutions designated as "emerging research universities".

name: texas
sentence: The two that should first emerge are the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas, probably in this order according to the discussions on the floor of the 82nd Texas legislature.

name: texas
sentence: The State is home to various private institutions of higher education, ranging from liberal arts colleges to a high-level research university recognized at the national level.

name: texas
sentence: Rice University in Houston is one of the leading universities of teaching and research in the United States and is ranked 17th best university in the country by US News & World Report.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity University, a private university, mainly undergraduate in liberal arts in San Antonio, ranked first among the universities that awarded mainly Bachelors and Masters degrees in the Western United States for 20 consecutive years by US News.

name: texas

sentence: The University of Texas hosts three presidential libraries: the George Bush Presidential Library at A&M University in Texas, the Library and the Lyndon Baines Johnson Museum at the University of Texas in Austin, and the George W. Bush Presidential Library at the South Methodist University.

name: texas
sentence: Despite the concentration of elite medical centers in the state, the Commonwealth Fund ranks Texas's health care system third in the country.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ranks close to the last in terms of access to health care, quality of care, avoidable hospital spending, and equity among the various groups.

name: texas
sentence: Causes of poor state ranking include politics, high poverty and the highest rate of illegal immigration to the nation.

name: texas
sentence: In May 2006, Texas launched the "Red Code" program in response to the report, with the state accounting for 25.1 per cent of the population without health insurance, the largest proportion in the country.

name: texas
sentence: The Trust for America's Health ranked Texas 15th in terms of adult obesity, with 27.2% of the state population being obese.

name: texas
sentence: The 2008 male obesity survey ranked four cities in Texas among the top 25 cities in America; Houston ranked 6th, Dallas 7th, El Paso 8th and Arlington 14th.

name: texas
sentence: Texas had only one city (Austin, 21st) in the top 25 "most interesting cities" in America.

name: texas
sentence: The same survey positively assessed the government's obesity initiatives with a "B+".

name: texas
sentence: The State ranks forty-second in the percentage of residents who practice regular exercise according to a 2007 study.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the highest maternal mortality rate in the developed world, and the death rate of women in Texas due to pregnancy-related complications doubled from 2010 to 2014, reaching 23.8 per 100,000.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has many elite medical research centers.

sentence: The State has nine medical schools, three dental schools and two optometry schools.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) laboratories: one at the University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB) in Galveston, and the other at the Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research in San Antonio, BSL-4's first private laboratory in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Medical Center in Houston holds the world's largest concentration of research and health care institutions, with 47 member institutions.

sentence: The Texas Medical Center performs the most heart transplants in the world.

sentence: The University of Texas Cancer Centre M.D. Anderson in Houston is a well-known academic institution focused on the care, research, education and prevention of cancer patients.

sentence: San Antonio's South Texas Medical Center facilities rank sixth in the impact of clinical research in the United States.

sentence: The institution's Faculty of Medicine employs the largest number of Nobel laureates in the world.

sentence: The Texans have always had difficulty crossing Texas due to the large size and rugged terrain of the state.

sentence: Texas offset by the construction of the largest U.S. road and rail networks.

name: texas
sentence: The regulatory authority, the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), maintains the state's vast highway network, and regulates aviation and public transportation.

name: texas
sentence: The State is an important transport centre.

name: texas
sentence: In the Dallas/Fort Worth region, trucks can reach 93 per cent of the country's population in 48 hours and 37 per cent in 24 hours.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 33 foreign trade zones (FTZs), the nation's largest.

name: texas
sentence: In 2004, a combined total of $298 billion in goods transited through the Texas TFAs.

name: texas
sentence: The first highway in Texas was the Gulf Highway, opened in 1948 in Houston.

name: texas
sentence: In 2005, 79,535 miles (127,999 km) of public road crossed Texas (instead of 71,000 miles (114,263 km) in 1984).

name: texas
sentence: To finance the recent growth of state highways, Texas has 17 toll roads (see list) with several additional toll routes proposed.

name: texas
sentence: In central Texas, the southern portion of the State Highway 130 toll road has a speed limit of 85 miles per hour (137 km/h), the highest in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: All of Texas's federal and state highways are paved.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 730 airports, the second in any state of the country.

name: texas
sentence: Larger in Texas by size and passengers served, the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW) is the second largest by region in the United States and the fourth largest in the world with 18,076 acres (73.15 km2).

name: texas
sentence: In traffic, DFW airport is the busiest in the state, the fourth busiest in the United States, and sixth in the world.

name: texas
sentence: American Airlines Group, the American / American Eagle, the world's largest airline in passenger miles and passenger fleet size, uses DFW as its largest and largest hub.

name: texas
sentence: It ranks as the largest airline in the United States by the number of passengers transported to the country per year and the largest airline in the world by the number of passengers transported.Southwest Airlines, headquartered in Dallas, operates in Dallas Love Field.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's second air facility is the George Bush Intercontinental Airport (IAH) in Houston.

name: texas
sentence: It served as the largest hub for the former Continental Airlines, which was based in Houston; it serves as the largest hub for United Airlines, the third largest airline in the world, per stolen passenger miles.

name: texas
sentence: IAH offers a service to the most Mexican destinations of any American airport.

name: texas
sentence: The other five largest airports in the state serve more than three million passengers each year, including Austin-Bergstrom International Airport, William P. Hobby Airport, San Antonio International Airport, Dallas Love Field and El Paso International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The smallest airport in the state to be designated as an international airport is Del Rio International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: Approximately 1,150 seaports provide the Texas coast with more than 1,600 km of canals.

name: texas
sentence: Ports employ nearly one million people and manage an average of 317 million tonnes.

sentence: Texas ports connect to the rest of the Atlantic coast of the United States with the Gulf of the Intracoastal Waterway.

name: texas
sentence: The port of Houston is now the busiest port in the United States in foreign tonnage, the second in total tonnage and the tenth in the world in tonnage.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Canal extends 160 metres wide by 14 metres deep and 80 kilometres long.

name: texas
sentence: Part of the state's cowboy tradition is derived from the large livestock campaigns that its herders organized in the 19th century to drive cattle to the railways and markets of Kansas, for the expedition to the East.

name: texas
sentence: Cities along the way, such as Baxter Springs, Kansas' first cow town, have developed to take care of seasonal workers and tens of thousands of cattle.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway to operate in Texas was the Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado Railway, which opened in August 1853.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway to enter Texas from the north, completed in 1872, was the Missouri–Kansas–Texas Railroad.

name: texas
sentence: With increased access to the railway, farmers did not have to take their cattle to the Midwest and shipped beef from Texas.

name: texas
sentence: This has led to a decline in the economy of cow towns.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1911, Texas has been leading the nation on miles of railway within the state.

name: texas
sentence: The length of the Texas Railway peaked in 1932 at 17,078 miles (27,484 km), but decreased to 14,006 miles (35,540 km) in 2000.

name: texas
sentence: Although the Texas Railway Commission initially regulated the state railways, in 2005 the State reallocated these rights to TxDOT.

name: texas
sentence: In the Dallas-Fort Worth area, three public transit organizations provide rail service: Dallas Area Rapid Transit (DART), Denton County Transportation Authority (DCTA) and Trinity Metro.

sentence: DART began operating the first light rail system in the southwestern United States in 1996.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Railway Express (TRE) suburban rail service, which connects Fort Worth and Dallas, is provided by Trinity Metro and DART.

sentence: Trinity Metro also operates the TEXRail suburban railway line, connecting downtown Fort Worth and Northeast Tarrant County to DFW Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The commuter A train line operated by DCTA serves as an extension of the DART Green Line in Denton County.

name: texas
sentence: In the Austin area, the Capital Metropolitan Transportation Authority operates a suburban rail service known as Capital MetroRail to the northwest suburbs.

name: texas

name: texas
sentence: Amtrak offers Texas a limited toll rail service.

name: texas
sentence: Three regular routes serve the state: the Texas Eagle daily (Chicago–San Antonio), the semi-monthly Sunset Limited (New Orleans–Los Angeles), with stops in Texas, and the Heartland Flyer daily (Fort Worth–Oklahoma City).

name: texas
sentence: Texas can have one of the country's first high-speed lines.

name: texas
sentence: The current Texas Constitution was adopted in 1876.

name: texas
sentence: Like many States, it explicitly provides for a separation of powers.

name: texas
sentence: The State Bill of Rights is much larger than its federal Bill of Rights and contains Texas-specific provisions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a plural executive branch system limiting the power of the governor, which is a weak executive in comparison to other states.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of the Secretary of State, electors elect leaders independently, so candidates are directly accountable to the public, not to the Governor.

name: texas
sentence: This electoral system has led to the division of certain executive powers between the parties and has reduced the governor's ability to implement a program.

name: texas
sentence: When Republican President George W. Bush was governor of Texas, the state had a democratic lieutenant governor, Bob Bullock.

name: texas
sentence: Executive positions include the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor, the Comptroller of Public Accounts, the Land Commissioner, the Attorney General, the Commissioner of Agriculture, the Texas Railway Commission, the Council of State for Education and the Secretary of State.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas bicameral legislature consists of the House of Representatives, with 150 members, and one senator, with 31 members.

name: texas
sentence: The Speaker of the House directs the House, and the Lieutenant Governor, the senator.

name: texas
sentence: The legislature meets in ordinary session every two years for just over a hundred days, but the governor may request special sessions as often as desired (notably, the legislature cannot meet).

name: texas
sentence: The fiscal year of the State begins on 1 September.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's judiciary is one of the most complex in the United States, with many layers and overlapping jurisdictions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two courts of last resort: the Texas Supreme Court, for civil cases, and the Texas Criminal Court of Appeal.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of some municipal benches, partisan elections select judges at all levels of the judiciary; the governor fills vacancies by appointment.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is remarkable for its use of the death penalty, which has led to executions since the death penalty was reinstated in Gregg v. Georgia (see capital punishment in Texas).

name: texas
sentence: Texas Ranger Division of the Texas Department of Public Safety is a law enforcement agency within the jurisdiction of the state.

name: texas
sentence: Over the years, the Texas Rangers have investigated crimes ranging from murder to political corruption.

name: texas
sentence: They acted as riot police and inspectors, protected the governor of Texas, hunted fugitives and acted as a paramilitary force for both the republic and the state.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Rangers were created informally by Stephen F. Austin in 1823 and formally formalized in 1835.

name: texas
sentence: The Rangers were an integral part of several important events in Texas's history and some of the most well-known criminal cases in Old West history.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Constitution defines the responsibilities of county governments as agents of the state.

name: texas
sentence: The so-called Commissioners, the judges of the courts, are elected to serve as an administrative body.

name: texas
sentence: Most State cities, with more than 5,000 inhabitants, have autonomous governments.

name: texas
sentence: The vast majority of them have charters for the forms of council-managerial government, by which voters elect members of the council, who hire a director of a professional town as an operating agent.

sentence: In the 1870s, the White Democrats regained power in the Parliament of the biracial coalition at the end of the reconstruction.

sentence: At the beginning of the 20th century, Parliament passed bills to impose voting taxes, followed by white primaries; these measures effectively deprived most blacks, poor whites and Mexican Americans.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1890s, 100,000 Blacks voted in the state; in 1906, only 5,000 could vote.

sentence: As a result, the Democratic Party dominated Texas politics from the beginning of the century, imposing racial segregation and white supremacy.

name: texas
sentence: Although Texas was essentially a single-party state during this period and the Democratic Primary was considered "the real election," the Democratic Party had conservative and liberal factions, which became more pronounced after the New Deal.

name: texas
sentence: In addition, several factions of the party separated briefly in the 1930s and 1940s.

name: texas
sentence: The conservative white voters of the state began supporting candidates for the Republican presidency in the middle of the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: After this period, they also supported Republicans for local and state offices, and most whites became members of the Republican Party.

name: texas
sentence: The party also attracted some minorities, but many continued to vote for democratic candidates.

name: texas
sentence: The transition to the Republican Party is largely due to the fact that the Democratic Party became increasingly liberal during the 20th century, and thus increasingly uncontrollable with the average voter in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: As Texas was still a conservative state, voters turned to the GOP, which now more closely reflects their beliefs.

name: texas
sentence: The commentators also attributed this change to Republican political consultant Karl Rove, who managed numerous political campaigns in Texas in the 1980s and 1990s.

name: texas
sentence: Other reasons cited include the redistribution ordered by the court and the demographic change in relation to the Sun Belt that favored the Republican Party and conservatism.

name: texas
sentence: The reconfiguration of Congressional constituencies led by Republican Tom DeLay in 2003 in Texas was called by the New York Times "an extreme case of partisan Gerrymandering".

sentence: A group of democratic legislators, the "Texas Eleven", fled the state in an effort to abuse quorum to prevent the legislator from acting, but failed.

name: texas
sentence: The State had already redesigned after the 2000 census.

name: texas
sentence: Despite these efforts, the legislature has adopted a map strongly in favour of Republicans, based on 2000 data and ignoring the estimates of nearly a million new residents in the state since then.

name: texas
sentence: Career lawyers and analysts in the Department of Justice have opposed the plan as diluting the votes of African-American and Hispanic voters, but the political appointees have overtaken it and approved it.

name: texas
sentence: In League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry (2006), the National Supreme Court ruled in favour of the State (and Republicans).

name: texas
sentence: In the 2014 Texas election, the Tea Party movement made great progress, with many of the Tea Party's favourites elected to power, including Dan Patrick as Lieutenant Governor, Ken Paxton as Attorney General, as well as many other candidates including Conservative Republican Greg Abbott as Governor.

name: texas
sentence: Electors in Texas are leaning towards fiscal conservatism, while taking advantage of the enormous federal investment in the state in military and other facilities obtained by the strength of the South Solid in the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: They also tend to have conservative social values.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1980, most voters in Texas have supported Republican presidential candidates.

name: texas
sentence: In 2000 and 2004, Republican George W. Bush won Texas with 59.3 percent and 60.1 percent respectively, partly because of his status as "preferential son" as former state governor.

name: texas
sentence: John McCain won the state in 2008, but with a lower margin of victory compared to Bush at 55 percent of the vote.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, Dallas, Houston and San Antonio systematically focus on democracy in local and state-wide elections.

name: texas
sentence: The demographic evolution of the state can lead to a change in its overall political alignment, as a majority of black and Hispanic/Latino voters support the Democratic Party.

name: texas
sentence: Residents of counties along the Rio Grande, closer to the border between Mexico and the United States, where there are many Latin American residents, generally vote for Democratic Party candidates, while most other rural and suburban areas of Texas voted for Republican Party candidates.

name: texas
sentence: As of the 2014 general election, a large majority of the members of the U.S. Texas House delegation are Republicans, as well as the two United States.

sentence: At the 114th Congress of the United States, of the 36 congressional districts in Texas, 24 are held by the Republicans and 11 by the Democrats.

sentence: Since 1994, the Texans have not elected a Democrat in a state-wide office.

sentence: The state's democratic voters are mainly Liberal and minority groups from Austin, Beaumont, Dallas, El Paso, Houston and San Antonio, as well as minority voters in eastern and southern Texas.
