name: texas
sentence: Texas has a reputation for very severe criminal punishment for criminal offences.

name: texas
sentence: It is one of the 32 states that use capital punishment, and since the Supreme Court of the United States allowed capital punishment to resume in 1976, 40 per cent of all United States executions took place in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: In 2008, Texas had the fourth highest incarceration rate in the United States.There were also strong self-defence laws, which allowed citizens to use lethal force to defend themselves, their families or their property.

name: texas
sentence: While American football has long been considered the "king" in the state, Texans enjoy a wide variety of sports.

name: texas
sentence: Texans can encourage a plethora of professional sports teams.

name: texas
sentence: In the four major professional leagues, Texas has two NFL teams (the Dallas Cowboys and the Houston Texans), two major league baseball teams (the Houston Astros and the Texas Rangers), three NBA teams (the San Antonio Spurs, the Houston Rockets and the Dallas Mavericks) and one National Hockey League team (the Dallas Stars).

name: texas
sentence: The Dallas–Fort Worth Metroplex is one of the twelve metropolitan areas in the United States that host sports teams from all the professional leagues of the "four grandes".

name: texas
sentence: Apart from the Big Four, Texas also has a WNBA team (the Dallas Wings) and two Major League Soccer teams (the Houston Dynamo and FC Dallas).

name: texas
sentence: College athletics has a profound significance in Texas culture, especially football.

name: texas
sentence: The State has 12 schools in the I-FBS Division, the largest in the country.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state universities, Baylor Bears, Texas Longhorns, TCU Horned Frogs, and Texas Tech Red Raiders, participate in the Great 12 Conference.

name: texas
sentence: Texas A&M Aggies left the Big 12 and joined the South East Conference in 2012, which led the Big 12 to invite the TCU to join; the TCU was previously at the Mountain West Conference.

name: texas
sentence: Houston Cougars and SMU Mustangs participate in the American Athletics Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Bobcats of the State of Texas and the Mavericks of the UT Arlington participate in the Sun Belt conference.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state's schools claim at least one national football championship: Texas Longhorns, Texas A&M Aggies, TCU Horned Frogs and SMU Mustangs.

name: texas
sentence: According to an I-A Division investigation, there is a rivalry between the University of Oklahoma and the University of Texas at Austin, the Red River Shootout, ranks third in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: The horned frogs of TCU and the Mustangs of the SMU also share a rivalry and participate each year in the battle for the Iron Skullet.

name: texas
sentence: A fierce rivalry, the Lone Star Showdown, also exists between the two largest universities in the state, Texas A&M University and the University of Texas at Austin.

name: texas
sentence: The athletic part of the Lone Star Showdown rivalry was suspended after the Texas A&Ms joined the Southeast Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The University Interscholastic League (UIL) organizes most of the competitions in primary and secondary schools.

name: texas
sentence: The events organized by UIL include athletics competitions (the most popular being secondary football) as well as artistic and academic disciplines.

name: texas
sentence: Texans also like rodeo.

name: texas
sentence: The first rodeo in the world was hosted in Pecos, Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The annual Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo is the largest rodeo in the world.

name: texas
sentence: It starts with hikes from several points throughout the state that meet in Reliant Park.

name: texas
sentence: The Southwest Exhibition and Livestock Fair in Fort Worth is the oldest rodeo in the history of the state in its annual events.

name: texas
sentence: Dallas hosts the Texas State Fair every year at Fair Park.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1997, Texas Motor Speedway has hosted annual races of the NASCAR Cup series and the IndyCar series.

name: texas
sentence: Since 2012, Austin's Circuit of the Americas has hosted a Formula 1 World Championship round – the first on a permanent road circuit in the United States since the 1980 Grand Prix at Watkins Glen International – as well as Grand Prix motorcycle races, FIA World Endurance Championship and United SportsCar Championship.

name: utah
sentence: Utah (YOO-tah, (listening) YOO-taw) is a state in the United States.

name: utah
sentence: It is bounded by Colorado to the east, Wyoming to the northeast, Idaho to the north, Arizona to the south, and Nevada to the west.

name: utah
sentence: It also touches a corner of New Mexico in the southeast.

name: utah
sentence: Of the fifty American states, Utah is the 13th largest by region; with a population of more than three million, it is the 30th most populated and the 11th least dense.

name: utah
sentence: Urban development is concentrated mainly in two regions: the Wasatch Front in the north-central part of the state, which is home to about two thirds of the population and includes the capital, Salt Lake City; and Washington County in the south, which has more than 170,000 inhabitants.

name: utah
sentence: Most of western Utah is located in the Great Basin.

name: utah
sentence: The territory of modern Utah has been inhabited by various indigenous groups for thousands of years, including the former Puebloans, Navajo and Ute.

name: utah
sentence: The Spaniards were the first Europeans to arrive in the mid-16th century, although the region's difficult geography and climate made it a peripheral part of New Spain and later Mexico.

name: utah
sentence: Even though it was part of Mexico, many early Utah settlers were American, especially Mormons fleeing the marginalization and persecution of the United States.

name: utah
sentence: After the war between Mexico and America, it is part of the territory of Utah, which includes what is now Colorado and Nevada.

name: utah
sentence: Disputes between the dominant Mormon community and the federal government delayed the admission of Utah as a state; it was only after the prohibition of polygamy that it was admitted as 45th in 1896.

name: utah
sentence: Just over half of all Uthahs are Mormons, the vast majority of whom are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Last-Day Saints (LDS Church), which has its global headquarters in Salt Lake City.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is the only state where the majority of the population belongs to a single church.

name: utah
sentence: The LDS Church greatly influences Uthah's culture, politics and daily life, although, since the 1990s, the state has become more religiously and secularly diverse.

name: utah
sentence: The state has a very diverse economy, with important sectors such as transportation, education, information and research technologies, government services, mining, and an important tourist destination for outdoor recreation.

name: utah
sentence: In 2013, the U.S. Census Bureau estimated that Utah had the largest population in all states.

name: utah
sentence: From 2000 to 2005, St. George was the fastest growing metropolitan area in the United States.

name: utah
sentence: Utah also has the highest median income and the lowest income inequality of all U.S. states.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 Gallup National Survey revealed that Utah was generally the "best future life" based on 13 forward-looking measures, including various economic, lifestyle and health-related measures.

name: utah
sentence: It is said that the name Utah derives from the name of the tribe Ute, which means "people of the mountains."

name: utah
sentence: However, no such word actually exists in the language of the Utes, and the Utes refer to themselves as Noochee.

name: utah
sentence: The meaning of Utes as "the mountain people" has been attributed to neighbouring Pueblo Indians, as well as to the word Apache Yuttahih, which means "the one who is higher" or "the ones who are higher".

name: utah
sentence: In Spanish, Youta was pronounced

name: utah
sentence: Thousands of years before the arrival of European explorers, the Puebloans Ancestral and the Fremont people lived in what is now called Utah, some of which spoke the languages of the Uto-Aztecan group.

name: utah
sentence: The ancestral Pueblo built their houses by excavations in the mountains, and the Fremonts built straw houses before disappearing from the area around the 15th century.

name: utah
sentence: Another group of Amerindians, Navajo, settled in the area around the 18th century.

name: utah
sentence: In the mid-18th century, other Uto-Aztecan tribes, including the Goshute, the Paiute, the Shoshone and the Ute people, also settled in the area.

name: utah
sentence: These five groups were present when the first European explorers arrived.

name: utah
sentence: The southern region of Utah was explored by the Spaniards in 1540, under the direction of Francisco Vázquez de Coronado, while searching for the legendary Cíbola.

name: utah
sentence: A group led by two Catholic priests – sometimes called the Domínguez-Escalante expedition – left Santa Fe in 1776 in the hope of finding a road to the Californian coast.

name: utah
sentence: The expedition travelled as far north as Lake Utah and met with Aboriginal people.

name: utah
sentence: The Spaniards made further explorations in the region, but were not interested in colonizing the region because of its desert character.

name: utah
sentence: In 1821, when Mexico gained independence from Spain, the region became known as part of its Alta California territory.

name: utah

name: utah

sentence: From the early 20th century, with the establishment of national parks such as Bryce Canyon National Park and Zion National Park, Utah became known for its natural beauty.

name: utah
sentence: The dry and powdery snow of the Wasatch chain is considered one of the best skiers in the world (the state license plate once claimed "the greatest snow on earth").

sentence: Salt Lake City won the 2002 Olympic Winter Games award, which greatly boosted the economy.

sentence: Ski resorts have gained popularity and many of the Olympic venues built along the Wasatch Front continue to be used for sporting events.

name: utah
sentence: In 1957, Utah established the Utah State Parks Commission with four parks.

name: utah
sentence: Today, Utah State Parks manage 43 parks and several undeveloped areas totalling more than 95,000 acres (380 km2) of land and more than 1,000,000 acres (4,000 km2) of water.

name: utah
sentence: Utah State Parks are scattered throughout Utah, from Bear Lake State Park on the Utah/Idaho border to Edge of the Cedars State Park Museum in the heart of the Four Corners area and everywhere in between.

name: utah

sentence: Transport management and urbanization are important issues in politics, as development consumes agricultural land and wild areas, and transportation is one of the main reasons for poor air quality in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is known for its natural diversity and is home to elements ranging from arid deserts with sand dunes to flourishing pine forests in mountain valleys.

name: utah
sentence: It is an rugged and geographically diverse state with the convergence of three distinct geological regions: the Rocky Mountains, the Great Basin and the Colorado Plateau.

name: utah
sentence: Utah covers an area of 84,899 m2 (219,890 km2).

name: utah
sentence: It is bordered by Idaho to the north, Wyoming to the north and east, Colorado to the east, only one point by New Mexico to the southeast, Arizona to the south and Nevada to the west.

name: utah
sentence: Only three U.S. states (Utah, Colorado and Wyoming) have exclusive latitude and longitude lines as their boundaries.

name: utah
sentence: One of the defining features of Utah is the variety of its terrain.

name: utah
sentence: In the middle of the northern third of the state is the Wasatch chain, which reaches heights of nearly 12,000 feet (3,700 m) above sea level.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is home to world-renowned ski resorts made popular by light, soft snow and winter storms that regularly accumulate up to three feet of it all night long.

name: utah
sentence: In the northeastern section of the state, from east to west, are the Uinta Mountains, which reach heights of more than 13,000 feet (4,000 m).

name: utah
sentence: The highest point in the state, Kings Peak, 13.528 feet (4.123 m), is in the Uinta Mountains.

name: utah
sentence: At the western base of the Wasatch Range is the Wasatch Front, a series of valleys and basins that house the most populated parts of the state.

name: utah
sentence: It extends approximately from the town of Brigham at the north end to Nephi at the south end.

name: utah
sentence: Approximately 75 per cent of the population of the state lives in this corridor, and population growth is rapid.

name: utah
sentence: Western Utah is mainly an arid desert with a basin and a range topography.

name: utah
sentence: The small mountain ranges and rugged terrain punctuate the landscape.

name: utah
sentence: The Bonneville Salt Flats are an exception, being relatively flat following the formation of the bed of the former Lake Bonneville.

name: utah
sentence: Great Salt Lake, Lake Utah, Lake Sevier and Rush Lake are all remnants of this former freshwater lake that once covered most of the Eastern Great Basin.

name: utah
sentence: To the west of Great Salt Lake, which extends to the Nevada border, lies the arid desert of Great Salt Lake.

name: utah
sentence: An exception to this aridity is the snake valley, which is (relatively) lush due to the large springs and wetlands fed by groundwater from snowmelt in the Snake chain, the Deep Creek chain and other high mountains west of the snake valley.

name: utah
sentence: Great Basin National Park is located just above the Nevada state line in the south of the Snake Range.

name: utah
sentence: One of the most impressive but least visited attractions in western Utah is Notch Peak, the highest limestone cliff in North America, located west of Delta.

name: utah
sentence: Most of the picturesque landscapes of the south and south-east (including the Colorado Plateau area) are sandstone, particularly Kayenta sandstone and Navajo sandstone.

name: utah
sentence: The Colorado River and its tributaries flow through sandstone, creating some of the most striking and wildest lands in the world (the area around the confluence of the Colorado and Green rivers was the last to be mapped in the lower 48 United States).

name: utah
sentence: Wind and rain have also carved soft sandstone over millions of years.

name: utah
sentence: Canyons, gulls, arches, pinnacles, buttocks, bluffs and mesas are common in south-central and southeastern Utah.

name: utah
sentence: This land is the central feature of state and federal protected national parks such as Arches, Bryce Canyon, Canyonlands, Capitol Reef and Zion, Cedar Breaks, Grand Staircase-Escalante, Hovenweep, and Natural Bridges National Monuments, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area (popular tourist destination site, Powell Lake), Dead Horse Point and Goblin Valley State Parks, and Monument Valley.

name: utah
sentence: The Navajo Nation also extends to southeastern Utah.

sentence: The southeast of Utah is also punctuated by distant mountain ranges, but raised La Sal, Abajo and Henry.

name: utah
sentence: The eastern Utah (northern quarter) is a high-altitude area covered mainly by plateaus and basins, in particular the Tavaputs plateau and the San Rafael swell, which remain largely inaccessible, and the Uinta basin, where the majority of the eastern Utah population lives.

name: utah
sentence: Economies are dominated by mining, oil shale, oil, natural gas drilling, livestock and recreation.

sentence: Much of Eastern Utah is part of the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reserve.

name: utah
sentence: Southwestern Utah is the lowest and warmest location in Utah.

sentence: It is known as Dixie de l'Utah because the first settlers were able to grow cotton there.

name: utah
sentence: The northernmost part of the Mojave Desert is also in this area.

name: utah
sentence: Dixie quickly became a popular leisure and retirement destination, and the population was growing rapidly.

name: utah
sentence: Although the Wasatch Mountains end at Mount Nebo near Nephi, a complex series of mountain ranges extend south of the southern end of the chain in the spine of Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Just north of Dixie and east of Cedar City is the highest ski resort in the state, Brian Head.

name: utah
sentence: Like most western and southwestern states, the federal government owns much of Utah's land.

name: utah
sentence: More than 70 percent of the land is either BLM land, Utah State Trustland, or US National Forest, USA National Park, US National Monument, National Recreation Area or US Wilderness Area.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is the only state where each county contains national forests.

name: utah
sentence: Utah has a dry, semi-arid climate in the desert, although its many mountains have a wide variety of climates, the highest points in the mountains of Uinta being above the wood line.

name: utah
sentence: Dry weather is a result of the state's location in the rain shadow of Sierra Nevada, California.

name: utah
sentence: Half of the east state is in the rain shadow of the Wasatch Mountains.

name: utah
sentence: The main source of precipitation for the state is the Pacific Ocean, usually on the way to major Pacific storms from October to May.

name: utah
sentence: In summer, the state, especially the south and east of Utah, is on the path to monsoon moisture from the Gulf of California.

name: utah
sentence: Most lowland areas receive less than 12 inches (305 mm) of precipitation per year, although corridor I-15, including the densely populated Wasatch Front, receives about 15 inches (381 mm).

name: utah
sentence: The Great Salt Lake Desert is the driest area in the state, with less than 5 inches (127 mm).

name: utah
sentence: Snowfall is common in all valleys, except in southern valleys.

name: utah
sentence: Although St. George receives only about 3 inches (76 mm) per year, Salt Lake City sees about 60 inches (1,524 mm), increased by snow from the Great Salt Lake effect, increasing total snowfall to the south, south-east and east of the lake.

name: utah
sentence: Some areas of the Wasatch range in the lake effect trail receive up to 500 inches (12,700 mm) per year.

name: utah
sentence: This micro-climate of increased snowfall from Great Salt Lake covers the entire vicinity of the lake.

name: utah
sentence: Cotton canyons adjacent to Salt Lake City are located in the right position to receive more precipitation from the lake.

name: utah
sentence: The ever-deep snowpowder led the Utah ski industry to adopt the slogan "The greatest snow on earth" in the 1980s.

name: utah
sentence: In winter, temperature inversions are a common phenomenon in the lower Utah basins and valleys, resulting in thick fog and fog that can last for weeks at a time, especially in the Uintah basin.

name: utah
sentence: Although at other times of the year its air quality is good, winter inversions give Salt Lake City one of the worst winter pollution in the country.

name: utah
sentence: Previous studies have shown a widespread decline in snow quantity above Utah, accompanied by a decrease in the snow-precipitation ratio, while anecdotal claims have been made that measured changes in Utah snow quantity are misleading and do not reflect actual changes.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 study found that the proportion of winter precipitation (January to March) falling as snow has decreased by nine percent over the last half century, a combined result of a significant increase in precipitation and a slight decrease in snowfall.

name: utah
sentence: Meanwhile, snow depth observed across Utah decreased and was accompanied by a steady decrease in snow cover and surface albedo.

name: utah
sentence: Weather systems likely to produce precipitation in Utah have decreased in number, with those that produce snowfall decreasing at a significantly higher rate.

name: utah
sentence: Utah's temperatures are extreme, with cold temperatures in winter due to its altitude, and very hot summers on a state-wide basis (with the exception of mountain areas and high mountain valleys).

name: utah
sentence: Utah is usually protected from large explosions of cold air by mountains to the north and east of the state, although large arctic explosions may occasionally reach the state.

name: utah
sentence: January average high temperatures range from about 30°F (−1°C) in some northern valleys to almost 55°F (13°C) in St. George.

name: utah
sentence: Temperatures below 0°F (−18°C) should be expected occasionally in most regions of the state in most years, although some regions often see it (for example, the city of Randolph has an average of about fifty days a year with such low temperatures).

name: utah
sentence: In July, average heights ranged from 85 to 100°F (29 to 38°C).

name: utah
sentence: However, low humidity and high elevation generally result in large temperature variations, resulting in cool nights on most summer days.

name: utah
sentence: The record temperature in Utah was 118°F (48°C), recorded south of St. George on July 4, 2007, and the low record was -69°F (−56°C), recorded at Peter Sinks in the Northern Bear Mountains of Utah on February 1, 1985.

name: utah
sentence: However, the record level for a inhabited site was −49°F (−45°C) at Woodruff on 12 December 1932.

name: utah
sentence: Like most of the Western United States, Utah has a few days of thunderstorms.

name: utah
sentence: On average, there are less than 40 days of stormy activity during the year, although these storms may be briefly intense when they occur.

name: utah
sentence: They are most likely to occur during the monsoon season, from mid-July to mid-September, particularly in southern and eastern Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Dry flashes and general dry weather often trigger forest fires in the summer, while intense thunderstorms can cause flash floods, especially in the rugged southern Utah terrain.

name: utah
sentence: Although spring is the wettest season in northern Utah, late summer is the wettest time for most of the south and east of the state.

name: utah
sentence: The tornadoes are uncommon in Utah, with an average of two striking the state each year, rarely more intense than the EF1.

name: utah
sentence: An exception to note, however, was the unprecedented F2 Salt Lake City Tornado that moved directly through downtown Salt Lake City on August 11, 1999, killing one person, wounding another sixty, and causing approximately $170 million in damage.

name: utah
sentence: The only other victim reported in Utah's history was a 7-year-old girl who was killed while camping in Summit County on July 6, 1884.

name: utah
sentence: The last tornado of the above intensity (E)F0 occurred on September 8, 2002, when an F2 tornado hit Manti.

name: utah
sentence: On 11 August 1993, an F3 tornado struck the Uinta Mountains north of Duchesne at an altitude of 10,500 feet (3,200 m), causing damage to a Scout camp.

name: utah
sentence: This is the strongest tornado ever recorded in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Utah has more than 600 vertebrate animals as well as numerous invertebrates and insects.

sentence: Predator mammals include brown and black bear, cougar, Canadian lynx, bobcat, fox (grey, red and kit), coyote, badger, grey wolf, black-footed ferret, mink, stoat, long-tailed weasel, raccoon and otter.

sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the Utah population was 3,205,958 as of July 1, 2019, an increase of 16.00 per cent over the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: virginia
sentence: Those who identify with the census as having "American ethnicity" are mainly English in origin, but have ancestors who have been in North America for so long that they simply choose to identify themselves as Americans.

sentence: Among English immigrants to Virginia in the 17th century, three quarters came as contract servants.

name: virginia
sentence: The largest minority group in Virginia are African Americans, which account for about one-fifth of the population.

name: virginia
sentence: Virginia was one of the main destinations of the Atlantic slave trade, and the first generations of men, women and child slaves were brought mainly from Angola and the Bight of Biafra.

name: virginia
sentence: The Igbo ethnic group of what is now southern Nigeria was the largest African group among the slaves in Virginia.

sentence: Although the black population was reduced by the Great Migration to the industrial cities of the North during the first half of the 20th century, since 1965 there has been a reverse migration of blacks returning southward.

sentence: English was adopted as the official language of the Commonwealth by legislation in 1981 and again in 1996, although the status is not prescribed by the Virginia Constitution.

sentence: Virginia is predominantly Christian and Protestant; Baptist denominations combined to form the largest group with approximately 26 percent of the population in 2014, and a total of approximately 763,655 members in 2010.

name: virginia
sentence: The Baptist denominational groups of Virginia include the Baptist General Association of Virginia, with approximately 1,400 member churches, which supports both the Southern Baptist Convention and the Moderate Baptist Fellowship Cooperative; and the Southern Baptist Conservatives of Virginia with over 500 affiliated churches, which supports the Southern Baptist Convention.

name: virginia
sentence: Roman Catholics are the second largest religious group with 673,853 members.

name: virginia
sentence: The Synod Virginia is responsible for the congregations of the Lutheran Church.

name: virginia
sentence: Presbyterian, Pentecostal, Congregational and Episcopalist members each accounted for less than two per cent of the population in 2010.

sentence: The episcopal diocese of Virginia, South Virginia and South West Virginia support the various episcopal churches.

sentence: Although Virginia's law allowed parishioners to determine their church membership, the diocese demanded the buildings and properties of secessionist churches.

sentence: Virginia's economy has a variety of sources of income, including local and federal government, military, agriculture and high technology.

sentence: The average government salary per job was 63,281, the 11th highest at the national level, and the gross domestic product (GDP) was $476.4 billion in 2018, the 13th highest among the U.S. states.

name: virginia
sentence: Prior to the March 2020 Coronavirus recession, Virginia had 4.36 million people employed with an unemployment rate of 2.9 per cent, but jobless claims due to the virus increased by more than 10 per cent in early April 2020, before leaving at 4.9 per cent in November, the 13th lowest in the country.

name: virginia
sentence: However, Virginia ranks first in terms of the timely review of unemployment benefits due to the pandemic.

sentence: Virginia has a median income of $72,600, 11th highest nationally, and a poverty rate of 10.7 per cent, 12th lowest nationally, in 2018.

sentence: Virginia has the highest defence spending in all states per capita, providing the Commonwealth with approximately 900,000 jobs.

sentence: Many Virginians work for federal agencies in Northern Virginia, including the Central Intelligence Agency and the Department of Defence, as well as the National Science Foundation, the United States Geological Survey and the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

sentence: Virginia has the highest concentration of technology workers in any state, and the fourth largest number of technology workers after California, Texas, and New York.

name: virginia
sentence: Tourism in Virginia supported some 234,000 jobs in 2018, making tourism the fifth largest business line in the state.

name: virginia
sentence: In 2017, agriculture occupied 28 per cent of Virginia's land with 7.8 million acres (12,188 m2; 31,565 km2) of agricultural land.

sentence: Nearly 54,000 Virginians work on 43,225 farms in the state, representing an average of 181 acres (0.28 m2; 0.73 km2).

name: virginia
sentence: Although agriculture has declined significantly since 1960, when there were twice as many farms, it remains the largest industry in Virginia, accounting for over 334,000 jobs.

sentence: Commercial fisheries support 18,220 jobs starting in 2020, while recreational fisheries support 5,893 other jobs.

sentence: Virginia collects personal income tax from those whose income exceeds a production threshold; there are five income brackets, with rates ranging from 2.0% to 5.75 percent of taxable income.

name: virginia
sentence: Unlike most states, Virginia collects a sales tax on food products, but at a lower rate than the general sales tax; the sales tax on foodstuffs and certain essential personal health products is 2.5%.

sentence: Virginia property tax is established and collected at the local government level and varies throughout the Commonwealth.

sentence: Temperatures in the western region were only 107°F (42°C) in Centralia and up to 6°F (−21°C) in Longview.

name: washington
sentence: Forests cover about half of the state's land, mainly west of the Northern Cascades.

name: washington
sentence: Approximately two-thirds of Washington's forest area is owned by the state, including 64 per cent of federal land.

name: washington
sentence: Common trees and plants in the area are camassia, Douglas-fir, hemlock, penstemon, ponderosa pine, western red cedar, and many species of ferns.

name: washington
sentence: The various wild areas of the state provide a sanctuary, with substantial populations of shorebirds and marine mammals.

name: washington
sentence: The Pacific coasts surrounding the San Juan Islands are heavily populated by white-headed, grey-headed and humpback whales.

name: washington
sentence: In eastern Washington, the flora is very different.

name: washington
sentence: Tumbleweeds and sage dominate the landscape in much of the countryside.

name: washington
sentence: Russian olive trees and other trees are common on river banks; however, with the exception of river banks, huge parts of eastern Washington have no natural trees at all (although many trees have been planted and are irrigated by people, of course).

name: washington
sentence: There is a greater variety of flora in both the blue mountains and the eastern slopes of the Cascades.

name: washington
sentence: Native state mammals include bat, black bear, bobcat, cougar, coyote, deer, elk, grey wolf, hare, moose, mountain beaver, muskrat, opossum, pocket gopher, rabbit, raccoon, river otter, squirrel and squirrel.

name: washington
sentence: Due to the wide geographic diversity, Washington State is home to several different ecoregions, allowing for a wide range of bird species.

sentence: This range includes raptors, shorebirds, forest birds, prairie birds, ducks and others.

name: washington
sentence: There have also been a large number of species introduced in Washington, D.C., dating back to the early 18th century, including horses and burros.

sentence: Catfish, lamprey and channel sturgeon are among the 400 known freshwater fish.

sentence: Berries and coastal islands are often inhabited by numerous quantities of molluscs and whales.

sentence: There are five species of salmon that go up in western Washington State, from streams to spawning grounds.

name: washington
sentence: Washington has a variety of National Parks Service units.

name: washington
sentence: These include Alta State National Park, Roosevelt Lake National Recreation Area, San Juan Islands National Wildlife Refuge, and three national parks – Olympic National Park, Northern Cascade National Park and Mount Rainier National Park.

name: washington
sentence: The three national parks were established between 1899 and 1968.

name: washington
sentence: Nearly 95% (876,517 acres, 354,714 hectares, 3,547.14 square kilometres) of the Olympic National Park area were designated as wilderness areas under the National Nature Conservation System.

name: washington
sentence: In addition, 143 national parks and 9 national forests are managed by the Washington State Park System and the United States Forest Service.

name: washington
sentence: Okanogan National Forest is the largest national forest on the west coast, totalling 1,499,023 acres (606,633 ha).

sentence: It is managed together as the national forest Okanogan-Wenatchee, covering a considerably larger area of about 3,239,404 acres (1,310,940 ha).

sentence: The area has been known to host megathrust earthquakes in the past, the last being the Cascadia earthquake of 1700.

name: washington
sentence: Prior to the arrival of Europeans, the region had many established tribes of American natives, remarkable for their totem poles and their adorned canoes and masks.

sentence: The peoples of the interior had a very different subsistence culture based on hunting, gathering food and certain forms of agriculture, as well as on the dependence of the salmon of Colombia and its tributaries.

sentence: The smallpox epidemic of the 1770s devastated the Amerindian population.

name: washington
sentence: The first European landing recorded on the Washington coast was by Spanish captain Don Bruno de Heceta in 1775, aboard the Santiago, part of a two-ship fleet with the Sonora.

name: washington
sentence: He claims the coastal lands to Prince William Sound for Spain as part of their rights under the Treaty of Tordesillas, which they maintain to make the Pacific a "Spanish lake" and all its shores are part of the Spanish Empire.

name: washington
sentence: In 1778 Captain James Cook, a British explorer, saw Cape Flattery at the entrance to Juan de Fuca Strait, but Cook did not realize that the Strait existed.

name: washington
sentence: The British-Spanish Nootka convention of 1790 ended Spanish exclusivity claims and opened the Northwest Coast to explorers and traders from other nations, including Great Britain and Russia, as well as the nascent United States.

name: washington
sentence: American captain Robert Gray (for whom Grays Harbor County is named) then discovered the mouth of the Columbia River.

sentence: The Lewis and Clark expedition entered the state on October 10, 1805.

sentence: Explorer David Thompson, on his journey on the Columbia River, encamped at the confluence of the Snake River on July 9, 1811, erected a post and notice claiming the country to Great Britain and stating the intention of the Northwest Company to build a trading post on the site.

name: washington
sentence: Britain and the United States have accepted what has since been described as a "joint occupation" of land west of the continental ditch to the Pacific Ocean under the Anglo-American Convention of 1818, which establishes the 49th parallel as the international boundary west of Lake of the Woods to the Rocky Mountains.

name: washington
sentence: The resolution of territorial and treaty issues in the western Pacific has been postponed to a later date.

name: washington

name: washington
sentence: Negotiations with Great Britain over the next few decades have failed to resolve a compromise border and the dispute over the Oregon border has been highly contested between Great Britain and the United States.

name: washington
sentence: The common occupation between Britain and the United States lasted several decades.

name: washington
sentence: While American settlers were pouring into Oregon Country, the Hudson's Bay Company, which had previously discouraged the settlement because it was in conflict with the fur trade, reversed its position in an attempt to maintain British control of the Columbia District.

name: washington
sentence: James Sinclair, by order of Sir George Simpson, governor of the Hudson's Bay Company, brought some 200 settlers from the Red River colony to the west in 1841 to settle on Hudson's Bay Company farms near Fort Vancouver.

name: washington
sentence: The group crossed the Rocky Mountains in the Columbia Valley, near today Radium Hot Springs, British Columbia, then travelled southwest of the Kootenai River and the Columbia River.

name: washington
sentence: Despite these efforts, Britain finally ceded all land claims south of the 49th parallel to the United States in the Oregon Treaty on 15 June 1846.

name: washington
sentence: In 1836, a group of missionaries, including Marcus Whitman, established several missions and the own colony of Whitman Waiilatpu, in what is now the southeastern state of Washington, near the county of Walla Walla, today, on the territory of the Cayuse and Nez Perce Indian tribes.

name: washington
sentence: In 1843 Whitman's settlement would help the Oregon Trail, the land-emigration route to the west, settle for thousands of emigrants in the following decades.

name: washington
sentence: Marcus provided medical care to the Amerindians, but when Indian patients, who were not immune to new "European" diseases, died in striking numbers, while at the same time many white patients recovered, they held "the man of medicine" Marcus Whitman personally responsible, and murdered Whitman and twelve other white settlers in the Whitman massacre in 1847.

name: washington
sentence: This event triggered the Cayuse War between settlers and Indians.

name: washington
sentence: Fort Nisqually, a firm and trading post of the Hudson's Bay Company and the first European settlement in the Puget Sound area, was founded in 1833.

name: washington
sentence: Black pioneer George Washington Bush and his Caucasian wife, Isabella James Bush of Missouri and Tennessee, respectively, led four white families in the territory and founded New Market, now Tumwater, in 1846.

name: washington
sentence: They settled in Washington to avoid the law of black exclusion of Oregon, which prohibited African Americans from entering the country while prohibiting slavery.

name: washington
sentence: After them, many other settlers, migrating over land along the Oregon Trail, wandered north to settle in the Puget Sound area.

sentence: The growing population of Oregon north of the Columbia River has formally requested a new territory.

name: washington
sentence: Following the Monticello Convention, held today in Cowlitz County, Congress passed a law and President Millard Fillmore signed the law on 2 March 1853, creating a new territory in Washington.

name: washington
sentence: The border of the territory of Washington first extended eastward than that of the present state, including what is now the Idaho Panhandle and parts of western Montana, and collected more land to the southeast that was left behind when Oregon was admitted as a state.

name: washington
sentence: The creation of the territory of Idaho in 1863 established the last eastern border.

name: washington
sentence: A constitution of the state of Washington was drafted and ratified in 1878, but it was never formally adopted.

name: washington
sentence: Although never approved by Congress, the 1878 Constitution is an important historical document that shows the political thinking of the time.

name: washington

sentence: In eastern Washington, the Yakima River Valley is known for its apple orchards, while wheat growth using dry growing techniques has become particularly productive.

name: washington
sentence: The state of Washington is one of seven states that do not levy personal income taxes.

name: washington
sentence: The Crown also does not collect corporate income tax or deductible.

name: washington
sentence: Washington companies are responsible for various other government levies, including business tax and labour tax (B & O), a gross revenue tax that imposes variable rates for different types of businesses.

name: washington
sentence: The sales tax on the Washington State base is 6.5%, which is combined with a local sales tax that varies by locality.

name: washington
sentence: The combined rates of government sales tax and local retail sales tax increase the taxes paid by consumers, depending on the variable rates of local sales tax, generally between 7.5% and 10%.

name: washington
sentence: In March 2017, the combined sales tax rate in Seattle and Tacoma was 10.1%.

name: washington
sentence: The cities of Lynnwood and Mill Creek have the highest sales tax rate in the state at 10.5%.

name: washington
sentence: These taxes apply to both services and products.

name: washington
sentence: Most foods are exempt from sales tax.

name: washington
sentence: However, prepared foods, food supplements and soft drinks remain taxable.

name: washington
sentence: An excise tax applies to certain products such as gasoline, cigarettes and alcoholic beverages.

name: washington
sentence: Property tax was the first tax levied in the state of Washington, and its collection accounts for about 30 per cent of the total revenue of the state and local governments in Washington.

name: washington
sentence: It continues to be the main source of income for public schools, fire protection, libraries, parks and recreation, and other special-purpose districts.

name: washington
sentence: All real and personal property is subject to tax, unless specifically exempted by law.

name: washington
sentence: Most personal property owned by individuals is exempt from tax.

name: washington
sentence: Personal property tax applies to personal property used in the conduct of a business or to other personal property not exempt by law.

name: washington
sentence: All property taxes are paid to the treasurer's office in the county where the property is located.

name: washington
sentence: Washington does not tax intangible assets, such as bank accounts, shares or bonds.

name: washington
sentence: The State also does not calculate tax on retirement income earned and received from another State.

name: washington
sentence: Washington does not collect taxes on the estate.

name: washington
sentence: However, estate tax is decoupled from federal estate tax laws and, as a result, the Crown imposes its own estate tax.

name: washington
sentence: The state of Washington has the 18th highest effective per capita tax rate in the United States in 2017.

sentence: Their tax policy differs from that of neighbouring Oregon, which does not collect sales tax but imposes a personal income tax.

name: washington
sentence: For 2013, the total value of Washington's agricultural products was $10.2 billion.In 2013, Washington ranked first among the countries in the production of red raspberries (92.7 per cent of total U.S. production), hops (79.2 per cent), mint oil (72.9 per cent), ruffled seed peas (60 per cent), apples (57%), sweet cherries (50.9 per cent), pears (49.5 per cent), Concord grapes (36.5 per cent).

sentence: Washington produces seven main varieties of apples that are exported to more than 60 countries.

sentence: Washington ranks second in the United States in wine production, behind only California.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia was the only state in the Union to separate from a confederate state (Virginia) during the American civil war.

name: west_virginia

Carlile favoured the immediate formation of a new state, while others led by Waitman Willey argued that, since Virginia's secession had not yet been adopted by the required referendum (as happened on 23 May), such action would constitute a revolution against the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The convention decided that if the Virginians adopted the secession order (of which there was little doubt), another convention, including the elected members of the legislature, would meet at Wheeling in June 1861.

sentence: On May 23, 1861, the secession was ratified by a large majority in Virginia as a whole, but in the western counties 34,677 voted against and 19,121 voted in favour.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Second Wheeling Convention met as agreed on 11 June and stated that, since the Secession Convention had been called without popular consent, all its actions were null and void and all those who had acceded to it had left their offices.

sentence: The Wheeling Conventions, and the delegates themselves, were never elected by public ballot to act on behalf of Western Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Located in the Appalachian Mountains, West Virginia covers an area of 62,754.8 km2, with 62,361.0 km2 of land and 393.8 km2 of water, making it the 41st state of the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia borders Pennsylvania and Maryland in the northeast, Virginia in the southeast, Ohio in the northwest and Kentucky in the southwest.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Its longest border is with Virginia at 381 miles (613 km), followed by Ohio at 243 miles (391 km), Maryland at 174 miles (280 km), Pennsylvania at 118 miles (190 km) and Kentucky at 79 miles (127 km).

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is entirely located in the Appalachian region, and the state is almost entirely mountainous, giving reason to the nickname The Mountain State and the motto Montani Semper Liberi ("The mounttains are always free").

name: west_virginia
sentence: Altitude and robustness fall near large rivers such as the Ohio River or the Shenandoah River.

name: west_virginia
sentence: About 75% of the state is located in the Cumberland Plateau and the Allegheny Plateau.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Although the terrain is not high, the plateau is extremely rugged in most areas.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The average altitude of West Virginia is about 1,500 feet (460 m) above sea level, which is the highest of all U.S. states east of Mississippi.

name: west_virginia
sentence: On the eastern line of the state with Virginia, high peaks in the Monongahela National Forest region create an island of colder climate and ecosystems similar to those in northern New England and eastern Canada.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The highest point in the state is the summit of Spruce Knob at 1,482 m (1,863 feet) and is covered in dense spruce boreal forest at altitudes greater than 1,200 m (1,000 feet).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Spruce Knob is located in Monongahela National Forest and is part of Spruce Knob-Senatorca Rocks National Recreation Area.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A total of six wild areas are also found in the forest.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Outside the forest to the south, the gorge of the New River is a 300 m deep canyon carved by the New River.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The National Parks Service manages a portion of the gorge and river that has been designated as the New River Gorge National Park and Reserve.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Other areas of protection and management include:

name: west_virginia
sentence: Most of West Virginia lies in the mixed ecoregion of the Appalachian Mesophyte forests, while the high elevations along the eastern border and in the panhandle lie in the Appalachian forests and the blue ridge.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The native vegetation of most of the state was originally a mixed forest of hardwood oak, chestnut, maple, beech and white pine, with American willow and sycamore along the state's waterways.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Many of these areas are rich in biodiversity and scenic beauty, a fact appreciated by native Virginians, who refer to their home as almost paradise (from the song, "Take Me Home, Country Roads" by John Denver).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Before the song, it was known as "The Cog State" (coal, oil and gas) or "The Mountain State".

name: west_virginia
sentence: The underlying rock strata are sandstone, shale, bituminous coal deposits, and limestone laid in an environment close to the coast from sediments from the mountains to the east in a shallow inland sea to the west.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Some beds illustrate a coastal swampy environment, a river delta, some shallow waters.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The sea level rose and fell several times during the Mississippi and Pennsylvania eras, giving a variety of rocky strata.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Appalachians are some of the oldest in the world, having formed more than 300 million years ago.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia's climate is generally a humid subtropical climate (climate classification of Köppen Cfa, except Dfb at higher altitudes) with warm to hot, humid and cold winters, increasing in severity with altitude.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Some regions of the southern highlands also have a temperate mountain climate (Köppen Cfb) where winter temperatures are more moderate and summer temperatures slightly cooler.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, time is subject in all parts of the state to change.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Hardiness zones range from zone 5b in the Central Appalachian Mountains to zone 7a in the warmest parts of the lowest heights.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the Eastern Panhandle and Ohio Valley, temperatures are warm enough to see and cultivate subtropical plants such as Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Myrtle Crepe, Albizia julibrisin, American sweetgum and even needle palm and occasional minor sabal.

name: west_virginia
sentence: These plants do not thrive as well in other parts of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The prickly pear of the east grows well in many parts of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Average January temperatures range from about 26°F (−4°C) near the Cheat River to 41°F (5°C) along the sections of the Kentucky border.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The July averages range from 67°F (19°C) along the Potomac North Branch River to 76°F (24°C) in the western part of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is cooler in the mountains than in the lower parts of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The highest temperature recorded in the state is 112°F (44°C) at Martinsburg on 10 July 1936 and the lowest temperature recorded in the state is -37°F (−38°C) at Lewisburg on 30 December 1917.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Annual precipitation ranges from less than 32 inches (810 mm) in the lower east to more than 56 inches (1,400 mm) in the upper parts of the alleghenous forehead.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The eastern valleys are less rainy because the ridges of the Allegheny mountains to the west create a partial rain shadow.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Just over half of the precipitation occurs from April to September.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Dense fogs are common in many valleys of the Kanawha section, particularly in the Tygart Valley.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is also one of the most cloudy states in the nation, with the cities of Elkins and Beckley ranking 9th and 10th respectively in the United States for the number of cloudy days per year (over 210).

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition to the persistent cloudy sky caused by the degradation of moisture by the Alleghenies, West Virginia also experiences some of the most frequent precipitation in the nation, with an average of snowshoes of nearly 200 days a year with rain or snow.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Snow usually lasts only a few days in the lower parts, but may persist for weeks in the upper mountainous areas.

name: west_virginia
sentence: On average, 34 inches (860 mm) of snow fall each year in Charleston, although in the winter of 1995-96, more than three times that amount declined, with several cities in the state setting new snowfall records.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Average snowfall in the Highlands of Allegheny can reach up to 180 inches (4,600 mm) per year.

name: west_virginia

sentence: The West Virginia Legislature is bicameral.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It consists of the Chamber of Deputies and the Senator, both housed in the Capitol of the state of West Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is a citizen legislature, which means that the legislative office is not a full-time profession, but rather a part-time position.

name: west_virginia
sentence: As a result, legislators often have full-time employment in their community of residence.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Usually, the legislature is in session for 60 days between January and early April.

sentence: Wisconsin is a state in the U.S. Midwest Great Lakes region bordered by Minnesota in the west; Iowa in the southwest; Illinois in the south; Lake Michigan in the east; Michigan in the northeast; and Lake Superior in the north.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The word Wisconsin comes from the name given to the Wisconsin River by one of the Algonquian Amerindian groups living in the region at the time of European contact.

name: wisconsin
sentence: French explorer Jacques Marquette was the first European to reach the Wisconsin River, arriving in 1673 and calling the Meskousing River (probably "meskowsin") in his newspaper.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Subsequently, French writers changed the spelling of Meskousing to Ouisconsin, which over time became the name of the Wisconsin River and the surrounding lands.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Anglophones anglicize Ouisconsin's spelling in Wisconsin when they began to arrive in large numbers at the beginning of the 19th century.

name: wisconsin

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Algonquian word for Wisconsin and its original meaning have become obscure.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Although interpretations vary, most involve the river and the red sandstone bordering its banks.

name: wisconsin
sentence: A main theory argues that the name comes from the word Miami Meskonsing, meaning "it is red", a reference to the setting of the Wisconsin River as it flows through the reddish sandstone of the Dells of Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Other theories include allegations that the name comes from a variety of Ojibwas words meaning "red stone place", "where waters come together," or "great rock."
